PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HON. MR JUSTICE LIONEL MURPHY, QC

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 21 October 1986 of the Hon. Mr Justice Murphy, QC, former senator for the State of New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 21 October 1986, of the Hon. Mr Justice Lionel Keith Murphy, QC, senator for the State of New South Wales from 1962 to 1975, Leader of the Opposition in the Senate from 1967 to 1972, Leader of the Government in the Senate and a Minister of the Crown from 1972 to 1975, and a justice of the High Court of Australia from 1975, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his widow and the members of his family in their bereavement.

Lionel Keith Murphy's death has taken from us a distinguished Australian. There are many here in the Senate who knew him much better than I did, who had much closer associations with him, who worked with him and who, in a sense, would regard themselves as almost lifelong friends of Lionel Murphy. The things I want to say are, in a sense, on behalf of the Government, somewhat formal things which have and ought to be recorded. Others will make, I have no doubt, personal comments which relate to particular relationships which they had with Lionel Murphy during his long and very varied career.

Lionel Murphy was born in 1922. He spent his youth in Sydney. He began his academic life at Sydney Boys High School, going on to Sydney University where his brilliance was rewarded with honours degrees in science and law. At university he began his lifelong association with the labour movement and the Australian Labor Party. He was admitted to the Bar of the Supreme Court of New South Wales in 1947, and he was created a Queen's Counsel in 1960.

In 1962 his deep political convictions and concern about social justice and reform led him into the Senate. He displayed here a tenacity, energy and decisiveness which led to rapid recognition and respect from both his colleagues and his opponents. In 1967 he became Leader of the Opposition in this chamber. As Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Lionel Murphy was pre-eminent in the renaissance of the Senate. It was his energy and determination that led to the reformation of the Senate committee system. Perhaps those of us who have followed him have not been sufficiently lateral in our thinking about how that system might be developed even further. Today the Senate committee system is regarded as an important arena of public debate and social change. Those who today praise and hold up the Senate as an important and valued institution should not forget the role of Lionel Murphy in the creation of that system.

Lionel Murphy played a pivotal role in the 1972 election victory of the Australian Labor Party. He served in the Whitlam Government as Leader of the Government in the Senate, as Attorney-General and as the Minister for Customs and Excise. During that time he presided over a period of legal and social reform unparalleled in Australia's history. His reforms were both real and enduring. To achieve reform Lionel Murphy was prepared to shake tradition and to disturb slow and hide-bound legal systems. He established the Australian Legal Aid Office, enshrining the principle that all Australians should have equal access to the courts. The principle was the important thing. He established the Law Reform Commission as a permanent means of challenging the relevance of laws and pursuing equity within the law. He introduced the Family Law Act and the institution of the Family Court of Australia. Despite all of the difficulties and anguish which are associated with that institution, it was perhaps his greatest achievement. Lionel Murphy had the strength, I believe, to remove some of the odium of moral judgment from the law which so plagued the divorce courts prior to the establishment of the Family Court system.

He overhauled and strengthened trade practices legislation, giving meaningful protection to consumers. In the non-legislative sphere his most dramatic achievement was to take to the International Court of Justice in The Hague, Australia's case against French nuclear tests in the Pacific. In 1975 Lionel Murphy was appointed to the High Court of Australia. He maintained on the Bench his compassion, his concern for the less privileged and his commitment to the principle of equality before the law. His judgments reflected unwavering concern for the individual and opposition to obstruction and entrenched self-interests and privilege.

As I said, I did not know Lionel Murphy well personally, particularly compared with my other colleagues in the Senate. Whatever differences or criticisms may be made about Lionel Murphy, there are certain undeniable things about his character which greatly appealed to me. First of all, he was a lateral thinker of a very big kind. One of the most fascinating discussions I have ever had with anybody was with Lionel Murphy when he explained to me at great length the changes that he felt would be brought about in society by the invention of the photocopy machine. We have all suffered from those changes. I suppose, in a sense, we have all bene- fited from them and society has benefited from them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That includes freedom of information.

—Yes, precisely. It was a fascinating discussion which I have never forgotten. All my friends and colleagues here often have unmemorable conversations, but that was a totally memorable conversation which took place many years ago. It reflected his great scientific interests which were sometimes forgotten because of his role as a lawyer. I believe he had a fascinating mind and, above all, that he was a man of great personal charm. He seemed to me to have worked wherever he went, including on the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: Lionel Murphy's life was remarkable for the enormous contributions he made in diverse aspects of Australian life as a barrister, parliamentarian, Minister and jurist. We have lost a man of vision, a man of compassion and, as the last months have so tragically underscored-something which I think was obvious to those who knew him before, but the last months have underscored it-a man of immeasureable courage. On behalf of the Government, I extend to his wife, Ingrid, his daughter, Lorel, and his sons, Blake and Cameron, our very deep sympathy and condolences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I indicate our support for the motion of condolence moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. Senator Button has already outlined the record of party, parliamentary and judicial service of the late Lionel Murphy. That service included leading his Party in the Senate both in opposition and in government, and involved a two-year period as Attorney-General and Minister for Customs and Excise. His career was wide ranging and, given the nature, great energies and wide interest of the man, inevitably controversial. I think it would be fair to say that was so when he served in opposition as well as in government, and indeed in his subsequent career on the Bench.

SPEECH.PARA: He was a man who inspired, great admiration and affection as well as strong opposition. I and my Opposition colleagues certainly stood in strong opposition to many of his ideas, while finding common ground with him on issues such as the development of the Senate committee system. The recent Senate committee report on in vitro fertilisation is a reminder of the value of the committee work of this chamber which he helped to foster. I served in the Senate for only a brief period while he was here, from mid-1974 to February 1975. In that brief time I had enough contact with him to understand some of the qualities that his friends found so attractive. He was convivial and hospitable, and notwithstanding his controversial role in Australian politics at that time he was very easy in his social relationships across party lines. He will be remembered for his contribution to the development of the Senate committee system and for some of the legislative initiatives which were undertaken by him during his period as Attorney-General. It is worth noting that the legislation most likely to be associated with his name, the Family Law Act, remains controversial to this day.

In speaking of the late Lionel Murphy I have used the word `controversial' a number of times and it does seem peculiarly apt when one remembers his life and career. Because of that he was often involved in strenuous differences with the Opposition and in some very strong personal clashes. Since coming to this place I have not been a keen reader of High Court judgments. On the basis of what I have read, however, it is clear that as a member of the High Court, Lionel Murphy brought an approach which was significantly different from that adopted by most judges in the past, not least because of his strong interest in United States precedents. I have no doubt that future legal scholars will study his influence on the Court and that by his judgments he will be seen to have made a contribution which is quite out of the ordinary.

His death was untimely given his age and the youth of his family. It was untimely also in that it left unfinished some of the final controversial issues that were so much a part of the pattern of his life. His death is a great loss to his wife, his young family and his many friends. On behalf of the Opposition I extend my sympathy to his wife, Ingrid, and his family, and to his friends both here and elsewhere, on account of his death and on account of the suffering they shared with him during his illness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party of Australia I support the condolence motion moved by Senator Button. Senator Button has detailed Mr Justice Lionel Murphy's lengthy political and judicial service to the Australian nation. While I did not sit in the Senate during his time here I fully recognise and support his efforts to enhance the role of the Senate by expanding the work of the committee system. This will be a continuing monument to his drive and energy. Mr Justice Murphy was a man with a vision. He knew what type of society he wanted for Australia and he worked tirelessly all of his public life to bring about his vision of the just society. Although I did not share his vision for Australia and I did not condone his willingness to sweep aside any social or political institution that stood in the way of achieving that vision which he pursued so assiduously, I admired the man for attempting to fulfil his dreams.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Justice Murphy, like all of us on the public stage, can only be judged by history. He will be remembered as a man who made a great effort to achieve his objectives. He faced his final months with dignity and with courage. On behalf of my National Party colleagues I extend our sympathy to his wife, Ingrid, and the other members of his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I support the condolence motion moved by Senator Button on the death of Lionel Murphy, a death which brings to an end, I think we would all agree, a remarkable, colourful and, as the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) has said, controversial career. Even the bare essentials of Lionel Murphy's career in politics and in law make an impressive list and an impressive impact on those who are aware of them, even if such people are not aware of the personality of the man. A science and law graduate, he became one of the busiest industrial barristers in New South Wales. Lionel Murphy entered the Parliament in 1962. Within five years he was Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and then Attorney-General in the Whitlam Government. In 1975 he was appointed to the High Court of Australia, where he remained until his death.

SPEECH.PARA: The details of his extraordinary and distinguished career are even more impressive. As has already been indicated, the Senate was a moribund place when he entered it and he did a great deal to revive it. He was a great believer in effective parliamentary supervision over the administration of government. That continued when he moved from the Opposition benches to the Government benches. He strongly supported the committee system which is so valuable a part of the Senate today. As Attorney-General he initiated significant reforms in family law, consumer protection, anti-trust laws, legal aid and civil liberties-reforms which were not always welcomed in quarters where people preferred things not to change.

As a judge on the High Court, he showed a willingness to set aside precedent to achieve a just result, and a determination to use the sort of language in his judgments that made the Court's work more understandable and hence more accessible to the people. As a small part of making the courts more human, he went wigless for all but the most ceremonial occasions and, essentially, remained his own man even on the highest court in the land.

As honourable senators have already said, there is no denying that controversy attended his long and distinguished career. Of course, that is often the case with those who question the status quo and who seek to effect change in one area or another. He has been variously described as brilliant, as accident-prone; and as a stormy petrel. But he was in fact a man of courage, determination and integrity. Despite the apparent contradictions that appeared, his central interest, for example, in reforms to protect minority groups who were harshly treated had to be set against his considerable respect for established values. A believer in simplifying and demystifying the law, he was a vigorous and effective speaker and passionate about the issues that concerned him. Because he wore his political and social heart on his sleeve, his appointment to the High Court was described as too political. Apart from the fact that he was eminently suited for the appointment, his openness about his convictions was in fact a great virtue and put paid to the ridiculous notion that other appointments to the High Court, or indeed to any other court in Australia, are politically neutral. Of course, with the passage of time, his more liberal values came to be shared by more of his fellow judges.

Tragically, the latter years of his life were clouded by events which I do not believe bear reiteration today. Suffice it to say that his more lasting legacy will be his considerable achievements in law reform and human rights. That legacy includes the Trade Practices Act, the Family Law Act, the Law Reform Commission and the Australian Legal Aid Office, to name but a few, and his many judgments which emphasised the enhancement of personal freedom and the prevention of discrimination. This unashamed reformist will long be remembered as a man of the people and for the people. Through his death, Australia has lost one of its most distinguished reformers and jurists. We are much the poorer for that. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I extend our deepest sympathy to his wife and children, whose strength and support were an integral part of his strength and determination to do what he believed was right, proper and in the interests of justice for all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those of us who knew Lionel Murphy as a colleague in the Senate and in the Australian Labor Party remember him as a man who approached his work with passion and compassion, with a reforming zeal, and who combined intellectual rigour with the capacity for lateral thought that my colleague Senator Button spoke about. He was gregarious; he was very human; he was never dull. He was at times unpredictable, always I suppose iconoclastic, but a person of great personal charm and a man I was very pleased to know.

SPEECH.PARA: A passionate approach to life makes many people in our society uncomfortable. Compassion is often seen as weakness. Intellectual rigour in this community is always suspect, for some reason, particularly by those who do not like to see the status quo or existing values questioned. Reform, of course, is always opposed by those who would protect their vested interests and who would ossify the institutions of this country in doing so. Any person who combined those traits with the intelligence and the communicating ability of Lionel Murphy obviously was opposed, and opposed vigorously, and obviously made enemies. Those enemies in fact pursued him relentlessly.

When the history of legal aid, law reform, family law, administrative law, the High Court of Australia, the Senate and its system, and the protection of civil liberties in this country is written-as it is being written-the name `Lionel Murphy' will be there prominently and will continue to be there as long as those history books exist. Ironically, there will be other names in those history books. There will be politicians, judges, lawyers and journalists whose names will be there only because they took part in the hounding of this good and decent man.

I knew Lionel Murphy personally, but not as well as some people did. I knew him as a very decent human being who was not perfect and who, because he was not perfect, I suppose, had people who considered that they were his enemies. But he did not take that approach. I, like my colleague Senator John Button, had memorable and long conversations with Lionel Murphy on all sorts of subjects. I will always remember, when I was Deputy Leader of the Opposition in this place, his coming over from the High Court, storming into this building and thumping the table at me and demanding that I do something about what he saw as the unfair treatment of an individual in this place. He demanded that I do something about what he saw as the infringement of someone's civil liberties and the infringement of someone's capacity to act in the position to which he had been elected. The irony of that is that that person believed, I know until recently and probably still now believes, that Lionel Murphy was his enemy and that Lionel Murphy not only did not like him but also vigorously opposed him because of his views. Murphy was passionate and he was vigorous in putting forward his ideas. But at the same time he was very fair and would defend principles. He was more concerned about principles than about pursuing personal vendettas.

We all will leave this world saying that there were certain people we were pleased to have known. I am very pleased to have known Lionel Murphy. To Ingrid, Lorel, Cameron and Blake I give my deepest condolences now, and I will do so personally later. It is a sad day when we in this place have to say farewell to a colleague; but at least it is a colleague who will never be forgotten in the history books of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It cannot be said too often that Lionel Murphy was a great reforming Attorney-General, a great reforming judge and a great Australian, and that his death, particularly in the circumstances of the last 2 1/2 years of his life, is a great Australian tragedy. As passionately as I feel about the injustice, the outrageousness of the campaign that was waged so mercilessly against him, and inevitably his family, over the last 2 1/2 years, I do not think that this is the occasion to dwell on any of that, except to say again, as I have said so many times in this place, that I will never believe that the Age tapes material or any other material of which I was aware as Attorney-General, or am aware now, was such as to justify the criminal charges alleged against him or his removal from the High Court of Australia. History will judge Lionel Murphy much more kindly than it will his detractors and persecutors.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a time, rather, to focus on those things by which I believe Lionel Murphy will be positively and affirmatively remembered, not only by his colleagues, friends and family, but by the whole Australian community. As Attorney- General in the Whitlam Labor Government, Lionel Murphy introduced some of the most far-reaching and enduring reforming legislation since Federation. The Trade Practices Act, the Family Law Act and Australian Legal Aid Office are all monuments to his energy and creativity. The Racial Discrimination Act, the system of administrative appeals, the Human Rights Commission and Australian Law Reform Commission, the Australian Institute of Criminology all owe their origins to him, although not all were fully in place by the time he left government.

A common thread running through nearly all these reforms was Lionel's uncanny capacity to detect the important issues of his time and of the future. His energy and enthusiasm in his portfolio to righting extended not only domestic wrongs but also those on the international stage. His advocacy on Australia's behalf before the International Court of Justice against French atmospheric nuclear tests in the Pacific was perhaps the most graphic and effective demonstration of that commitment.

I worked with him as a consultant on human rights legislation for most of his time as Attorney-General, and it was a pretty heady experience. Trying to describe both the atmosphere of the time and the achievement, I wrote somewhere once that the Murphy years had about them all the exhilaration, and most of the danger, of a careering downhill toboggan. It was not a time for legal wowsers. Public opinion in the Murphy philosophy was there to be led, not cautiously and nervously followed a step at a time. It could have all gone disastrously wrong and become a succession of Australian Security Intelligence Organisation raids, entirely defensible in principle but conceived in a hurry, embraced with excitement, executed with vigour and then repented thereafter at leisure. But somehow it did all come together. The Murphy years in government were years of marvellous, lasting, recognised achievement. It was a demonstration of the art of the possible in government, as I have said elsewhere, and provided a model, a touchstone for any Labor reformer of the future. It has been a hard act, as I well know, for any would-be Labor reformer to follow.

On the High Court of Australia, Lionel Murphy did nothing but enhance his reputation. His judgments may not always have been meticulously crafted, in purely technical terms, as some traditionalists would like, but they were always full of intelligence, creativity, comparative learning and sound common sense. They have had the effect of convincing a great many people of his concern with the common sense and practical application of the law, and his conviction that the High Court can be and should be the place where ultimate justice can be sought and obtained.

His first main achievement as a judge was simply to be taken very seriously very quickly by the legal profession and by his brethren. There were many, as we all know, who came originally to scoff and to criticise, but who stayed to admire his handling of his role on the Bench, his handling of some complex pieces of litigation andthe way in which he conducted in all sorts of ways his position on the Bench. Very early on I recall, in particular, standing at the Melbourne Bar, watching his handling of the Defence of Government Schools case-the DOGS case-the state aid case, and the way in which the deftness, intelligence, sense and experience with which he handled that enormously complex piece of litigation won him a whole host of admirers from those people at the Melbourne Bar who had been foremost in leading the pack against him at the time of his appointment, and indeed voting against him in that notorious resolution criticising his appointment.

There is no doubt that through that formidable combination of charm, intelligence and breadth of learning, he influenced the attitudes and the approach of his fellow judges. He made a very important contribution to some of the big developments, the changes in direction and emphasis that have occurred in that Court in recent years-in taxation law, criminal law and procedure and, I suppose most memorably, constitutional law. He was not always in the majority and on occasion he was a solo voice, but his voice was never irrelevant on the Court. Of the many landmark judgments in His Honour's judicial career, as a lawyer I think particularly of Buck v. Bavone on section 92, Westraders on tax avoidance, McInnes on the rights of defendants, the Bistricic case on Australia's legal relationship with Britain, and his contributions beyond that to some of the mainstream developments in the constitutional law, in the Social Welfare Union case, the Koowarta case and the Tasmania dam case. I think,too,of his spectacular dissents in, among other cases, the sate aid case and the Northern Land Council case.

All those things are achievements on the public record and they are on display for anyone to see. But finally, I wish to say something about those more personal qualities of the man, which, although they can be pretty readily guessed from the public man-there was always quite a bit of Lionel Murphy on view in more ways than one-were qualities which were perhaps only really visible to those privileged people who worked with him or knew him well personally. Perhaps I should make clear for the record at this point-I do hope that I will not be misunderstood in this respect-that although I worked for Lionel Murphy and I got to know him reasonably well personally over the years, it has never really been accurate to describe me, as the media continually do despite my pleas for them to get it right, as a `close personal friend'. I knew him as I know his widow, Ingrid, no more closely I guess than hundreds of people knew him. Lionel and I were never intimate friends, and if the friendship was sustained at all during the last traumatic two-and-a-half years, it was one that was conducted very much at arms length, as it had to be, given my ministerial role as Attorney-General and again as Acting Attorney-General at various crucial moments.

I make this point for two reasons: First, because to describe our relationship otherwise is to misunderstand the degree of objectivity with which I can talk about him. If I defend and praise Lionel Murphy as warmly as I do, it is not out of emotion or personal loyalty; it is not because I loved him as a mate; it is because I genuinely believe that his life and career demand that measure of respect and that kind of objective assessment. The second point I make-in many ways it is more important-is that I am always a little embarrassed by references to our `close friendship' because it seems to me that that diminishes the quality of the relationship he undoubtedly had with those privileged few, some of them such as George Georges in this chamber, who really were his and Ingrid's intimate and close personal friends.

Having said that, I must add that anyone who knew him at all personally can testify to his marvellous capacity for friendship, his marvellous warmth, his captivating charm, his intense and genuine interest in just about everyone he met, the sheer boisterousness and gregariousness of his personality-sometimes, undoubtedly, an insufficiently discriminating gregariousness-the energy he put, here and everywhere else, into his personal and social relationships. Lionel Murphy must have been a gruelling, but absolutely marvellous person to live with. Of all the losses that I imagine Ingrid, Blake and Cameron have suffered, it may be that the loss of that sheer vital life force in their midst was the greatest one of all.

In my relationship with Lionel Murphy the side of him to which I was most exposed, especially during his political years, and which I now remember with the greatest clarity and most affection and respect, was his sheer dynamic, restless, creative intellectual energy and his fascination with and passion for ideas. It was a passion, it must be said-it has been hinted at already by what Senator John Button and Senator Don Grimes have said-that often proved pretty gruelling for those around him. When he got his teeth into an idea or argument he would worry at it, work at it and pursue it for hours on end, into the small hours of the morning. When the hospitality had been flowing, as it often did, I remember very well sitting around with others in what is now Senator Button's office looking with all of us for matchsticks to prop up our eyelids while Lionel Murphy would still be exuberantly, boisterously going strong, spinning off ideas like sparks from a catherine-wheel.

The ideas and ideals that moved Lionel Murphy most were those of justice, equality and human rights. They were not just abstract concepts to Lionel Murphy; they were concrete, here and now, tangible realities that had to be reached out for and grasped and put into practice, and put into practice with zeal, energy and speed. Everything he did in his public life, and I believe in his private life as well, was directed towards achieving one or other of those ideals and objectives. That, combined with the appetite for life that I and others have tried to describe, made him a very unusual man. There are not many people, particularly in law or politics, who take ideas seriously. Those who do tend not, I guess, to be the gregarious and exuberant type. Lionel Murphy was all those things. He was a unique and splendid individual. I cannot imagine that there will ever be anyone quite like him again in Australian law and politics and we will all be the poorer for his passing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with genuine sadness that I rise to join this condolence motion with respect to an outstanding politician, a distinguished jurist and law reformer and a very great Australian. I do this not only personally, on behalf of my immediate family, my parents and brother and sister, but also on behalf of the many thousands of people outside who have the greatest respect for this great Australian. I do not have to go to the Who's Who or other informative books to remember all of my experiences, both in the personal and political areas, because as we journey through life we have many experiences which are good, bad and indifferent. The one good experience that many of us can refer to is the experience of having received pleasure from working with a person whose integrity, honesty and devotion to principles are foremost in those relationships.

SPEECH.PARA: Lionel Keith Murphy was the most compassionate, generous, able and charming man I have ever met. My life has been enriched, as indeed I believe the Australian community has been enriched, by his contribution to the industrial, political, legal and social areas of our country. From time to time we eulogise about persons who have served in this place and in the other place and the fact that today we have a very substantial number of senators here somewhat tempers my concern over the recent period about the attitudes that have been adopted sometimes in respect of the more difficult experiences which Lionel Murphy had and which undoubtedly contributed to his state of health.

Lionel Murphy was a lover of humanity, no matter where humanity was. He believed that most people were good. He had few personal enemies. However, because he stood for change and for reform, and because that involved him in controversy, he obviously incurred enmity and prejudice, which, to some extent, resulted in personal bitterness. He was, without doubt, a man of the people and for the people. His whole life, his philosophy and his actions were directed towards advantaging the disadvantaged and defending the powerless against the powerful. To that extent, he fell foul of those who believed that their privileged position in society should not be challenged by a person who, from the humblest origins, was able to reach the top and become Attorney-General, and, finally, a member of the High Court of Australia.

I first met Lionel Murphy 34 years ago when he was a young man, in his thirties, beginning his public life in the industrial movement. He was concerned about the struggle for democracy that was going on in a right wing trade union. The management of that industrial organisation was vested in its annual meeting. One hundred members was the quorum required by that industrial organisation to determine its policy and its leadership. The members of the union, who were some of the most exploited members of our society, were endeavouring to change that in order to improve their living standards. He was responsible for giving advice to that rank and file movement, to counter the various pretexts used by the officials of that organisation. Finally, it was determined that the quorum of that organisation should be 1,000 before the effective management could pass to new leadership. I came to know of his concern for democracy and for the little people in that way.

Shortly after that, he wanted to contest a pre-selection ballot for the seat of Phillip. At that stage his colleagues in the steering committee of the New South Wales Branch of the Australian Labor Party prevailed upon him not to do so, because we had agreed in principle that Joe Fitzgerald, who later became a senator in this place, should have that endorsement. However, Mr President, in 1961 we were able to give him support, as we gave you support. I recall those rather difficult and torrid years when we had to take steps to challenge the authority of the leading group in my Party in that State.

It was not long afterwards that Lionel Murphy made his impact in this place. He was responsible for improving the quality of the work of the Senate and the establishment of the committee system, and he gave the Senate a higher profile in its important review activities. Of course, he then became involved in other struggles, such as that against Australia's involvement in the war in Vietnam, and he became involved in the wider issues that faced our society. As has been pointed out by other speakers, as Attorney-General in the Whitlam Government in 1972, he left perhaps his greatest legacy through the law reform he initiated. I recall the affection and the esteem in which he was held by members of the Opposition in that period. I am sure that you, Mr President, will recall those years.

Long after most senators who are now in this chamber have been forgotten the name of Lionel Keith Murphy will be remembered for his innovative contributions to law reform work in the areas of trade practices, because he was concerned about consumers and about proper practices in that area; corporate law; family law, for which he will be particularly remembered by many people in the Australian community; legal aid; administrative law; the Australian Law Reform Commission; the Federal judicial system; international law, including his attempts to have the French condemned for their testing of nuclear devices in the Pacific; environmental law, especially his great contribution to the Franklin Dam issue; criminal law and justice; international trade law, which is very important in world trade today; all those improper practices that take place in the corporate sector; copyright law; constitutional law; and, of course, human rights. As was pointed out last night at the meeting of Amnesty International, he was a founding member of its parliamentary group.

This list can in no way capture the breadth of this man's vision for Australia, the compassion that he had for disadvantaged members of our society, the entirely original and remarkably creative nature of many of his law reform proposals, and particularly the can do mentality which he brought to parliamentary life. No problem, he said, should be put aside because of its difficulty. That was the means by which he was able to make his name in this Parliament. Lionel Murphy's elevation to the High Court of Australia enabled him to take law reform to another sphere. He was undoubtedly an outstanding jurist. He showed a preparedness to cast aside outmoded legal principles and forms. When he discarded the regalia, the outmoded, medieval and feudal means by which these people parade around in their gowns, his very gregarious personality and his desire to remain a man of the people led him into conflict with, and his unorthodoxy put him at a different level to, those with whom he was sharing a new working environment. In those areas of the judiciary there are men who are, by their very nature, conservative in attitude and practice. I have no doubt that for this reason some of his latter difficulties were perhaps emphasised more than they would have otherwise been.

He constantly strove to overcome the undue legalism and slavish adherence to legal precedents, which had characterised the work of many of his judicial predecessors on the High Court, where they stood in the way of ensuring that a just result was reached in the issue before the court. Maybe history will take note of the fact that his judgment in the Chamberlain case was a dissenting one, on which I make no comment other than that the case is again being considered in another judicial setting. It is recognised that a number of his High Court judgments have substantially influenced the development of the law.

I feel very privileged to have known and worked with such a very great Australian. He was, as others said, a warm and compassionate man, and he cared very much about the welfare of others. Not everything that this Senate has done, not everything that this Government has done and not everything that has happened in recent times can we look at now and say: `This was in the best interests of an individual and in the best interests of justice'. I will not go very much further down that track, but I do not think some of these decisions could ever be described as our finest hour.

I believe that Lionel Murphy had the utmost integrity. He was concerned about corruption, not so much in the personal sense but in that of power. That led him down certain paths. This power does not reside solely in this place, in the Parliament; it resides in many other areas outside the Parliament. Lionel Murphy found himself from time to time in conflict with those powerful interests. I have no doubt that when the history of Lionel Keith Murphy is written he will be accorded his proper place in the development of our democratic society. Those who have traduced him, those who have castigated him and those detractors who have written about him should not forget that the difficulties that Lionel Murphy faced in recent years originated in the Queensland Parliament. By taking advantage of a coward's castle, a campaign was unleashed which seriously damaged his reputation and his health. I am not a medico and therefore I am not able to make an expert judgment, but I do believe that stress plays a very important part in our overall health. Politicians are told that when we go for our annual heart check-ups. I have no doubt, as a layman, that over the last two or three years stress played a significant part in Lionel Murphy's ill health and brought his very valuable life to a premature end.

Journalists have a very important role to play in our society. Some journalists, particularly those associated with the Fairfax Press, even in today's editorial, talk about the flaws of this man. How many of us have not got flaws? Which of us believe that somehow or other we have not made mistakes along life's journey? I make no bones about my subjectivity and my concern because I have to live with my own conscience as, indeed, Lionel Murphy had to live with his. He would have been the very last person to be involved in corrupt practices. Yet the National Times and other scribes of the Fairfax organisation pursued this man and, undoubtedly, contributed towards his untimely death. They will be forgotten, whereas Lionel Murphy will be remembered. Some evil things have been done in high places and low places in the judiciary in respect of Lionel Murphy. This is not the time to be very specific about that. Other occasions will enable us to rectify some of those incidents and concerns.

I recall the decision to establish the Senate committee inquiry and the decision to establish the judicial inquiry. I am not proud of the fact that I had to accept those decisions in silence as I had to submit to other disciplines. One does not have to go far back in history to recognise that history adjudicates on these matters, it rectifies things, and when that time comes I have absolutely no doubt that history will come to exactly the same conclusion as those who did know Lionel Keith Murphy intimately, who do know about his integrity, who do know about his compassion and who do know that he was a man who would never have transgressed the proper behaviour of those who hold public office.

Politics becomes distasteful when we seek to score in a personal way-I suppose we are all guilty of that in one way or another, although sometimes I think those in the other place are more guilty of it than we are here-instead of scoring politically, properly, in relation to the role our representation takes. Political prejudice runs very deep. I can understand Mr Fred Daly saying that part of the problem was that Lionel Murphy was a Labor member appointed to the High Court. That is perhaps a little simplistic; I think the issue was fundamentally that he dared to crack that most august place of all in Australian contemporary life, the High Court. In my view he has paid the price for this with his life.

I could talk at greater length but I do recall one experience which demonstrates the humanity of Lionel Murphy. He and I, together with others, were delegates to the Constitutional Convention, I think towards the end of 1973, when he was Attorney-General. We were in the New South Wales State Parliament and a group of militant blacks came to the Parliament to express their concerns about the way in which society was treating them and about their demands for land rights. Like the women out the front of this Parliament House, they did not always distinguish or differentiate between those who were with them and those who were against them. I remember that Lionel and I were regaled, I think by Gary Foley. We listened, we were harangued, and we promised that we would visit the Redfern area to see whether the experiences of the blacks in Redfern were as expressed by the black leadership speaking to us at that time.

To my disgust I saw the way in which the New South Wales Police dealt with blacks in Redfern. What Gary Foley said was correct. Lionel and I visited there one late afternoon or early evening and stood unobtrusively across the road from an hotel to watch the behaviour of those in the area. Every black who came out of the hotel at 10 o'clock was picked up and arrested by the police and put into the paddy wagon whereas all the white Anglo-Saxon Australians, who were just as inebriated as the blacks, were allowed to go. In subsequent discussions with Lionel Murphy, he said: `You have to realise that the prejudice that exists against blacks is in the public sector. It is in the public officials who query the rights of blacks in the Northern Territory and central Australia to have their social security benefits. It is in the police force and in those sorts of people where the prejudice is most expressed'.

Of course, Lionel Murphy was not only associated with those issues to which I have referred. He gave me some understanding of all of the other minority movements. He educated me about the problems of homosexuals as a minority group. He was a person who wanted to play a part in the reforms of our penal institutions, believing that they hardened prisoners rather than rehabilitating them. Of course, he pointed out that there were no votes in that and that probably no government would be prepared to spend sufficient money to overhaul the penal institutions. Nevertheless, he believed it was an issue with which compassionate people should concern themselves.

I have gone over my time. I appreciate the fact that the Senate has given me an opportunity to say something about one of my closest friends and colleagues and a person with whom I have retained friendship over the years despite his august position, my more humble position, and, more recently perhaps, my slightly more exalted position. I enjoyed socialising with him and his family. To Ingrid, Cameron and Blake, and to Lorel, his daughter of a previous marriage, from my wife Dawn, my daughter Dale and my two sons, Lee and Adam, and on behalf of the countless thousands of people who would expect me to speak freely and frankly about Lionel Murphy, I express to the Murphy family, to his brother and to those immediate members to whom I have referred, our profound sympathy in their very untimely and sad loss. It should be known that out there in the Australian community thousands and thousands of people will be mourning the loss of a great Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In moments of sorrow, words of bitterness and anger should be put to one side. But words of bitterness and anger are hard to avoid today. I have said on a previous occasion, when appealing to the Senate on behalf of Lionel Murphy, that we were witnessing a tragedy of classic proportions. At that stage I said that there was one more chapter to unfold. That chapter unfolds today in this place. If I were to express words of bitterness, they would be to those who opposed him and who did not properly understand him. But my words of anger are against those who moved away from him, when he needed assistance, in order to achieve respectability, to protect their respectability, and perhaps to establish a new reputation. I wonder just what those people are thinking. I know what some of them are saying. What they say is hollow. I know what some of them are writing, and what they write is empty.

SPEECH.PARA: Lionel Murphy was a man of great courage, but a courage that he did not express for himself; he expressed it for others. His concern, right up to the very end, was for others. When I spoke to him he was concerned about me and my health, not his own. He was concerned about the position of others. He spoke of things that needed to be done, things that needed to be achieved in the interests of people. He was a great humanist; he was a great human. He endeavoured-and he succeeded in this-to humanise society and to brush aside idle philosophies and superstitions. He did that in the early stages of my knowing him. I remember making a speech during the adjournment debate on the difficulty for those people who sought to be married in a secular way in Queensland. When I got into difficulties-the first of many times that I was in difficulties-he not only came to my assistance and supported me but also eventually made a decision which was to have considerable and far-reaching consequences in our society. One need only look at the number of secular marriages being performed in this country today compared with some 15 years ago to realise just how he was able, by an understanding decision, to ease and alter the lives of ordinary people.

As I said, he was a person of great courage and determination. He wanted the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry to come to an end. He did not care how it came to an end. It came to an end and he was grateful for that, irrespective of the conditions which qualified that decision. He went back to the High Court of Australia in spite of great difficulty and in spite of great opposition in the highest places. He sat in that Court and participated in two cases. He wrote his judgments on them when he had little strength to do so. Those judgments were handed down yesterday at 3.30 p.m. At the request of the High Court they were brought forward; they were supposed to come down today at 3.30 p.m. Those judgments were brought down, and Lionel Murphy died at 4.15 p.m. It was said somewhere that he was in a coma for 10 days. That is not true. He was merely briefly in that state of no recognition. It was just for a short time on the Monday. But one could see the determination and the spirit of the man that persisted right until the end.

His end is a loss because he had much more to offer and much more to give. Although it is said that there is no person who cannot be replaced, one thing is certain: Lionel Murphy will not be replaced easily. I would like to express my condolences to Ingrid, to his brother Bill and Bill's wife, and to his children, Cameron, Blake and Lorel, whom I know well. I also express my condolences to his two staff members, Rhonda and Peter, who shared the agony until the end and who have a further agony to perform in bringing his affairs into order and in vacating the great office that Lionel Murphy held, the office of Justice of the High Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to be associated with the condolence motion. I shall be brief because so many things have been said of Lionel Murphy, and all are very true. Mr President, you might recall, following what Senator Gietzelt said, that we met in my office in 1961 to discuss a matter that occasionally comes up in politics-who should be the Senate candidates from New South Wales. We fairly quickly agreed that you, Mr President, should be a candidate at that time, but I held out against the young barrister people were referring to, and that was Lionel Murphy. I held out because I was very suspicious of barristers who, through their training, were very inclined to speak eloquently but who, from my experience, were not inclined to follow the principles of the labour movement. Fortunately, my colleagues prevailed on me. I was very wrong and Lionel Murphy with you, Mr President, came into the Senate in 1962.

SPEECH.PARA: Other people have clearly indicated the speed with which he rose to the highest office in the Senate and his excellent work in reforming the Senate. I feel that some aspects should be emphasised a little more. Lionel Murphy worked outside the Senate as well as in it. His tremendous energy meant that he was able to campaign in every possible way on so many different issues. I was involved in the anti-Vietnam War campaign and Lionel found the time, among all his other activities, to be a prominent personality in that campaign. His quality of lateral thinking has been mentioned. I have been in politics for over 30 years and have met many prominent people in State and Federal parliaments, but know of no person who had that quality to the same degree as did Lionel Murphy. He was able to look at a problem and see the way through it. He was able to think of a problem so comprehensively that throughout his life he was able to help people and make suggestions that were beyond the capacity of most human beings.

As a Party officer in the early 1970s, I was able to work with him in that run-up to the election of the Whitlam Government. I do not think it has been emphasised enough that it was what he did not only in government but also in preparation for it that was outstanding. For example, in 1971 he was primarily responsible for many initiatives-such as in the arts area. The culture of Lionel Murphy has not been mentioned sufficiently. He influenced the opening up of the arts that was referred to in the program on which the Whitlam Government went to the people. The right of people to read things as adults, with a few qualifications, was a singularly outstanding achievement that Lionel Murphy creatively pushed forward. It became accepted in most parts of Australia, and inevitably in Queensland, too.

The Whitlam Government Ministers were very grateful for the way in which Lionel Murphy was able to suggest solutions to problems-a quality we all wish we had when facing and stewing over difficult problems. Lionel Murphy in a singular way will be remembered by his colleagues and everybody who has known him as a person who solved problems, often not in his own direct area of influence and responsibility.

I shall not add to what has been said so eloquently by other speakers about Lionel Murphy's contribution to the law. Just as this Senate reflects an American approach, throughout his career Lionel Murphy looked to countries other than mother England. When the history books are written finally, I think he might be judged responsible for making us look to sources of law and wisdom other than the traditional ones we have always accepted. It is typical of the man that he knew no constraints.

I do not wish to raise at any length the matter of the persecution that Lionel Murphy had received from the house of Fairfax. Some small minded journalists sought to tug at him-a great man-in their efforts to gain some short term notoriety. As other senators have said, history will record the facts very clearly. All I know is that there is great anger in the labour movement throughout Australia about the way in which Lionel Murphy was persecuted. I conclude by passing on my condolences to Ingrid, her children and family and I am very sad that I have lost a friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the context of the many tributes which have been paid since Mr Justice Murphy's untimely passing and which will be made over the next few days, my remarks may appear to be insignificant. If that is so, I stress to the Senate that what I am about to say is said with an extreme depth of feeling. Like others who had any association with Lionel Murphy, I was dismayed when I heard earlier this year that he was terminally ill. I had been speaking to him only a week before and, although he did not look well, I was still shocked when the nature of his illness became evident. Many people throughout Australia who had not had the honour of meeting Lionel were equally shocked and saddened. Since then, and until yesterday, I had always harboured the hope that there would be some miraculous recovery or at least a significant remission. That was not to be and yesterday Lionel Murphy passed from this world-at last in peace following the tortuous events of the past two years.

SPEECH.PARA: I did not know Lionel Murphy as well as many others in this chamber. I never had the opportunity to meet his family, who must, at this stage, be suffering from profound grief. To them I offer my deepest sympathy. I hope that it will be of some solace to Lionel's family that their sorrow is shared today by thousands upon thousands of people throughout this nation. Although, as I mentioned, I did not know him as well as some others, I had the opportunity to speak to him on many occasions and regarded him as a personal friend. We first met in 1969 after I had been selected by my Party as a Senate candidate. I shall never forget when we first met, under a high-set home in south Brisbane. The warmth of the man became instantly and clearly evident. After that we met regularly at political functions. Although at one stage it appeared that I might be elected to this chamber in 1974, that did not occur. Thus I did not have the opportunity to be one of his colleagues in the Senate. When I was subsequently elected in 1975 Lionel Murphy had moved to the High Court of Australia.

I shall always remember Lionel Murphy as a compassionate man, an intellectual giant and one of my friends. I was pleased that my elder son was able to engage in thought provoking discussions with Lionel almost a year ago-in fact, it would have been a year ago this Saturday. I am sure that my son will not forget the experience of being able to speak with one of Australia's great men, a man who could converse with people from all walks of life.

Some of us hope that when we pass from this world we will have made a scratch on the mirror of time. Lionel Murphy did far more than this. He was a man who will be long remembered, not only by those who knew him, but also by Australian historians. His contributions to Australian politics and to the judiciary will be acclaimed by those who, in the future, look at his life and the part he played in shaping the direction taken by our nation. While others of us will be forgotten, the name of Lionel Murphy will loom large in Australia's history. On a personal basis, I simply say: `Goodbye, my friend. I am proud to have known you. May you rest in peace'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —To have known Lionel Murphy is a privilege I will always treasure. There are many anecdotes that many of us could relate and images which help us to remember important and minor events in our lives and the lives of others. I remember that in February 1972, when I was first endorsed as a candidate for Denison in the House of Representatives election, the first function of my campaign was a Young Labor dinner in Hobart in early March 1972; that was my first public speech. Lionel Murphy was the guest speaker at that function as the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate at that time. He came to Hobart with a young George Negus as his Press secretary. Because of his character, which I came to know better after that time, he was not just accepting of me; he was enthusiastically supportive and encouraging during that campaign and during the next two years, 1973 and 1974, the years of the Whitlam Government, before he was appointed to the High Court of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Before and since that time and at the time of his appointment he suffered the attacks, derision and abuse of the establishment. I recall the horror of our opponents and conservatives generally not only that a Labor person was being appointed to the High Court but somebody from the Labor Left. Since that time my contact with him has been less, but he was always a gregarious person, as he has been described. When we met at a function or a party he was always welcoming and accepting.

There were many issues during 1973 and 1974 in which we were all involved, and the Family Law Bill was one of the major ones. People here may not remember that because of the free vote arrangement at the time the passage of that Bill through the House of Representatives was much more difficult than it was through this chamber. It was frustrating for Lionel Murphy that amendments had to be accepted that he would have preferred not to have made, but that was one piece of legislation, among others, that required a lot of attention. Because of the free vote arrangement there had to be negotiations, not just between parties but also among individuals, in order to get the reform through. I will not repeat all the reforms for which we will remember Lionel Murphy, but they include the relaxation of censorship laws, the introduction of the civil marriage celebrant arrangement which Senator George Georges mentioned and many other achievements.

Lionel Murphy gave so much and he did it so generously. I certainly regret his passing but I also celebrate his life. I know that for the rest of my life, whenever I hear a recording of Lionel Murphy's unmistakable and endearing voice, not only will a lump come to my throat and tears to my eyes, but also I will recall all that I am grateful to him for and all that the Australian Labor Party and Australia as a whole should be grateful to him for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a person who has felt Lionel Murphy's warmth, I would like to be associated with the condolences. I agree with the sentiments that my colleagues have expressed about him. One important point that has not been mentioned about Lionel Murphy is the marvellous attribute that he had-the common touch. I think few people could be compared with Horatius, but honourable senators might recall that when Macaulay wrote about Horatius, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: And even the ranks of Tuscany could scarce forbear to cheer.
I believe that this applies equally to Lionel Murphy. I offer my condolences to his wife and children.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to express my condolences to the family of Mr Justice Lionel Murphy in their bereavement and to record my regret at the passing of a great trailblazer, a compassionate and courageous Australian who contributed enormously to stimulating progressive reforms in legal and political life in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I probably knew Lionel Murphy a lot earlier than many people in this chamber. In 1959, retail workers in Tasmania were unorganised, working in substandard conditions, under substandard awards, and some were completely unprotected by awards. As a young union official, from 1959 until the early 1960s I laboured long and hard to organise these retail workers and to obtain for them award coverage and union protection. Having achieved that objective, I was dismayed when a left wing union from Sydney attempted to take over the membership lock, stock and barrel. I was further amazed that this attempt was not done on the ground but was sought to be achieved in the courts. That was the time I first came into contact with Lionel Murphy, who was briefed as Queen's Counsel by that union. Unfortunately, my vision of him was coloured at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, in 1968 Lionel Murphy played a major role in the decision of the Federal Executive of the Labor Party, by the closest of margins, to refuse me a seat on that Federal Executive as the elected representative of the Tasmanian branch of the Australian Labor Party. I suppose that it can be said that I was a political enemy of Lionel Murphy. But in no way can it be said that I was a personal enemy of his. Perhaps that was due more to his magnanimous and gregarious character than to any characteristic of mine. As I recall, there was at no stage a personal animosity. In fact, we shared some policies in common-for example, a passionate concern that there should be an abolition of capital punishment. But I did not support many of his contributions to the legal framework of this nation, for which he is now being most remembered-the social ramifications of which are being felt and are beginning to be faced by our society. Nevertheless, I admired his mental agility, his intellectual capacity and his restless passion for good and justice as he saw it. In particular, during the last few months since I heard that he had contracted cancer I had a personal understanding and compassion for him and his family. He undoubtedly had a great mind which was oriented to the search for truth. Standing here, I cannot logically conceive, just because his body was riddled with cancer and he has died, that his mind is no longer active, that he is no longer in existence. After all, his mind gave searching consideration to such non-material and abstract concepts as justice. I simply say that I hope and pray that he has now found rest in the truth. I offer to his wife, his family and also his close personal friends my deepest sympathy.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Colleagues, I should like to add my support to the condolence motion that has been moved by Senator Button. As has already been said, for many years my political path and that of Mr Justice Murphy ran side by side. With the late Senator Fitzgerald, Lionel Murphy, as he was then, and I were elected as Labor senators for New South Wales on the same ticket at the 1961 election. Indeed, when the validity of my election was challenged by the then Australian Democratic Labor Party in the High Court of Australia it was Lionel Murphy, Queen's Counsel, who successfully appeared for me in that action. As a result of his persuasion to a Bench that he subsequently joined, I became a senator for New South Wales.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Murphy and I entered Parliament together on 1 July 1962. We served together in opposition for 10 very long years. We were elected to the Ministry together in 1972. We served as Cabinet Ministers together for three years, and for 18 months of that time I was the Manager of Government Business in the Senate while he was the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Therefore we had a very close association.

I think everything has been said about him as a parliamentarian, his achievements as a parliamentarian and his distinguished career as a jurist. I want to take a few short minutes to speak about him and about my memories of him as a man. He was a warm, kind, gracious and most generous person-as Senator Button has said, a man of great charm. His little idiosyncrasies, his mannerisms, his words, his deeds and his actions all became part of the folklore of the labour movement. I remember how he used to push his hair back with his hands before he spoke. I remember him starting his remarks with the word `Well' before he made a pronouncement of his thoughts on any given subject. I remember his head leaning to one side when he was pensive in thought. I remember the long, strident, vital steps that he took as he strode from the Senate door to the parliamentary table-a man in a hurry, a man keen to get on with the job.

I remember his hearty laughter or chuckle as someone took him off. I remember his being able to take a joke against himself. Indeed, talking about his generosity, I well remember the great party he threw shortly after we entered Parliament, in honour of former Senator O'Byrne and his wife, Anne, when they celebrated the birth of their first child. It was one of the great parties of all times. I remember his deep convictions, his respect for the rule of law, his belief in the parliamentary institution and, because the Australian Parliament was isolated, as it were, in Canberra, his concern to get it to the people and to get the people to it. Therefore I remember his activities in this place to develop a committee system which would take the Parliament to the people of Australia. I remember his great love of life.

He came into Parliament with great men such as Reg Bishop, Jim Cavanagh and his own close personal friend, the late Sam Cohen, QC-all great men, great Labor people and great Australians. For Lionel Murphy to have been elected Leader of the Labor Party in the Senate when there were such men as those in the Labor Party marked him as a real man among real men. My sympathy and that of my wife, Lorna, and the sympathy of all those who elected Lionel and me to the Parliament go to that lovely lady, Ingrid, who has been such a tower of strength to him, a magnificently loyal wife and an outstanding mother to Cameron and Blake. Colleagues, I invite you all to stand as a mark of respect to the memory of Lionel Keith Murphy.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:-
That there is widespread community concern about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:-
1. Block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia and
2. Ban the import of cobalt-60 and caesium 137 and caesium 134 to be used to irradiate food products,
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
This petition of the undersigned concerned citizens of Australia shows that:
the Joint Space Defence Research Facility at Pine Gap is a vital part of United States plans to fight a nuclear war, thus implicating Australia in these immoral plans;
spy satellites such as those linked to Pine Gap are used to spy on both allied and non-allied countries, including Australia;
these activities of Pine Gap are a destabilizing influence in a dangerously uneasy world, raising the level of fear and distrust between nations;
the significance of Pine Gap to the U.S.A. is such that it is a prime nuclear target;
Pine Gap desecrates an Aboriginal dreaming track.

Your petitioners therefore strongly urge that the Australian Government give to the government of the U.S.A. the one year's notice required to terminate the lease on the Joint Space Defence Research Facility at Pine Gap.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(i) the welfare of many employees and their families depends upon a healthy, expanding gold mining industry;
(ii) the success of many small businesses in gold mining towns also depends upon the continued profitability of gold mining and prospecting operations;

(iii) the Federal Government's proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining and prospecting represents a threat to the profitability of these industries and will therefore cause widespread unemployment and depression throughout the whole gold mining industry.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Federal Government to reject any proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining or prospecting thereby ensuring that the spectacular growth of the industry over recent years is continued.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal System in Australia, the State and Federal and criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education system, the independence of the Churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children and the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and the Australian Society generally.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for at least twelve months and for the political parties to become involved in a public awareness program of the Australian Bill of Rights, so that the Australian people can debate, scrutinize and discuss the issue for themselves, prior to a referendum, as to whether or not they want a Bill of Rights introduced.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operation Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Funding: Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned Queensland citizens respectfully showeth:
(i) For the 1986 Calendar year 34,000 students applied for only 14,500 first year places at Tertiary institutions in Queensland.

(ii) Queensland has 16.07% of Australia's total population, but the participation rate of students attending Universities and Colleges of Advanced Education is only 13.7% and 14.9% respectively. (Which for example compares unfavourably with the New South Wales figures of 34.85% of population and participation rates of 37.9% and 25.8% respectively.)
(iii) Queensland students because of lack of places are disadvantaged and deprived in that they suffer the lowest participation rates of any State or Territory in Australia.
Your petitioners request that.
The Federal Government immediately increase its Tertiary Funding so that Queensland students have at least the same opportunities as the average for Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the Oceans.
2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a ``first strike'' attack.
This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The `joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to the nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `Joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits tax on the following grounds:
its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

in that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Capital Gains Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
that all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions;
that the Hawke Government's Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the small business and rural sectors, which will severely affect their long-term viability.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government withdraws the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2.
