PETITION.TITLE: Drug Usage
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth; that we support your efforts to strengthen our family and community life particularly by increased penalties for `drug pushers' and distributors. We, however, wish to register our firm opposition to any legal changes which would increase or encourage the distribution or availability of so-called `soft drugs' such as marijuana. We believe such drugs to be harmful to the physical and psychological health of the individual and therefore to the interest of the community of which such individual is part. Although there is current controversy concerning the question of such harm it appears to us quite foolish to legalise and encourage the use of such drugs unless or until it be shown that such drugs are in fact harmless. The serious social problems of alcohol should provide sufficient warning to our society.
Any efforts to legalise or decriminalise usage or distribution of such drugs will have the following results:
1. Encourage and inculcate a social acceptability towards such drugs.
2. Increase the volume of usage of such drugs in schools and the community by present users and by `drug pushers' through the proposed one ounce legal possession.
3. Extend the usage of such drugs to persons who would previously have abstained because of the legal sanctions.

4. Put pressure upon Parliament to establish and license import, growth, manufacture and/or distribution of such drugs, that is, to regulate another destructive industry contrary to the best interest of the individual and society.
5. There would be the probable temptation to tax such drugs as another source of Federal revenue.

We urge the Government to increase the medical and counselling facilities for the assistance of drug users and to expand existing Drug Referral Centres and Clinics. We have general confidence in the existing law and its sympathetic implementation by the Police and Courts.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will firstly take no measures that could extend the major social problem of drug usage and secondly will oblige those who are promoting marijuana and/or similar drugs to prove without doubt that such drugs are harmless before any legislation or decriminalisation of use is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Standards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate, of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament becomes aware that the Public has no legal right to influence the setting of Standards for Television Programming, that we deplore the new Standards which came into force on 1st February, and that we call on Parliament to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, section 16 (2), so that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, when determining Television Standards, and screening hours, shall consult with the Australian people:
because at present the Tribunal is compelled by law to consult only with television stations on these matters,
because the new standards are a result of such consultation, and have already been implemented without public discussion,
because the new Standards are ambiguous, and without definition,
because the new Standards are composed of modifying terms which circumvent the proscriptions,
because the media is only motivated by aspirations of pecuniary superiority,
because, in contrast, the public is only motivated by their wish to exercise pastoral care over the nurturing home environment of their children,
because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe extreme importance to `the storyline' of a film screened,

because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe total unimportance to the effects of viewing, especially violent films, on the young, the impressionable, the immature, the unstable, or the socially disadvantaged,
because we refuse to accept the media-imposed assessment of community standards,
and because we wish to impart our demand to be consulted, our demand to have legal status in decision-making, and the right to counsel those whose decisions so deeply affect our homes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest attention.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gietzelt for Senator Button) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to provide for the payment of subsidy on the production, or in respect of the importation, of certain cultivation machines and related equipment, and for related purposes.
Bill presented by Senator Gietzelt, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill seeks to implement the undertaking contained in the rural economic policy statement of 15 April 1986 to replace tariffs on certain cultivation machinery and parts with direct assistance to local producers with effect from that date. Stocks on hand as at that date, including imported stocks, are to be covered by the new arrangements.

The prime objective of this policy change is to reduce prices on a range of cultivation equipment and parts used in the rural sector without disrupting the existing levels of assistance accorded local manufacturers.
The Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) was asked to inquire into and report on the terms and conditions of such assistance and its report was released on 16 June 1986.

The IAC concluded that assistance at a rate of 12.5 per cent of ex-factory selling price would provide a level of assistance equivalent to that accorded by tariff. In addition, it concluded that payments at this base rate should be discounted for subsidy already paid on locally produced parts and discounted by a notional tariff on imported parts which are incorporated in complete machines. In principle the Government accepts the findings of the IAC.

Tight budgetary constraints however have severely limited the availability of funds to cover anticipated subsidy payments at rates proposed by the IAC. Accordingly the rates of subsidy for this scheme have been reduced by a factor of 20%. This reduction which was announced in the Budget is consistent with the treatment generally accorded other bounty schemes.
Clause 12 of the Bill contains provisions specifying the rates of subsidy to be paid on eligible equipment.

The base rate at which subsidy will be paid will be 10 per cent of the sales value of the equipment determined in accordance with clause 6. Payments at this base rate, generally the ex factory selling price, are to be discounted for any subsidy or bounty paid on locally produced components incorporated in eligible equipment and by an amount equal to 12 per cent of the value for duty of imported components incorporated in such machinery.

The Bill contains special provisions at clause 10 whereby the subsidy will be paid in respect of domestic sales of imported cultivation equipment entered for home consumption before 15 April 1986 but not sold until after that date.
This clause, together with clause 9, which enables manufacturers to claim subsidy on stocks accords with the government's commitment to extend the subsidy scheme to stocks on hand at 15 April 1986.

Clause 17 provides that subsidy claims will only be processed when the amount of subsidy payable exceeds $200. This measure has been introduced in an endeavour to minimise the administrative costs associated with the scheme.

In its report the IAC recommended that the new assistance arrangements cover all goods of a type falling to customs tariff item 84.24 and that margins of preference for imports of parts from preferential sources be retained.
The government accepts the IAC proposal that all goods within Customs Tariff Item 84.24 be covered.

It has been decided however not to accept the IAC's recommendations to accord preferential treatment to imports of parts from such sources as Papua New Guinea, New Zealand, Canada and the Forum Islands. Discrimination between sources of imports for subsidy payments could be seen as being at variance with the most favoured nation clause of the GATT as well as having implications for our overall policy on bounty administration.

The new arrangements allow for the duty free entry of all goods falling to Customs Tariff Item 84.24. Necessary action is being taken to alter the Customs Tariff to coincide with the assistance arrangements proposed by this Bill.

Clause 23 of the Bill includes a provision designed to promote the orderly development of the cultivation machinery industry sector and to avoid fragmentation of production. Under that provision the Comptroller-General of Customs will not register the premises of any applicants for registration that were not in production of goods eligible for subsidy on 15 April 1986 (the operative date of proposed change in assistance arrangements) if, in the opinion of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, such registration would not permit the orderly development of the Industry in Australia.
The other provisions of Parts 3 to 5 of the Bill are of an administrative nature modelled on similar provisions in recent bounty legislation.

The arrangements I have outlined will remain in force until 31 December 1990, but will be reviewed by the IAC before the end of this period. Provision has been made to enable the scheme to be extended for up to 6 months to cater for any unforeseen delays in determining the assistance measures (if any) to apply beyond 31 December 1990.
Financial Impact Statement

It is expected that subsidy payments in 1986-87 under this bill will be approximately $16.8m. In that same period revenue foregone in permitting duty free entry under the proposed consequential amendments to the Customs Tariff Act will amount to approximately $2m.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1986 and the Bank Account Debits Tax Amendment Bill 1986. I make it quite clear from the outset that the Opposition will not oppose these two pieces of the Government's Budget legislation, notwithstanding that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is not strictly a Budget Bill in that some items of non-Budget matter are included therein. Nevertheless, the Bills do raise serious matters of concern to the Opposition and I will certainly draw attention to those during my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose I should start at the beginning with the Budget itself and point out at the outset that by its Budget this Government stands proven again to be the highest taxing government since Federation. We now see the Hawke Labor Government taking in taxation 25.5. per cent of the gross domestic product for the purposes of governing. That is the highest proportion ever in the history of this nation. The point that needs to be made about that, which is of real political consequence, is that the Government went to the people before the election of 1984 and gave a solemn undertaking that it would not increase taxation above the taxation level of the previous year, that is of the 1984-85 financial year, as expressed as a percentage of gross domestic product. Yet in the first Budget following that undertaking being given, the Government raised taxation to a level which now is the highest it has ever been in the history of the nation. All of us have known that this is a high taxing Government. But quite clearly the Government has stretched itself to break its promises, as it has done on so many occasions. It is quite clear that the word of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), of the Treasurer, Mr Keating, and of other Ministers simply cannot be believed on the issue of taxation, or for that matter on any other issue.

Since 1983 when this Government came to power, we have seen successive promises broken in the taxation area. The first one that comes to mind was broken in May of 1983 with the imposition of the 30 per cent tax on lump sum superannuation. Yet, prior to the election of 1983, the Australian Labor Party gave a clear undertaking that it would not tax lump sum superannuation payments. Secondly, the Government introduced the assets test on pensions, again having given a solemn undertaking that it would not introduce an assets test on pensions. Since then we have seen the latest breaking of an undertaking given before the 1984 election that there would be no increase in the Medicare levy. Just a moment or two ago we saw the passage of the Medicare Levy Bill which increases the Medicare levy by some 25 per cent. That is what is happening. The Government constantly breaches its undertakings and has absolutely no credibility in the eyes of the public.

Let us turn for a moment to the Budget. All of us know that the great trick of the Budget was to come out with a sensational new deficit figure that nobody in the financial community or the Government expected. In fact, the Government brought down a deficit of $3.5 billion compared with the previous year's figure of around $5.8 billion. That very significant reduction of the deficit was brought about not by reducing the activities of government, not by cutting the Government's expenditure, not by stimulating growth in the economy in some sudden and magical fashion, but by raising taxation. This has been the common feature of all the Hawke Labor Government's decisions: When in trouble it raises taxation. So it is that, of that $2 billion decrease in the deficit, at least $1.5 billion has come from new taxes raised in this Budget and the remaining amount from some deferrals-not cuts in expenditure but deferrals in some areas-and more particularly from some windfall profits from the Reserve Bank of Australia because of the currency devaluation. That is how the Government has achieved its objective of reducing the deficit by some $2 billion. But, frankly, it has all been done with mirrors. The people who are paying for it are the poor taxpayers of this country who are now paying the highest levels of taxation that the nation has ever suffered. It represents a direct breach of the Government's undertaking at the election in 1984.

Perhaps I should cite just two statistics to show what effect this is having on the Australian people. The rate of inflation since this Government came to power in March of 1983 has increased by a total of 30.5 per cent. However, the increase in the tax take in those 3 3/4 years has been 60 per cent. What has happened is that the rate at which the Government is taking tax from the people has grown twice as fast as the rate of inflation. Consequently that is coming out of the real moneys available to the population and is restricting the ability of the population to look after itself. Of course the effect of that will be reflected in lower consumer demand. It will be reflected in the lower standard of living that people are able to enjoy and afford and, consequently, will have a major impact on the Australian economy. That is what has happened to the people in Australia since this Hawke Labor Government came to power. It is little wonder that people are literally being borne down with the weight of taxation on their shoulders. They feel that their standard of living is suffering as a result and, consequently, they feel that this Government is doing nothing for them. Of course, when they assume that, they are absolutely correct, because nothing is being done for them-only a continuation of broken promises while the economy slips into more and more trouble built up by greater and greater debt being owed by the nation to foreign countries.

On the issue of debt, it has risen during the period of this Government from some $35 billion-a relatively small figure-to nearly $100 billion, which represents some 40 per cent of our gross domestic product. Of course, that debt will be around in this country for many years to come. The recent report of the Economic Planning Advisory Council highlighted that and pointed out that it will not be cured until at least well into the 1990s. That shows that the trend that has been developing as a direct result of Government policy in the last 3 1/2 years is most detrimental to the long term future of the Australian economy.

Returning to taxation as it affects the individual, we should observe that in March of 1983 the marginal tax rate that applied to taxpayers on average weekly earnings was 30 per cent. That was the amount which was paid by an individual taxpayer for the next dollar that was earned over and above average weekly earnings. Yet, under this Government, after 3 3/4 years, that rate has risen to 40 per cent. So, there has been an increase of one-third in the rate at which tax will apply to people on average weekly earnings. That surely demonstrates clearly to us the problems that people are feeling in the community. It demonstrates why consumer confidence is so low and why people are finding their standards of living slipping and, consequently, finding it more and more difficult to look after themselves.

I turn now to a few of the issues involved in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1986. I mention firstly the very significant-in fact, it is more than very significant; it is gigantic-increase in the fee which will be charged by the Government when it increases the amount which people have to pay, by way of a deposit, when they lodge an appeal with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in objecting to their taxation assessment. Whilst this is not specifically a matter mentioned within this legislation-it comes in a later Bill-it is relevant to mention it in terms of the changes that are occurring within the total tax structure and since it was mentioned as part of the Budget. There will be an increase in the lodgment fee, which was originally $2. It will be raised to $200.

Apart from the fact that this measure obviously represents a severe penalty and really amounts to a money raising measure, the point is that it will restrict perhaps quite a lot of very small taxpayers from lodging appeals with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, consequently leading to their suffering injustices in not being able to have their cases properly heard and perhaps overturned by the AAT. That means that taxpayers in that category may be paying more tax than they legally are bound to pay. Consequently, that is very much a penalty and against the interest of justice for these people.

Another matter in respect of this legislation is that of the interest withholding tax. The Treasurer announced on 1 July this year a change to the way in which interest withholding tax would apply in respect of overseas transactions. As a result of that announcement we saw a collapse in the value of the Australian dollar developing, which eventually led to a total denouement on 28 July, when the Australian dollar crashed down to US57c. With that, the Treasurer finally panicked and removed, by announcement, I think the next day, the proposed interest withholding tax, and consequently the dollar started to stabilise at around the US60c level. Of course, this was achieved only with the major intervention of the Reserve Bank of Australia, which sought to put a floor under the dollar at that time. During that period the dollar, in trade weighted index terms, crashed down to below 50 and settled on that very day, 28 July, at 49. Is it any wonder that this Government, which seems to have lost all sense of economic and political direction, reacted in such a fashion and clearly without any perfect knowledge of what it was doing in the first place?

Clearly, when this legislation was thought of no consideration was given to the broader effects in the economy. Consequently, the legislation had a dramatic impact upon the Australian dollar. Certainly, it was read overseas as a sign that the Government had lost control of its economic fortunes. The Treasurer, of course, reversed that decision, perhaps not so much with a clear view of what ought to be done in those circumstances, but rather because of the political pressure that was generated as a result of the terrible crash in the value of the dollar at that time. Since then, propping up operations have had to be undertaken by the Reserve Bank of Australia in the foreign exchange markets to keep the Australian dollar at anything like a reasonable level. Of course, interest rates have been maintained at a very high level as well.

Nothing would give the people overseas looking at the Australian economy a greater impression of the banana republic status of this country than the observation of that particular set of gyrations on the part of the Treasurer. Clearly, those events of the month of July would have unsettled the confidence which overseas markets had in Australia. Clearly, they also would have unsettled the confidence of Australian businessmen in their ability to invest safely in this country. It is little wonder that Treasurer Keating is now rated as the second worst Treasurer in Australia. I suppose it is some kind of record to have gone from the top to the bottom in less than 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Second worst? Who is the worst? Howard was the worst.
—I understand that the Egyptian gentleman was mentioned as the worst in that list.
—You said `the second worst in Australia'.

—I beg your pardon. I meant `in the world'. Thank you for correcting me. The other matter mentioned in this legislation is that of reservists' pay. This measure again demonstrates the problems of this Government in that it fails to understand the consequences of its actions when it makes decisions. We recall that back in, I think, May 1983 the Government sought to remove the exemption from taxation for pay of the Army Reserve personnel. This exemption, apparently, was viewed at the time by the Government as some kind of a tax rort, and the exemption was reduced from 100 per cent to 50 per cent. This was supposed to save the Government a great deal of money at that time. But when we look at what has happened with our reserve forces we get a clearer impression of the real result of this measure. In 1980, we might recall, the Fraser Government, which was in power at the time had 22,000 in the reserve forces of Australia. During 1981 a recruiting campaign sought to raise that number to 30,000. We have now seen, as at 30 June 1985, that the reserve forces have in fact dropped back to 23,673. That has been a very significant drop compared with that number of 30,000. Obviously, that drop is directly linked to the decision of the Hawke Labor Government to tax the pay of Army Reserve personnel.

SPEECH.PARA: We must remind ourselves that the people who undertake these Reserve occupations with our armed forces do so in their free time when others are enjoying themselves in their leisure pursuits. We have dedicated people who are prepared to give their time, take the risks and give up their leisure activities and family life to go and learn about how they can defend Australia. This, of course, is a worthwhile activity, which the Liberal Party of Australia fully supports. Yet this Government through its action of taxing their pay, made sure that we reduced our capacity in that area by some 7,000 personnel during its period in office.

What was the next thing the Government did in these circumstances? One clearly is not sure about the motives of those who advise the Government in this area, but the next thing we were assailed with was television advertisements in which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) exhorted people to get involved in the reserve forces in order to try to build up the numbers from that depleted level of 23,000 back towards the Fraser Government's level of 30,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —The numbers have conti-nued to fall.

—The numbers have continued to fall even in the last year. I make the point that, despite all the advertising which is being undertaken and which has given the Prime Minister a great deal of publicity-we see his face more often on television, at a cost of $3m to the taxpayer-the number of soldiers who are giving up their spare time has fallen by 600 or 700 since that advertising campaign commenced. Clearly the Government's thinking has been erroneous. It has no thought for the broader consequences of its actions when it takes ill-considered decisions on taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: Another clear example that is waiting in the wings for us is the lump sum superannuation tax. In the years to come we shall see a growing number of people moving on to the social security system. They will not be able to look after themselves because of the imposition of this new form of tax. Consequently, far from the Government saving money on social security, there will be an increase in the demand for social security pensions resulting from the introduction of that crazy tax. There are numerous examples of what has happened in this area in recent times. I formally move the Opposition's amendment to the second reading motion for the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1986:
At the end of the motion, add:
`, but the Senate condemns the Government for-

(a) its failure to control government spending to the point where it has broken its ``trilogy'' commitment to hold taxation to no more than 25 per cent of gross domestic product and proceeded to tax Australians to the highest point in our history;
(b) its contempt for ordinary taxpayers, illustrated by its decision to charge a $200 fee for appeals against the Tax Commissioner's rulings regardless of the size or complexity of the claim;
(c) its incompetent handling of the withholding tax issue, whereby the Government changed the tax rules, caused a run on the dollar, and retreated 27 days later; and

(d) its disgraceful treatment of the Defence Forces Reserves, by withdrawing the tax free status of reservists' pay, thereby causing a grave rundown of reserve forces and damage to their morale and effectiveness, and belatedly restoring the concession.

I notice that the Australian Democrats will be moving two amendments to the second reading motion on the Bank Account Debits Tax Amendment Bill. The Liberal-National Party Opposition will be opposing those amendments and I shall give my reasons when we reach that debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Messner has criticised the Government's Budget strategy as coming from the highest taxing government in Australia's history. Of course, we agree with that. It is a pity, however, that the Opposition's criticisms of the Government on so many points are not translated into some action. Taxes now are higher than they have ever been. Most of the tax cuts that the Government has said so much about have been eroded due to inflation, as necessarily they will be eroded under any government unless it is prepared to index income tax cuts for inflation. Only last evening we moved an amendment, not opposing any of the Government's legislation but merely in the form of an attachment to a taxing Bill, condemning the Government for not indexing personal rates of income tax. The Opposition was not prepared to support our amendment. Why do we have to listen to the Opposition criticising and castigating the Government for being the highest taxing government in Australia's history when that Opposition is not prepared to stand up and be counted on the only measures that can be adopted if erosions of income are not to take effect? I can only conclude that the Liberal Party of Australia has no concerted economic strategy. It criticises but does not say how it would manage the economy if it were in government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats find many aspects of the Government's strategy to criticise. We have on many occasions made our criticisms clear, but for the record I will reiterate some of them. Certainly there is to be a low Budget deficit, which we applaud as necessary, but, as Senator Messner pointed out, it will be achieved by raising taxes of all sorts. We condemn that approach. We believe that revenue raising measures were open to the Government which would have attacked some of our economic problems directly. For instance, why was not the Government prepared to do something about our balance of payments problem on the current account? All it had to do was impose a tax on luxury imports. About a fifth of those imports could have been taxed as representing luxury imports which Australia could not afford and which are unnecessary to the Australian people in a period of austerity. Instead, the Government has done nothing to discourage imports, when that measure alone could have raised between $1 billion and $2 billion and would have had a very dramatic effect on the size of the deficit.

The Government has steadfastly refused to do anything about takeover rorts. It is sad and depressing to see well established, efficient, internationally competitive Australian companies being taken over by overseas enterprises. I need mention only the Nicholas Kiwi company as a case in point. That company was taken over a few weeks ago by an American interest. That company has been highly respected in the ethical drug business around the world as a very formidable competitor with large American companies. That is the case no longer. It is now owned by an American company and its ability to sell its products around the world will be seriously curtailed from now on. I am glad to see that Senator Watson agrees with me on this issue. That is only one example. The Government has done nothing other than to say to overseas businesses: `Come in, take over our efficient Australian companies if you wish. We welcome the cash that that represents'. That is a short term approach because nobody would buy out an Australian business without wanting to get its money back in three or five years.

The Government's approach in borrowing more money, encouraging the selling of the farm, selling our wealth-producing enterprises, is very shortsighted and has not attacked the fundamental problems. The tragedy of the Parliament today is that the Opposition has not come up with any strategy to attack the fundamental problem. Australia is living beyond its means. The Government is saying that we should remain in that position and that we should import any luxury item. It does not care but takes the attitude: We will borrow money and sell off assets to pay for those imports. Clearly the matter has got out of hand and there is no Budget strategy to address that fundamental problem.

Turning to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), the Senate is debating a wide variety of changes to tax laws. In the time available to me I cannot possibly talk on all the changes but will comment on only a few mainly to illustrate how cynical are the processes of government. Promises made by the Australian Labor Party when in opposition have been broken. Yesterday in the social welfare legislation we saw a vicious attack on the poor and underprivileged simply so that the Government, by whatever means, could raise money from whatever source, with no concern or regard for where that money was coming from. I will comment on only a few of these areas to illustrate the absolute cynicism of government today. We hear comments to the effect that the only thing lower than a snake is a politician. There is great disregard for the political system in this country and when firm promises and undertakings are broken so indiscriminately without any regard, when we see the Opposition and the Government voting together time and again to support measures which obviously should not be supported, we wonder why we have a parliament at all and why we bother to debate legislation.

I turn to the first cynical action of the Government as illustrated in this piece of legislation. I refer to the fact that the Government now proposes to allow tax deductions for payments made by oil companies to the Government for the award of offshore oil exploration leases and for the cash bidding system which was introduced last year. In its cynical way the Government says that this move will allow Australian companies to compete more effectively with foreign firms which are allowed tax deductions by their home governments. This may be true to a minor extent, but I suspect that many foreign companies conduct exploration in Australia through subsidiary companies, so in this case the argument does not have much force. The important point is that the Government is expressing concern about our oil resources falling into foreign hands. Indeed that is occurring in many cases; the majority of our oil resources right now are in foreign hands.

The Government sheds these crocodile tears and expresses concern about our resources falling into foreign hands, yet in the Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill 1986 it is moving to reduce its control over foreign ownership of our resources. In effect the Government is saying: `We do not care who buys up our resources'. There was legislation in place which put some control on who should buy our resources but the Government is now moving to widen those controls so that virtually anybody can come here and buy up any part of our country, our resources, our land or our businesses without any government concern being expressed. Clearly we are saying to countries all around the world that with the Australian dollar now valued at US63c, the value of our industries has depreciated in terms of foreign currencies and that they are available at bargain basement prices. We are virtually asking foreigners to come and buy our industries at cheap prices because we do not care. I do not know why the Government bothers to make a tax concession for oil exploration in this legislation when, at the same time, it is widening the opportunity for foreign takeovers. This does not add up and it points to a cynical approach by the Government.

Senator Messner drew attention to the position of the Army Reserve. The Australian Democrats agree that this is a critical problem. The number of Army reservists has fallen quite dramatically over the past few years. That has occurred simply because in 1983 the Government attempted to scrap the tax free status given to Army reservists. The Democrats, to their credit, drew attention to the likely outcome of that change of tax free status to reservists and we moved an amendment at that time. That amendment was passed and the tax liability of reservists was reduced by 50 per cent. The Government has now done a complete about face; it has restored the tax free status of reservists. We applaud the Government for that but the whole incident underwrites and illustrates the fact that there is no real strategy or direction behind the Government's actions. It is purely looking at ways of getting revenue from whatever source it can without trying to apply its tax raising policies in line with an overall economic strategy. Of course our reservists are vitally important to the defence of this country. The Democrats' policy of an independent, non-aligned, non-nuclear defence strategy can apply only if the Army Reserve plays a very important role. It is a tragedy that the Government, through needless penny pinching, has allowed the force to lose nearly one-third of its operational strength.

I turn to another part of this legislation-the Government's hike in the tax on debits to cheque accounts. On average, this increase has been about 50 per cent. The lowest rate increase is from 10c to 15c and the highest is from $1.50 to $2. This is purely a revenue raising operation and has no regard for fairness and equity. The Australian Democrats will move an amendment to this part of the Bill. I wish to take a few moments to point out just how inequitable this revenue raising measure is. It means that there will be a 15c tax on all debit transactions between $1 and $100. The old rate was only 10c. On transactions between $100 and $500 the new rate will be 35c, compared with the old rate of 25c. On transactions between $500 and $5,000 the rate has been increased from 50c to 75c. On transactions between $5,000 and $10,000, the tax has been raised from $1 to $1.50 and on transactions over $10,000 the new rate is $2.00 compared with the old rate of $1.50. This scale represents a 15 per cent tax on transactions at the lowest end of the scale to a tax of 0.02 per cent on transactions of $10,000, or a 0.002 per cent tax on transactions of $100,000 and so on. The inequitable nature of the tax was recognised by the Government members when they were in opposition. For example, when we were debating the introduction of this tax in 1982, Senator Grimes said:
It is a revenue raising measure which I must say is typical of the type introduced by this Government-
that is, the Fraser Government-

in that its impact will be inequitable as between both institutions and individuals and it bears no relation to ability to pay. The legislation will also, incidentally, add to the cost of business in the community and as a side effect it will encourage tax avoidance and evasion.

Senator Grimes then went on to read excerpts from a letter from State Premiers expressing their concern about the tax. That was in 1982. Probably one needs to look no further than this piece of legislation to see the reason for Senator Grimes's decision to retire from politics. In 1982 he moved an amendment which said:
But the Senate is of the opinion that the tax imposed by the Bank Account Debit Tax Act is inequitable, discriminatory, inflationary and counter productive.

The Australian Democrats will move an amendment identical to the 1982 Grimes amendment. It will be interesting to see whether the Government has completely changed its mind or whether there are any members of the Government who are prepared to stand by the words that were used in 1982. To give Government members that opportunity to stand up and be counted and to comment on why there has been a 180 degree change of opinion, we will move this amendment.

We will move a further amendment which will have the effect of eliminating the inequitable nature of this tax-a tax which has a very high percentage rate at low levels of transaction and a very low percentage rate at high levels of transaction. That is inequitable and unfair on those who use cheque accounts to a much lesser degree than larger businesses and corporations. We propose to move an amendment which would have the effect of introducing a flat tax on all debits-we call it a transfer tax. It would be levelled at 0.5 per cent on all cheque account debits, irrespective of their magnitude. This would have the effect of raising very large amounts of revenue and it would give the Government room to manoeuvre in its Budget strategy. For instance, it would raise sufficient revenue, if the Government so wished, to reimburse the States to eliminate payroll tax. That is an iniquitous tax on labour which should not have been allowed to continue for as long as it has. It would raise sufficient revenue to allow the inequitable nature of this tax to be done away with.

The tax would also leave some money over which could be applied to very important areas of social concern. Rather than placing an additional burden on the poor and underprivileged as we have done in the social welfare legislation passed last week, a tax along these lines would raise sufficient revenue to apply additional help to the underprivileged in our society. I do not know what the Government will say about such a tax, but we will move this amendment to illustrate that there were very many options the Government could have adopted to keep the deficit down and raise additional revenue if it had chosen to do so.

I suspect that the only reason the Government did not look at those sorts of measures is that they would have imposed a tax on big business. It is very obvious that the one sector of the community that has been let off in all the stringencies that this Budget represents is big business. There has been no attempt to do anything about the great flows of capital from overseas companies into and out of this country, all of which are taxed in many other countries and are a source of great revenue to governments. Instead, the Government has adopted a strategy, which this Budget is introducing, of the market forces being allowed free rein and of overseas money being allowed to slosh around the Australian economy in any way it likes. The Government sits back and says: `Goodo, go to it, we do not have any responsibility to manage the Australian economy. We will let the money go where it wants'. The facts of the matter are that overseas big business is getting off scot-free and the Australian underprivileged are having a much greater burden imposed on them.

There is a lot in this Bill on which one could comment. It covers all kinds of different tax raising measures by the Government. I think I have illustrated sufficiently that there is no concerted policy by the Government. It has merely gone through various possible ways of raising money to get down the deficit, so that that in turn could be something that overseas banks and financial institutions could applaud. It is a cosmetic approach. There is no concern whatsoever as to the hardship that the Government has imposed on various sectors of the Australian community, no concern as to the fact that the economic strategy that has been applied over so many years has failed-I refer to borrowing money indiscriminately overseas and selling our assets-and no concern about developing Australian industries so that they can be internationally export competitive. All of those measures have been completely ignored by the Government in its strategy. It is an ad hoc approach to money raising and taxing which, as Senator Messner pointed out, adds up to the highest rates of taxes as a percentage of gross domestic product in Australia's history.

The Australian Democrats advocated that one important thing the Government should have done when the Australian dollar fell so dramatically was to put a floor under the dollar. We advocated that for about six months and we were laughed at by the Government initially, but finally the Government was forced to act. By putting some control over the free-falling Australian dollar the Government managed to get a measure of responsibility back into international money speculation in the Australian economy. Why the Government did not do that earlier remains to be seen, but it indicates the ad hoc approach the Government is adopting.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) will be leaving Question Time at 2.50 p.m. It may be of assistance to honourable senators who have questions to direct to him to know that.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the annual report of the Steel Industry Authority, which throws serious doubt on the future of the steel industry and long term employment in that industry. The Minister will be aware that the Authority, in its report, has highlighted a dramatic increase in industrial disputation-which at Port Kembla alone rose by 680 per cent in the second part of the financial year-a disturbing decline in productivity, and the continuation of entrenched management and work practices. In view of the Authority's prediction that the steel industry will suffer as a result of predicted declines in the building and construction industries and the motor vehicle industry, what action will the Government take to alleviate the disturbing findings of the Steel Industry Authority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the best answer to that question-and I do not wish it to be misinterpreted-is none, if Senator Chaney was anticipating that I might say that the Government would offer some additional assistance to the steel industry, or anything like that. I am simply trying to make the point that the steel industry plan is structured in such a way that, if there is a decline in production, the bounty system becomes of more assistance to the industry. It is on a staggered scale, so it will have that effect. With the greatest respect to the question, which is clearly based on a careful gleaning of the Steel Industry Authority's report, I think the conclusion that the overall report casts serious doubts on the future of the steel industry has to be seen in the context of a number of very positive factors which are in the report.

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as there was an increase in industrial disputation in the steel industry, particularly, I think, starting in May this year, that is a source of concern and regret, but it is basically a matter for the companies and the work force to address, and the mechanisms have been put in place by the Government for that to happen. We will be trying, in every way we can, to encourage the enormously improved performance which has taken place in the steel industry over the last few years in respect of industrial unrest and the various disabling issues associated with that.

Insofar as the Steel Industry Authority comments on a decline in activity in the building and construction industry, that will depend on a variety of macroeconomic variables. While that was seen as a possibility in certain sections of the industry when I met with industry representatives a couple of months ago, it is not by any means certain that that will happen. I also draw attention to the fact that the steel industry expansion has significantly been directed into export activity. In spite of anything the Steel Industry Authority says, production is currently, I think, at a record level-it has been for the last few months-since the steel industry plan was put in place. One can always anticipate and speculate about downturns. The industry will have to accommodate that if it occurs, but I do not necessarily believe that it will.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Treasurer say what is the estimated revenue from the fringe benefits tax during the 1986-87 financial year? Can he also say what is the estimated cost to revenue of the 1 December personal income tax cuts during the current financial year? Does the Minister take the view that the revenue from the fringe benefits tax is vital to the financing of the personal income tax cuts on 1 December and that that is the essential reason why the Opposition and right wing groups in the community are campaigning against the fringe benefits tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The estimated revenue yield for this financial year from the fringe benefits tax is $325m and next year it is expected to be of the order of $575m. If one were to believe the assertions made in that infamous advertisement sponsored by Mr Ansett, Mr McLachlan and Mr Hay, the revenue yield from small business alone would be $2 billion. Now that, of course, is patently ridiculous. Those three people are maliciously and knowingly spreading lies in the community and they should be identified for what they are and judged accordingly. It is just unfortunate that someone like McLachlan is carrying quite a few gullible farmers along with him in his bogus campaign.

ANSWER.PARA: But it is absolutely correct that the fringe benefits tax is inseparable from the tax cuts that will be introduced-stage I on 1 December this year, and stage 2 on 1 July next year. The fringe benefits tax full-year revenue yield of the order of $600m is almost half the cost in this financial year of the first stage of the tax cuts and a smaller proportion of the cost of the tax cuts in future years. But the whole tax reform package, of which the fringe benefits tax is a major and essential component, is required to finance the tax cuts from which ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers and others, but principally PAYE taxpayers, will benefit on 1 December this year and 1 July next year. Those other people in the community, such as the gullible farmers who have been sucked in by McLachlan's disgusting campaign, who might be sucked in by the campaign that is being run by the bleaters, the whingers and the former tax evaders who want to go on evading tax as they have become accustomed to doing, ought to remember that the tax cuts which will benefit the ordinary taxpayers cannot be separated from the fringe benefits tax and all the other components of the tax reform package.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, concerns the price of fuel in this country, and the disparity between the revenues raised in excise and the expenditure on road maintenance and construction. I preface my question by stating that this Government, since coming to office in 1983, has increased the revenue raised from fuel excise by a massive 336 per cent. Is it a fact that the Government raises approximately $5.6 billion a year from fuel excise? Why is it that at a time of lower oil prices world-wide, this Government is further escalating fuel excise revenue? What is the Government's response to the fact that the net on-farm price of distillate has risen by 25 per cent in the past month alone? How can this Government justify the collection of these billions of dollars in fuel excise from motorists, transport operators and farmers for the specific purpose of providing finance for road construction and maintenance and yet not channel the funds back into much needed roadworks for the benefit of all Australians?

—It was very kind of Senator Bjelke-Petersen to address that question to me. I cannot address an answer to her. I do not know whether she would like to put her question on notice. If so, I will obtain an answer. Alternatively, arrangements could be made for Senator Bjelke-Petersen to ask the question of Senator Gareth Evans or the Minister for Finance on another occasion. There is a lot of detail in the question. I am certainly not across that, and I do not think I ever will be.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it a fact, as reported, that the Indonesian Army has already stationed 12 out of 30 battalions in Baucau prior to mounting an operation code named Kikis against the resistance fighters in East Timor? Is it a fact that this offensive is in response to the Fretilin occupation of Vikeke earlier this month? If these are facts, can the Minister indicate what action the Government proposes to take to endeavour to prevent bloodshed and the slaughtering of our former allies, the people of East Timor?

—Senator Robertson should appreciate that the Government simply does not wish to be drawn into detailed comment on the security situation in East Timor, including comment on the disposition and activities of Indonesian and pro-Fretilin military forces. All I can say on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs is that the Australian Government has consistently maintained the position that the military conflict in East Timor should be brought to an early, peaceful resolution. —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Did the Expenditure Review Committee decide shortly before the Budget was brought down that Telecom Australia should be forced to repay $98m of its outstanding long term debt to the Government in the course of this financial year? How will Telecom finance this repayment? In particular, will Telecom borrow this money itself or will it have another organisation do so for it; if so, which other organisation? Finally, can the Minister give the Parliament the assurance that the Government will not force Telecom to make payments to the Government out of retained earnings, and so run down its assets for short term budgetary reasons?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

As Senator Siddons said, there is a figure of $98m somewhere in the Budget Papers, but I do not know on precisely which pages, which is a repayment of debts owed to the Government by Telecom. ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the second part of the question regarding Telecom's capital expenditure program, I cannot remember the precise details of it, and I will see whether the Treasurer can supply anything more precise. TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. An article on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald today reports that another mid-air collision nearly occurred when two aircraft-one a 747 belonging to Qantas Airways Ltd and the other a DC10 belonging to Continental Airlines-passed within 300 metres of each other at the same altitude last Sunday between New Zealand and Australia. Will the Minister indicate the Government's attitude to this latest incident?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

The incident is being investigated by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigations with its New Zealand counterpart, as the incident appears to have happened in the New Zealand air space area.

ANSWER.PARA: No definitive details are as yet available, and they will not be available until the investigations have been completed. So it would be improper for me or for the Minister for Aviation to comment any further until that report is handed down by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigations.
