TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that where revenue raised by the Government is tied directly to specific government outlays only the net expenditure figures are recorded as outlays in the total Budget? Is it a fact that, when gross expenditure figures are considered, estimated government spending in 1986-87 is almost $3 billion higher than is shown in the Budget Papers, thereby recording a real increase in spending, not the nil increase claimed by the Government? Finally, is it also a fact that, when this factor is included, government spending as a proportion of gross domestic product this year will break that part of the Prime Minister's trilogy relating to expenditure, thereby joining the other broken leg of the trilogy, namely, that relating to taxation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the last part of the question, and to set the record straight, let me say that it was asserted that the taxation leg of the trilogy has been broken; it has not, although it is a possible interpretation. At the time the Prime Minister gave that undertaking, during the 1984 election campaign, tax revenue as a proportion of the estimated GDP for that year was 25.5 per cent, which is exactly the same as it is estimated to be this year. The outcome in 1984-85 was that tax revenue was 24 per cent of actual GDP because the GDP was larger than the 1984 Budget had forecast and tax revenue also fell short of the 1984 Budget forecast.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the other parts of the question, if the sort of adjustment that Senator Short is suggesting should be made were to be made, to get any meaningful comparison, of course, it would have to be made retrospectively; that is, applied back to the base years from which the trilogy or anything else is measured, as is the custom when changes of that type are made.

Off the top of my head I cannot say whether the figure of $3 billion is correct, but the Department of Treasury and the Department of Finance follow and, as I understand it, have followed for many years the international accounting conventions which define what is treated as revenue, what is treated as outlays and what revenue can be treated as an offset to outlays.

At the margin, whether particular items should be in or out is certainly arguable, there are clear cases where the Government is providing a service for which it is making a charge, such as aviation charges; the taxpayer is providing a service and most of the cost of that service is recovered from the industry. Under those circumstances I think it is conceptually quite clear that the revenue ought to be treated as an offset to outlays.

I do not think I have much more to say. I have already dealt with the assertion that Senator Short made about taxation. As for outlays, if $3 billion were to be added to this year's outlays, outlays might be about the same proportion of gross domestic product as they were in 1984-85, but of course it would be a foolish thing to make an adjustment in any particular year and then compare that year as adjusted with the figure of some previous year non-adjusted. One would, of course, be treating as like things which are unlike.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Special Minister of State report on Australian Federal Police investigations into several violent incidents which occurred in proximity to the women's peace camp last night? In particular, will the Minister ensure that there is a thorough examination of a number of events which included a molotov cocktail being thrown at the car of an elderly woman as she left the peace camp last night, the physical assault of three women during the night and a series of explosions with resulting fires adjacent to the peace camp? Can the Minister also report on the level of intoxication that is acceptable before the police are required to take action to curb the activities of people behaving aggressively in a public place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only information I have to hand on these matters at the moment is that supplied to me and indeed to Senator Gietzelt by way of follow-up to the question which was asked by Senator Knowles yesterday and which Senator Gietzelt was intending to read into the record after Question Time. But what I can say is that in regard to the specific questions that were answered yesterday about the particular matters in respect of which an investigation was urged and follow-up action of other kinds by police, the situation is as follows: There is no instruction to the Australian Federal Police not to intervene and no charges have been laid. By way of explanation of those two propositions, it is an accepted part of our society that members of it have a right to demonstrate peacefully. Whilst minor offences may occur from time to time, the AFP adopts a well established policy of not taking action on minor offences if that action is likely to aggra- vate the situation and may cause a significant breach of the peace. I am further advised that if any complaint is subsequently received, the AFP would, of course, investigate it. To date in this case no complaints have been received.

ANSWER.PARA: There are some other matters which Senator Reynolds addressed in her question. I will simply have to seek a further specific answer from the Special Minister of State and advise her accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Education been drawn to the statement from various Queensland academic staff protesting about the establishment of a private university on the Gold Coast, in which they made the pious assertion that `equitable education and profit are a contradiction in terms'? In view of the fact that the background paper released by the Bond Advisory Council states that it will be a non-profit-making, break-even operation, does the Minister agree that these pathetically defensive bleatings about profit are a smoke-screen to divert attention from the real prospects of at last meeting the excess demand for tertiary education in Queensland? Does the Minister accept that there is no prospect of a government funded university being established in the Gold Coast region, which includes the seventh largest city population in Australia, and that, if successful, a new university would free up access to other tertiary institutions? If not, will the Minister prefer the initial outlay for stage 1 of $125m to be devoted to another commercial television station, a new brewery or a better yacht?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston has asked a number of questions, many of them hypothetical. I have seen the reported statement of some Queensland academics expressing concern about proposals for a university which is to operate on a profit-making basis. I have not seen the Bond proposal, so I do not know whether it intends to operate on a profit-making basis, which some of its spokespersons certainly said earlier on, or whether it has now decided sensibly that an education institution cannot be profit-making.

ANSWER.PARA: I have some sympathy with the views expressed by academics that if an education institution is set up to be profit-making, it is almost inevitable that standards will be very low. I know of no university anywhere in the world which makes a profit out of its teaching programs. Certainly the kinds of universities that people like to throw into the debate at this stage, such as Harvard, do not operate on a profit-making basis. Harvard operates on a basis of the income it has from about $3 billion of its own money invested and it takes Federal and State grants. It is able to subsidise the fees charged to students who are able to get into Harvard.

If there is still a proposal that this institution should run on a profit-making basis, I think there are very real grounds for concern. If, on the other hand, there has been some change in the plan and the institution is to run on a non-profit basis--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have never seen the plan.
—I have said many times in this place that I have never seen the plan.
—What are you going on about? You do not know what you are talking about.

—I think Senator Archer should make his complaint to his own colleague. As I said, his own colleague has raised a series of hypothetical questions. I have made our Government's position on private institutions clear. I will repeat it now: There will be no public funding going towards private institutions of these kinds if they get going. Our concern will be to ensure that the reputation of Australian universities remains. Whether a proposal such as this will fill the unmet demand depends very much on what fees are charged, the entrance criteria and who will be prepared to go under those particular conditions. As yet, we do not know the answers to any of those questions.

—I ask a supplementary question. Before the Minister's train of thought was derailed by an interjection, she was in the process of stating what the Government's position would be in the event that it was not to be a profit-making institution. I therefore ask: Does the Minister have any objection in principle to the establishment of a private, non-profit-making university?
—Our position is that we will not give financial support to a private institution of this kind.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Does the Government intend to renegotiate the 1977 Pine Gap agreement, as suggested by Senator Kilgariff on 16 October? Are there any discussions about altering or amending that agreement under way at present, or has any alteration already taken place? If there were any renegotiations of the agreement, who would be involved in the discussions? Could the Minister explain exactly who would negotiate any new agreement? What provisions are there for the people of Australia, or their elected representatives, to be involved? Will the Australian public be notified if or when the terms of the agreement are altered in any way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should say at the outset, with particular reference to what Senator Kilgariff said on 16 October, that the 1977 agreement referred to by the honourable senator does not provide for the lease of the Joint Defence Space Research Facility. Rather, the 1977 agreement extended the 1966 agreement which established the facility and provides that the agreement be extended for a period of 10 years from 19 October 1977 and thereafter until terminated.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Vallentine is no doubt aware, one year's written notice to terminate the agreement may be given as of 19 October this year. As such, the agreement continues and there is no requirement for it to be renegotiated or amended. The Government presently sees no need to amend it and has no current intention of amending it. If at some time in the future a government were to decide the agreement needed renegotiation, such action could be taken. In the event that this or some subsequent government should decide that the 1977 agreement needed to be renegotiated, decisions on that renegotiation would, of course, be taken by Ministers, not by officials, and would be made in the light of full consideration of all aspects of our policies on foreign affairs and defence. As Ministers will be taking these decisions, I certainly believe that this will represent involvement by elected representatives of the Australian people in Senator Vallentine's terms. Again, I make it clear that, as the 1977 agreement is a public document, any changes will also be public.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The only aspect of the question to which Senator Evans did not refer was the people of Australia having any involvement in that decision-making process. Since the original agreements, as all agreements and treaties which have been jointly signed by the Australian and the United States of America governments, have been conducted without the consultation of the Australian people and in secrecy, is there any provision or intention to allow the Australian people to have a say in this matter if it does come up for renegotiation?
—We are not, mercifully, in the habit of conducting referendums or plebiscites on matters of policy in this or any other area. I believe I have sufficiently answered Senator Vallentine's question.

—Does the Minister representing the Minister for Health recall the recent claim by the Tobacco Institute of Australia that Dr Robert Masironi of the World Health Organisation and Professors Robin Weiss and Julian Peto of the Institute of Cancer Research in London have claimed that passive smoking is safe? Is the Minister now aware that the doctor and the two professors have since written to newspapers across Australia refuting the claims made by the Tobacco Institute, which used their names in newspaper advertisements across Australia? Is it a fact that the World Health Organisation Executive in January this year reaffirmed and strengthened its public views on the health dangers of smoking to both smokers and non-smokers? Is it also a fact, as Dr Masironi has claimed, that views attributed by the Tobacco Institute to the World Health Organisation were put forward at a conference in which the WHO did not participate or cooperate in any way? Did the study to which the Tobacco Institute referred in its advertisements in fact relate to work funded by the United Kingdom Tobacco Advisory Council, a body representing the tobacco industry in Britain? Finally, since Professors Weiss and Peto had to write letters refuting conclusions attributed to them by the Tobacco Institute of Australia, what can be done to stop irresponsible and untruthful lobbying by the Tobacco Institute of Australia as it seeks to deny to Australians the truthful and balanced information on smoking needed by each of us to make our own responsible decisions about this personal habit?
—Mr President--
—You can bring damages for drugs.
—Senator Elstob has a strange view of the term `drugs'. The most commonly abused drug in this country and the drug which causes the most illness, disease and distress is tobacco.
—There are none so pure as those who have reformed.
—Senator Baume has asked a serious question; I am sorry that Senator Walters does not think it is serious. All the statements Senator Baume made are correct.
—That won't work. You are trying to pull swifties all the time.
—Mr President, it is very surprising that Senator Walters, who used to take this matter very seriously, now considers that it is a matter for great levity.
—She has gone to pot.

—That is unkind, but I respond to Senator Colston to get his interjection in Hansard. All the statements made by Senator Baume are correct. The Tobacco Institute of Australia does frequently misuse information, even information which has been distributed at the behest of one of its brother or sister organisations such as the Tobacco Advisory Council in Britain. It is unfortunate that an organisation like this should, through the Press by way of paid advertisements et cetera, deliberately misrepresent the attitude not only of doctors such as those who have had to complain in these circumstances but also of the World Health Organisation. The simple fact of the matter is that if we are to make the choice on whether to smoke or not-and it is a choice-we should have the capacity to make that choice in the light of accurate information. The implication of Senator Baume's question is right. The Minister for Health and the Government will have to look at a means of combating this misinformation. We are a free country, a country where people have the capacity to air their views as they like-and I hope it will remain that way-but we need to be able to refute those views as quickly as possible. I will refer the matters that Senator Baume has raised to the Minister for Health for a further answer.

—Is the Minister for Resources and Energy able to say whether the recent decision of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries to extend its current production agreement will have any effect on current oil prices in Australia? Can the Minister also advise whether the increased production forecast by OPEC will have any effect on on-shore and off-shore drilling for new oil deposits in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is some news that has just come to hand that the OPEC countries meeting in Geneva, after what has been their longest meeting ever, have just reached some agreement which involves a slight increase in their production quota, but I do not have any further details to hand. I think we can probably assume, the way that the meeting was going, that it is only a slight increase in the production quota and it is probably only temporary at this stage, until the end of the year. Accordingly, it is difficult to judge at this stage precisely what the impact on Australian oil prices will be and what consequential problems there will be down the line. Nonetheless, I can make some points of general interest on the basis of the situation as I am aware of it.

ANSWER.PARA: Any significant change in world oil prices either before Christmas as a result of this agreement or thereafter will be directly reflected in Australian crude oil prices via our import parity pricing policy. As to where prices are likely to go in the short to medium term, it emerged clearly from my discussions with some of the major OPEC Ministers at the end of last month, including in particular Sheikh Yamani from Saudi Arabia and Sheikh Al-Khalifa from Kuwait, that they will be attempting, as today's news seems to indicate they have succeeded in doing, to hold something like the status quo until the end of the year but it is also clear that subsequently they will be trying for 1987 to recognise some pressures from some of their members for higher production quotas in their agreed production levels. Whether such an increase, say to around 18 million barrels a day for OPEC countries compared with, until today, 16.8 million barrels, would be compatible with the achievement of a $US15 to $US17 or $US18 price level, which has already been stated as a desirable objective for OPEC, it is difficult to say.

Whether prices can be maintained at that sort of level will depend upon a number of things: First, the level of stocks currently held by distributors and consumers, which are currently at a very high level; secondly, the extent to which non-OPEC producers, particularly Mexico and the United Kingdom and Norway in the North Sea, limit their output either officially or unofficially; thirdly, the extent to which OPEC members themselves can hold to the production and price agreements that they make without cheating on the part of the United Arab Emirates and others which are well known to do that sort of thing; fourthly, the circumstances of the Iran-Iraq war, which currently is clearly holding back significant production capacity; and, finally, the growth of consumer demand which itself relies on such imponderables as the severity of the impending northern hemisphere winter, the level of economic growth in major consumption centres around the world and possibly some further changes in consumer behaviour in the light of currently depressed oil prices. An OPEC agreement which one way or the other did keep market prices around the $US15 to $US17 level would be a pretty satisfactory outcome for Australia in all the circumstances. It would not add significantly to existing prices for petroleum products in Australia but if sustained for any reasonable period, or given the prospect of being sustained, would certainly keep some incentive alive for Australian oil explorers, who as we all know are presently experiencing very difficult times as a result of low world oil prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce noted the warning from General Motors-Holden's Ltd that union claims for superannuation are jeopardising the future of the motor vehicle industry? Is the Government considering or about to consider making representations to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to establish an immediate moratorium on those union claims? Since the market for motor vehicles is already being severely affected as a result of Government action such as the fringe benefits tax, devaluation and interest rates, will it also take up General Motors' suggestion as a matter of urgency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The nature of the question is best illustrated by the last part, in which I am asked whether I agree that there are Government-induced factors, including devaluation, that have affected the viability of the motor vehicle industry. If Senator Messner wants to have a debate at Question Time or after Question Time about the floating of the dollar and the devaluation that has taken place subsequently, I am happy to do it. The benefits of devaluation to industry generally in this country have been significant. They have been significant in terms of the motor vehicle industry, and particularly the local manufacturers. Other Government-induced things with which Senator Messner charges us are various taxation measures and so on. I just make the point that there was no sicker manufacturing industry in the world, probably, than the Australian motor vehicle industry under the previous Government. For the entire seven years of that Government the industry was in a mess. It had to be rescued from that mess, and it has been rescued by this Government. In spite of difficulties that the industry is currently encountering, it is a much stronger industry now than it ever was in any period of Liberal government. One of the reasons that it was in such a mess was that the previous Government, I think in 1981, put in a vehicle plan for the motor vehicle industry the terms of which were dictated by one manufacturer to a weak government. That is a matter of record in the industry. The Opposition can try to deny it, but all people in the industry know that that is what happened. And Senator Messner asks me a question about General Motors-Holden's Ltd!

ANSWER.PARA: Of all General Motors-Holden's problems, the least of them would be, in general terms, the fact that there is a superannuation dispute there at the moment. General Motors-Holden's has been losing $4m a week. It has enormous debts. It has lost its market share. That is what the restructuring of the company is about. I welcome that restructuring because it gives the company the opportunity to strengthen its position in Australia and potentially to grow. All Australians should welcome that.

I turn to the nit point-as in nitpicking-that Senator Messner sought to make about the news reports in today's newspapers. Yes, I very much regret the fact that General Motors has had to stand down workers as a result of a superannuation dispute by metal workers. It is the sort of thing, as I have said on previous occasions and say again, that this country cannot afford in the future. Senator Messner also asked what the Government is doing about it. The Government has been having a series of negotiations with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and with others to try to bring about a resolution of the superannuation issue. I am not in a position at the moment to say precisely what that will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the Minister confirm reports that on Monday, 20 October four East Timorese students sought political asylum in the Netherlands Embassy in Jakarta? If so, does the Government have any further information on this event? Can the Minister also confirm that the Australian Council for Overseas Aid has asked the Australian Government to consider offering the four East Timorese asylum here? If so, has the Government made any decision on this request?

—I am advised by the Minister for Foreign Affairs that the Government understands that there are four East Timorese students in the Dutch Embassy in Jakarta who have sought Dutch assistance to travel to Portugal. Of course, the Dutch represent Portuguese interests in Indonesia. I am also aware that the Australian Council for Overseas Aid put out a Press release on 20 October calling on the Australian Government to grant asylum to these students. No application has been received from the students. If any application were received, it would, of course, be evaluated against the established criteria for the granting of asylum.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Is the Minister aware that many nutritional experts are alarmed at the decline in milk consumption among school children, leading to a calcium deficiency? Is the Minister aware of a pilot program being conducted in Queensland to place vending machines in primary schools to give access to flavoured milk, the trade name being `Cool Fuel'? I mention that this worthwhile program is in jeopardy because of this Government's 10 per cent sales tax on these items. In view of the importance of this program to the nutritional well-being of our primary school children, and the fact that these products will be available only to schools, will the Government undertake to waive the recently imposed sales tax on the products in this program?

—The answer to the last part of the question is no. With regard to the earlier part, I am not aware of the study to which Senator Collard referred. I will take his word for it that there is such a study that has come up with those sorts of conclusions, which might lead one to believe that it would be a good thing if children were to consume more milk. However, whether it would be a good thing for children to consume flavoured milk loaded with extra sugar is another issue. I am not sure how on balance that would work out healthwise.

—My question is to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. The significant devaluation of the Australian dollar seems to have provided a substantial boost to the international competitiveness of Australia's manufacturing industries. Will the Minister provide an indication of the extent to which the devaluation has affected the export performance of our industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Historically, Australia's export base has been a narrow one, relying mainly on agricultural and mineral commodities. Senator Crowley asks an important question. I recall that Senator Lewis asked me a more specific question on this issue three or four weeks ago. In the opinion of many people, our exchange rate under the coalition Government was greatly overvalued. The Fraser Liberal Government gave the manufacturing sector no chance to become internationally competitive or export oriented. The legacy of all that is now clear. Of course, other factors were at work which camouflaged what went on at that time, in a sense, from a wide range of people in the community.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that our manufacturing sector now exports less than 15 per cent of its output. This percentage is far lower than that in countries such as New Zealand, where the figure is 25 per cent, Canada where it is 32 per cent, Korea and West Germany where it is 30 per cent, the Netherlands where it is 48 per cent, and Sweden where it is 45 per cent. Only 60 per cent of our manufactured exports are elaborately transformed. Only a few, 3.5 per cent, are research and development intensive. Many other countries are well ahead in these respects. It is hoped that this poor performance is in the past and that Australia's competitive position has now been greatly enhanced by the devaluation of the dollar. Of course, it has also to be enhanced by better performance in marketing, quality design and things of that kind-the other side of competitiveness.

As I have said on a number of occasions, the effect of the exchange rate movement will be slow on the export and import competing performance of the manufacturing sector. The balance of payments figures of recent months suggest some improvement in export volumes. The overall picture is one of a very gradual adjustment to the devaluation and the associated renewal of international competitiveness. As I have said on previous occasions, we cannot expect a quick turnaround in either the balance of payments or the behaviour of industries which grew up in a highly different and highly protected environment and which were stifled by an inappropriate exchange rate regime.

Today the Bureau of Industry Economics will release a further study of the impact of the devaluation on industry performance. The first study, released two or three weeks ago, examined the effects on importers and import competing manufacturers. It found very limited scope for import replacement in the short term as two-thirds of imports have no suitable locally produced substitute.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seventy per cent.

—I said two-thirds. I do not know whether the honourable senator is having a debate with me or is just telling me what two-thirds is. The export study was undertaken in February-March 1986. The earlier study was done in 1985. The export study examined the adjustment of exporters of elaborately transformed manufactures and processed foods. The results were derived from a postal survey conducted early this year and from personal interviews. The results are not encouraging for those who seek the quick fix for industry problems and performance. Overall, the study found that, although the volume of locally manufactured exports increased in 1985 following the sharp drop in the value of the dollar, most of the growth was due to a temporary increase in demand for some products and did not indicate a sustained growth in Australia's export performance.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the major findings in the study was that, in the short term, a significant increase in manufactured exports is unlikely, partly because of the prevalence of corporate strategies which do not place prime importance on exporting and also because of the difficulties associated with export orders. This result could also reflect the fact that for many products price is only a relatively minor factor in achieving export sales. Another major finding was that a number of market factors inhibit the growth of manufactured exports. They include overseas concerns about reliability of supply; the fact that many Australian firms have not been consistent exporters, but have used the export market as an arena for surplus products; and also that Australia's reputation has not been good as a reliable supplier over many years. Another factor was continuing competition. Many newly industrialised countries have revalued, or devalued only slightly, against the Australian dollar and continued to compete in overseas markets. A further factor was weakening overseas markets, some of which have not increased as much as expected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want me to take a point of order?

—I do not care what honourable senators opposite think is important. The survey indicated that firms which are already export oriented form the only identifiable group which clearly increased the profitability of their export activities as a result of the 1985 devaluation. A number of other things in the study are very important, but they amount to this: The devaluation is not likely to lead to a significant increase in exports in the short term. It shows that some manufacturers will take advantage of it, while others will not; and that the process of adjustment to renewed competitiveness is likely to be very slow. I draw the Opposition's attention to the survey; it is worth reading.

—Is the Minister for Education aware that some external students in higher education are already being asked to pay the Government's proposed administration charge at their enrolment in November of this year, even before this Parliament has determined whether there should be a charge? Is the Minister aware that these external students, unlike internal students, usually enrol or re-enrol in the November preceding the year of studies? Have the tertiary institutions been given any specific instructions regarding the enrolment of external students and the application of any charge: If not, is the Minister taking steps to overcome the apparent confusion regarding external students and so avoid embarrassment to higher education institutions and uncertainty in the minds of those students enrolling for external studies?

—I am not aware of the claim made by Senator Macklin that external students are being asked to pay their administration charge for 1987 in November of this year. If it is the case that they are being asked to do that, I think it is quite surprising that I am not aware of it, since I met with the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee just last week to discuss the implementation of the charge.
—CAEs.

—I see. Well, it has not been brought to my attention. In any event, a working party is to be set up, with representatives of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals in Advanced Education and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, to discuss the most straightforward and efficient and least difficult way of ensuring that students who are liable to pay the charge for 1987 do pay it without undue difficulty to themselves or their institutions.

—My question also is directed to the Minister for Education. Is the Minister aware of a movement called Feebusters which has been organised by tertiary students in South Australia? The organisers of this movement are calling for all eligible students to boycott the payment of the higher education administration charge. There has also been a call for the Government to introduce a fairer system in relation to the charge. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the Government's opinion of this movement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that some student activists have been calling for a boycott of the charge and I think in Western Australia that situation might be a bit more prevalent because the Western Australian Minister for Education seems to be encouraging students to resist paying the charge. That is not a very sensible course of action because, as Mr Pearce would understand and as all student leaders who have spoken to me now understand, non-payment of the charge will simply penalise the institutions. Our Government's grants to the institutions will be adjusted to take account of the fact of the charge being paid. So, if students are liable to pay the charge and refuse to pay it, that will be a matter for the institutions to take up with them, since they will be reducing the amount of money available to their institutions.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the comments about the fairness of the charge, I remind honourable senators, and I particularly remind those student activists who are engaging in a bit of a disinformation campaign, that the charge will not affect any student who is in receipt of education allowances, formerly under the tertiary education assistance scheme, but now known as Austudy. It will not affect Aboriginal students who are on Austudy. It will not affect single parent beneficiaries, invalid pensioners or carer pensioners. Also, of course, the charge extends only to students in colleges of advanced education and universities; it does not affect technical and further education students in any TAFE courses. So, the claim that there is no equity in the charge is really very poorly based.

The charge is a very modest one. We have made it clear that it is our intention to leave the charge at $250, adjusting it only to account for inflation in future years. In the light of the public benefit that students in higher education get-a benefit which ranges from about $7,000 a year up to $18,000 or $20,000 a year, depending on which course is being undertaken-we consider that it is fair to require a very modest contribution to the administration costs of the institutions from those students who are not in the poorer category of students.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to his comments about interest rates in the Australian Financial Review of 12 November 1985-nearly a year ago. I know that the Minister has a good memory; so I know that he will remember these words:

QUESTION.PARA: The predictions made by Mr Keating and the Prime Minister have turned out to be incorrect: there is no doubt about that.

Have predictions by some Government Ministers that interest rates would fall this year also turned out to be incorrect? When will Australian interest rates return to world parity, given that this week the prime lending rate in the United Kingdom is 11 per cent; in the United States, 7.5 per cent; in West Germany, 7 per cent; and in Japan, 4 per cent; while in Australia it is 19 per cent?

TALK.START.PARA: —I, of course, recall what I said on 12 November 1985. That was, as I remember it, the day after 11 November 1985 and, of course, it is fixed in my memory. I do not think anybody who has predicted that interest rates will fall in this financial year is incorrect. The honourable senator went on to ask me when Australian interest rates will assume some degree of world parity. I have been around here long enough to see conservative politicians in previous governments with egg all over their faces through predicting interest rate movements. I will not be in that game. I do not think anybody really should be, except in the general sense. But if the honourable senator wants me to make a general prediction I will do so: Yes, interest rates will fall significantly this financial year. The honourable senator can use that prediction in July and refer me to my answer of 12 November 1985, if he wants to. I do not regard comparisons with other countries as terribly important or relevant in the current context, following the devaluation of the Australian dollar and having regard to a wide range of other economic indicators which might be quoted on both sides of the chamber.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen allegations that the Budget figure for Medicare benefits is understated? How does this allegation measure up against the current level of expenditure on Medicare benefits? Secondly, what is the current rate at which medical practitioners are bulk billing the Health Insurance Commission for their services to patients?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the allegation has been made, particularly by the Opposition spokesman on health, whose name I cannot remember, that the Medicare budget has come in considerably in excess of the sum estimated. The facts are that for the first quarter of 1986-87 the budget was $746.3m and actual expenditure $742.1m, which is an incredible piece of estimation. Not only is the budget on target, but utilisation of medical services has only marginally increased in the September quarter compared with the same period last year.

ANSWER.PARA: In September over 50 per cent of all services were direct billed-50.6 per cent to be exact. According to the Opposition and other opponents of Medicare, this should lead to excessive servicing and increased costs. SPEECH.PARA: The main item on the Government's current political agenda is how to fill a couple of ministerial and Party vacancies. That issue will consume this Government while the Australian economy withers. This Government has no sense whatsoever of priority, leadership or direction. A quick glance at a few economic indicators reveals our current state of decline, despite what the Government might say about recovery and the J-curve being just around the bend. It is certainly around the bend. Let us look at economic growth. In the December 1985 quarter, growth in Australia was minus 0.6 per cent. In the March 1986 quarter it was minus 0.2 per cent and in the June 1986 quarter it was minus 0.2 per cent. Technically we are in recession. In recent months we have had a decline in car registrations, building activity, consumer sentiment, business investment and, above all else, confidence. We are lacking confidence. The 30 per cent depreciation in our currency has not turned around our mediocre performance.

What about the balance of payments? In 1985-86 the current account deficit was $13.7 billion, or 6 per cent of gross domestic product. The 1986 Budget estimate is $14.6 billion or 5.75 per cent of gross domestic product. In the first quarter of 1986-87 we have already notched up in excess of $4 billion-in fact $4.263 billion or an increase of 19 per cent over the same three-month period last year. We are heading for a total deficit for the year of about $16 billion. Let me compare this performance with those of other countries. Taking the current account deficit as a percentage of GDP, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development estimates that in 1986-87 Australia will have a figure of minus 0.6 per cent. This compares with Japan with an estimate of plus 4.2 per cent; West Germany with plus 3.4 per cent; France with plus 1.1 per cent and Italy with plus 0.9 per cent. I repeat that the estimate for Australia is minus 0.6 per cent.

More importantly, our growing balance of trade deficit is sending this country into hock at the rate of $1 billion-that is, $1,000m-a month. The number of goods we import continues to rise and our exports are simply not paying for them. Our foreign debt has tripled in the time this Labor Government has been in power and this financial year the Treasurer is set to become the world's first non-Spanish speaking Treasurer to preside over a $100 billion foreign debt. What a record! It is only matched by the Treasurer's other great achievement-the recent loss of Australia's AAA credit rating. The Treasury expects that foreign debt of $100 billion to be reached this financial year. It represents $7,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia. Every new born baby in this country will carry into the world an IOU for $7,000. The Government's Economic Planning Advisory Council, in its recently released report entitled `External debt and economic growth', pointed out that in 1980-in what now seems like a golden age before the Labor Government came into office-our net external debt amounted to 6 per cent of GDP. In 1986 that figure is 29 per cent. In 1990 EPAC estimates that our foreign debt will be 40 per cent of gross domestic product-that is, 40 per cent of what we produce in this country. The staggering thing is that each month's balance of trade figures, which nudge us ever closer to the precipice, seem to create less and less concern in the community. We have become so used to bad economic news, yet our problems do not go away.

What about inflation and unemployment? Honourable senators should remember that this Government was elected on the promise of simultaneously reduced inflation and unemployment from the admittedly high levels of the recession of 1982-83. What is the situation now? Inflation is forecast to be around 8 per cent in 1986-87. In Japan, which is one of our major trading partners, the inflation rate for 1987 is estimated at zero. For West Germany it is 0.25 per cent and for the United States 2.5 per cent. The average for the OECD is 3 per cent. With the devaluation-indeed the debasement-of our currency under this Government one might well ask what has happened to the quick fix? Why has the J-curve not worked? Why has there not been a correction on our balance of payments? One of the major reasons is that our inflation rate remains high. Unless and until that inflation rate is brought down we will be back where we started and the massive devaluation will be of no benefit whatsoever. It is horrifying to think about the situation of this country and the trend in interest rates. In fact, the two major reasons why there has not been a response to devaluation have been the enormously high interest rates and inflation which continues to increase at a rate which is significantly higher than those of our trading partners.

The most recent figures on the growth in average earnings in Australia show an increase of 6.6 per cent. In Japan the figure is 2.2 per cent, in West Germany 3.3 per cent, in the United States 2.4 per cent and in Canada 2.6 per cent. It is little wonder that our cost structure in Australia is so high. On the unemployment front we record a current figure of well over 8 per cent and rising. Our stagnating growth will ensure that that gets worse and the Government itself admits this. Unemployment among our young people remains above 20 per cent-that is, one in five of our children are not able to get jobs when they leave school, mainly because of a rigid centralised wage fixing system which prevents employers from paying them realistic wages. This is truly a crime against society caused by a crazy, inflexible award structure. The theme of the 1983 National Economic Summit, which was the cornerstone of the Australian Labor Party's economic strategy, was `jobs, jobs, jobs'. Three years later, despite all the Government's bluster, the average length of periods of unemployment for people has increased from 34 weeks to 52 weeks. I wonder what the kids who are just about to leave school will think about that. When they find there is no work for them what will they think about the Government's promise of `jobs, jobs, jobs'?

Struggling families, particularly single income families, know the cruel triple whammy of ever growing taxes, rising prices and crippling interest rates on their mortgages. Short term interest rates today are running at about 17.4 per cent. In Japan they are 4.7 per cent, in West Germany 4.4 per cent, in the United States of America 5.6 per cent and in Canada 2.6 per cent. What does that mean to average people with mortgages of, say, $50,000 on their homes? It means that average people out there battling with those sorts of mortgages on their homes are paying $70 per week extra in interest than people in comparable countries overseas. That money is not being spent on consumer goods, investment or savings.

These figures tell a very sorry tale. They show why our standard of living has fallen and private capital investment is declining. It is a fact that Australia's high interest rates and taxes mean that a gross return of 25 per cent is required on investment in Australia, compared with 15 per cent in Hong Kong, 16 per cent in the United States and 18 per cent in Britain. That is why business is not investing in this country and that is why our immediate prospects are so grim.

I refer to a little-publicised speech by the Prime Minister to the Fabian Society in May 1984. The Prime Minister addressed the Fabian Society which, as everyone knows, is the philosophical and intellectual base of socialists throughout the world. He said that what the Fabians were all about is the principle of gradualism. He referred to Sidney Webb, one of the Society's gurus, who talked about permeation. The Prime Minister said that what we need to do is change the hearts and minds of people. Today he says that we do not call this permeation or gradualism; we call it consensus. If that does not put a new meaning on the word `consensus' I will be very surprised. Finally, in the Prime Minister's speech to the Fabian Society he pointed out what we must do. He said:
. . . you must wait, as Fabius did, most patiently, when warring against Hannibal, though many censured his delays; but when the time comes you must strike hard . . .

That is what the word `consensus' means. Our standards of living have fallen dramatically under this Labor Government. The ordinary Australian knows this. It shows up in the miserable amount of increase in after tax take home pay that everyone will receive and it shows up in the price of goods on the supermarket shelves. It shows up every time we fill up the car with petrol and every time we take the family out for a meal.

The Labor Party promised us that during its term of office there would be no increase in the overall tax burdens as measured by the share of gross domestic product taken by the Government in tax revenues. This was part of the famous trilogy about which we do not hear much these days. What has actually happened? In the past two Budgets the Government has increased the percentage of tax collected as a proportion of gross domestic product. In 1986-87 the Government will collect $1.4 billion in additional tax over the trilogy ceiling. Tax collections as a proportion of GDP have gone up from 25 per cent to 25.5 per cent in the last Budget.

In addition to the false nature of the tax cuts promised in December we have a whole range of new taxes-a sales tax hike, an increase in the Medicare levy, a capital gains tax, a fringe benefits tax, a higher tax on lump sum superannuation and an entertainment tax. When we talk about these taxes, everyone will recall the famous statement on the new capital gains tax by the Prime Minister when he said: `Let me say in words that even the Opposition will understand: There will be no capital gains tax'. One of the many promises. Now we are told by the Government that all will be well again; that the necessary decisions have now been taken to set things right. Yet the Government's very own Budget forecasts for the year show no fall in inflation, unemployment, foreign debt, the balance of payments deficit, the overall levels of taxation or wasteful Government expenditure.

Part of the matter of public importance is in respect of the broken promises. Recently some research was done on Labor's record of promises versus performance. The catalogue of indecisions, reversals and broken promises for 1986 alone in that research came to 18 pages. Let us look briefly at that catalogue of 18 pages of broken promises. Of course we have the most famous one, to which I referred earlier, the capital gains tax. We were promised lower petrol prices. We remember how Paul Keating, when in opposition, accused the Government of establishing a branch of the Australian Taxation Office at every petrol pump. Yet under the Labor Government car users are paying an additional 14c a litre in petrol taxes since Labor came to power. Before the 1984 election Mr Hawke and Mr Keating promised lower interest rates. Since that promise was made we have suffered the highest continual interest rates for 50 years.

The Government simply has not informed the people of Australia of the true state of our national plight. For three years we have been led to believe that we were living in some sort of paradise. In reality we were living in a Hawke's fools paradise. Unfortunately, the people placed their trust in Labor, but it will not happen again. What we need and must create in Australia is an environment where wealth creation, individual enterprise and business investment are actively encouraged and rewarded. Our primary concern must be the creation of wealth, which is impossible under the Labor Government's inconsistent policies.

Queensland is dragging the national average down. It is below the other States on 18 key economic indicators. It is below the national average on 12 of those indicators, scores the worst score of all the States on five and the second worst on six of them. That is a factor that has to be considered in the general economic scenario.

I was about to conclude my remarks by going to some of the details of our general national economic performance. Perhaps, given the delay that has occurred, I can summarise that by referring to a speech presented to the Confederation of Australian Industry by Dr Don Stammer, a consultant economist for Bain and Co., and circulated to back benchers. In that speech he calls upon the detractors of the Australian economy to look at the opportunities available and in effect to stop bad mouthing Australia and get on with the job of producing the wealth that is there to be produced. By very strong inference, one can say that the lack of objectivity and the always carping criticism of the Opposition is nothing short of an economic crime against the performance of this country. Those who perpetrate it should stand clearly identified as those who would deny Australia the growth it could achieve were they to promote a more confident vision of this country, which is an accurate vision. That is essentially the theme of the Stammer address to the Confederation of Australian Industry. I conclude by referring to a graph on page 9 of his address, headed `Australia's International Competitiveness'. The graph is formulated from his own research and shows that unit labor costs are the lowest they have been at least since 1970 and that on a less competitive-more competitive scale Australia is now more competitive in its internal economy and with its trading partners than it has been at any time in that period.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hawke Labor Government came to power on a wave of social and economic optimism. The Australian Labor Party claimed to stand for participation, consensus, equity and justice. The National Economic Summit Conference in 1983 epitomised a new era of consultative government which eventually culminated in the National Taxation Summit. It was said then that tax reform would mark the beginning of a new era in economic justice and growth. However, since then the lights have gone out. The Labor Government lost its nerve. Instead of tax reform, we got more of the same. We have had patch on patch on the old tax system which is leaking like a sieve and requiring more and more bureaucratic paperwork, more and more bureaucrats and more and more accountants working overtime and discovering new ways to plug new rorts in the taxation system. Instead of economic justice and growth, we have seen a rundown in the economy to the point where many small businessmen are giving up the unequal struggle with the Government's regulations, exports have slumped and unemployment is again rising out of control.

SPEECH.PARA: Deregulation of coal export prices is a signal to the world that we are prepared to drop our prices and allow our coal producers to be picked off one at a time. Indeed, this will have quite an effect on the Queensland economy. The indicators are that already this has caused a price drop of around $4 a tonne. Rex Connor died protecting our national resources from that type of cartel pressure. The Government pays lip-service to the concept of buying Australian but it has taken no strong measures to tie Australian suppliers into the large resource projects on the North West Shelf. Along with the burgeoning bureaucracy, the Government has set about dismantling the protective machinery against foreign takeovers and foreign ownership of Australian land and resources.

There is no credible foreign investment policy. The Foreign Investment Review Board is being weakened although for the last few years it has reported decreasing productive investment in new and expanded manufacturing enterprises and increasing incursions into the Australian property and financial services market. It is not productive investment that we are getting; it is speculative investment by people from overseas. This leaves Australia with no strategic view of foreign investment and allows takeovers of successful Australian firms such as Nicholas Kiwi Ltd and Repco Corporation. Now Australian Consolidated Industries is under threat from an American company, Henley Group Inc., which is about to buy 10 per cent of its capital. Since it is unlikely that ACI will want a sleeping investment of 10 per cent, Henley will probably attempt to get a controlling interest at a later date. We are selling Australia holus-bolus to foreign investors. This Government is not doing anything to protect our local people from being taken over. There are no `buy Australian' regulations for government departments, in spite of the Government's lip-service and public expenditure on a campaign to promote this policy in the private sector. A notice of motion on this subject standing in my name will be debated tomorrow.

The Government has a dualistic view of the value of the dollar. On the one hand, we are told of the advantages to our exporters of a low dollar exchange rate. We are told that it is part of the Government's strategy to keep the dollar low so that Australian exports are more competitive on world markets. On the other hand, the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Government have been taking steps to maintain the value of the dollar on international exchange markets. In July and August this year these measures resulted in the loss of Australian foreign currency reserves of $2.5 billion-more than the total drop in reserves for the previous 12 months. The Government is giving away our foreign reserves. The Government has consistently refused to support the obvious need for world currency reform, despite the slide in the value of the Australian dollar caused by massive movements of speculative capital in and out of Australia, of so-called `hot money'.

Our terms of trade have declined by 15 per cent since January 1985 but the dollar has declined in value by 40 per cent. This leaves Australian resources wide open to invasion and takeover on a grand scale and underlines our position as a Third World country, a banana republic, in trade terms. We would have much more influence if we joined the developing countries and negotiated from their total current pos- ition of strength. Indeed, with them we would have the capacity to bring about the demise of the current world banking system rather than hanging on the coat tails of the United States of America and supporting a system that is basically already bankrupt.

The time is ripe as never before to pressure for a new world economic order, for economic justice and an international code of business conduct enforceable at law. The time is ripe to set standards of acceptable international corporate behaviour and international accounting standards for scrutiny of the books of large international trading conglomerates. The time is ripe for reform of the international currency market, which disadvantages developing countries and advantages those which are technologically advanced. It is only through international justice that we can expect a lasting world peace and an end to poverty, and to the diseases and starvation which are caused by that poverty. Indeed, the Government is doing little or nothing about this. Yet our own survival is dependent upon our getting a sensible trading relationship with countries around the world, upon setting up a new world economic order in which Australia can be a proud and sensible partner in trade with all the other countries of our region and beyond.

As most honourable senators will know, there has been a massive decline in our terms of trade and an equally massive decline in our current account. Australia has always been a trading nation dependent on agriculture and resources for export income, with our prosperity stemming pretty well solely from the export of those commodities which are subsidised by a high level of foreign investment. Manufacturing has never comprised more than about one-quarter of the gross domestic product. Because of natural disadvantages such as distance and market size, compounded by inefficiencies stemming from the high level of protection, the manufacturing industries have seldom been competitive either at exporting or even at import replacement. The Government is doing nothing effective about this problem. Despite the fact that the cost of industry protection through tariffs, quotas and bounties has been well known for decades, the alliance of employers and unions, and the fact that many industries are geographically concentrated, which increases their political influence, has led to the survival of protection as a means of holding together certain industries such as the motor vehicle and textile industries.

We need to look very closely at our trading arrangements. The Government has not properly done that. It has just accepted the edicts from the mandarins at Treasury, the `Stone clones' who have been running this country for many years. It is very disappointing when a government such as the Hawke Government, which put forward high ideals before it came to power, continually breaks promises. That is exactly what this matter of public importance is about.

The Hawke Government has broken promises. It has permitted the large scale introduction of foreign banks, contrary to its position prior to being elected to government. It has permitted major overseas ownership in vital resource projects such as the North West Shelf, and it has now effectively closed down the Foreign Investment Review Board. It has permitted the export of uranium to France, relaxed the ceiling on home loan interest rates, and replaced wage indexation, the centrepiece of the prices and incomes accord, with a wage discounting system. I must say that these are rather fundamental policy reversals.

But it is indeed funny that the Opposition should object and criticise the Government for these particular broken promises, because in each case, in breaking the promises, the Government has substituted for its own policy that of the Opposition during the last election campaign. The introduction of foreign banks was Opposition policy. The Opposition argued that the FIRB should be done away with, that uranium should be exported and that wages should be discounted. We have, in fact, two identical groups of people-the Government and the Opposition-following the same types of policies and insulting each other for doing so. This is quite unreasonable and I believe that not only has the Government broken its promise but also members of the Opposition have abrogated their responsibility to the people who elected them, because they are currently letting the Government carry on on a helter-skelter course towards economic destruction of Australia and are not doing anything about it. The Opposition basically lets the Government do whatever it wants provided that the Government uses the words `this is a Budget Bill' in front of whatever it presents. I believe the people of Australia need to know this.

The main point of my presentation is that, while a lot of the problems that have come about have been due to external factors, the Labor Government has not been up to handling them. The Labor Government has lost not only its economic nerve but also its electoral nerve. This really is a problem. More and more the Government is hiding from the people, avoiding consultation, abolishing or emasculating all the democratic and consultative institutions which it proudly espoused when it came into government. We have seen just recently the proposition for the demise of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs-a national representative and consultative body to promote multiculturalism in Australia and to redress the inequities and the difficulties faced by non-English speaking people and people of non-Anglo-Saxon culture. The Government wishes to replace this consultative body with an office within the Public Service which can never fulfil the democratic representation of our ethnic and Aboriginal communities-something which they now entirely lack. Along with abandoning consultation with multicultural Australia, the Government has abandoned its commitment to migrant education through cutting the English as a second language program. In the schools area, it has failed to implement the national language policy, which seeks to encourage and support multilingual education in Australia.

How can we export? How can we employ all these migrant people in Australia who may have difficulties with English unless we have a sensible program for educating them and allowing them to work effectively within our industry? There is no excuse for this type of behaviour. Where the Government has made changes to the taxation system, it has in fact simply fiddled with it. The fringe benefits tax is very much a fringe tax, despite all the noises made by the Opposition. It has caused an enormous amount of administrative disruption and it merely enforces something which the Liberals in government were quite unable and unwilling to enforce. The Governments's failure to provide self-government for the people of Canberra and its dismantling of the advisory Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, which is being replaced with a body appointed by the Minister for Territories, is leaving the people of Canberra with no elected input into the management of their affairs, leaving those in Canberra with a real problem. This was despite the promises which the Government made in the Governor-General's Speech at the start of this Parliament.

We could go on, as Senator Parer said, looking at the broken promises. We also have the major problem with the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill which passed through this Senate just recently, with the support of the Opposition. In this case the Government has raised the cost of freedom of information requests so much that it is practically impossible to get any information, particularly in the economic field where it is extremely useful for industry to be able to make requests. I just make the point that the people of Australia are in fact seeing our enterprises and our resources sold out to foreign conglomerates, our information sources sold out to corporate multimedia networks and our Government selling our birthright for a mess of potage, for funds for the next election campaign and for exposure in the commercial media. It is time that the Australian people elected an Australian Democrat government which is prepared to take a long view of Australia's needs. The Democrats have not and will not sell out their principles for media backing nor for corporate electoral financing.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are today debating a matter of public importance, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's broken promises and the continual failure of its inconsistent economic and industry policies which have caused uncertainty and confusion in the community leading to reductions in investment, employment and economic growth.

The Senate is indeed indebted to Senator Parer for bringing this very important matter before it. Since this Government came to office about three and a half years ago Australia has been hit with broken promises. It has seen an industrial policy that has caused confusion. It has seen inconsistencies in the business sector. It has seen taxation policies which not even members of the Government opposite can understand. The Government had to postpone the collection of the fringe benefits tax for two weeks. One would not know whether this was because it did not understand it or whether it was trying to dive for cover because an election in Queensland was coming up in another week. We have seen increases in sales tax on birdseed, icecream, milk and fruit juices. Anything that can move is taxed. That is the Australian Labor Party policy, both Federal and State: Anything that can be taxed is taxed. We have seen a tax on superannuation and a capital gains tax which incorporates a death duties tax. We have seen the assets test and the abolition of the tax deduction for entertainment expenses, which has just about abolished the restaurant industry. We have seen $440m ripped off the rural sector and now we have the fringe benefits tax, the tax to end all taxes.

The Labor Party is supporting the Australian Council of Trade Unions in an industrial claim on redundancy payments and on superannuation for the unions. All these things are taking away the people's ability to invest. We are locked into a spiral of inflation because of the ACTU-ALP deal on the accord. The fuel excise has risen from 6.1c a litre to 19.7c a litre. That is a massive increase of 336 per cent. This Government has become a taxing disaster area. It is a typical ALP approach to anything-if it moves tax it, and then tax it some more. Day after day we hear Senator Walsh in this House and the Treasurer, Mr Keating, in the other place trying to talk up the economy, answering carefully worded questions, dorothy dixers, telling people how wonderful the economy is. But Australians are not that simple-minded. We should look at some of the economic indicators to see how Australia is faring against our overseas competitors and at how the economy is performing.

Let us look at interest rates. I know that Senator Parer covered that matter, but let me go over the ground again. On the short term money market today in 90-day loans Australia rates at 17.4 per cent, the United States of America 5.6 per cent and Japan 4.7 per cent. As to housing interest in Australia the banks here are locked in at a rate of 13.5 per cent. But what is the Government doing for the hundreds of thousands of people who have borrowed money from housing corporations? Those interest rates have skyrocketed now to 15.5 per cent. The Government did hold bank interest rates at 13.5 per cent, but most people who borrow money from banks are reasonably well off.

Let us look at the position of the dollar overseas. It has been devalued by 36 per cent against the United States dollar, 58 per cent against the Japanese yen and 38 per cent against the trade weighted dollar. Inflation rates in Australia are running at 8.4 per cent; in the United States of America the figure is 1.7 per cent and in Japan 0.5 per cent. They are our trading partners. As to the cost of imported goods, we are bringing in $1.45 billion worth of goods compared with Australia's exports. Our purchasers exceed our sales by that figure. Anyone who runs a business or household will know that when one's sales are exceeded by one's purchases, one is bankrupt. Unfortunately, that is what is happening in Australia. Let us also look at external debt. From the beginning of the Commonwealth Parliament to the advent of the Hawke Government our external debt was $25 billion; from the Hawke Government to the present it has risen to $86 billion.

On any financial indicator the Hawke Government has been an economic disaster. It is a government that is caught between the extreme left faction and the right faction and the three or four factions in between. It is caught between implementing the right policies for Australia and what it is allowed to do by its ACTU bosses, and it can only survive in that environment. Australia is paying the price for that incompetence. There is no plan to encourage investment, to manufacture, to export, to create jobs. There are no policies to encourage employment. Who will invest in this country when interest rates are at a level that cannot be sustained, when faced with capital gains tax, redundancy payments and union controlled superannuation-of which the people out there are terrified. That figure will be not 3 per cent. The unions have said that that is only an initial ploy and the figure will be 6 per cent with a 6 per cent contribution from the employee. These matters are worrying small business and obviously the business sector out there.

Yesterday I was talking on the telephone to a friend in Queensland, a man who had recently sold a fairly significant business. I asked him what he was going to do with his money and where he intended to invest it. I asked whether he was going back into business. He summed it up for the whole of Australia. He said: `I would not put confederate money in anything when this Government is in power. I will put my money in the bank and when this Government is thrown out of office, I will reinvest when I can get a fair go'. I think that sums it up for the rest of Australia. That man is not going to invest his money while Labor is in charge, taxing him on everything that moves.

What is happening, as we gathered from Senator Cook's contribution to the debate and as we see every day at Question Time both here and in the other place, is that the Government, in seeking to divert attention from its miserable economic performance, attacks unmercifully the Queensland Government and the Tasmanian Liberal Government. Labor, to divert attention from its own miserable economic performance, has set itself up as a de facto opposition in Canberra. I can tell the people of Australia that Labor has enough economic problems on its own plate without worrying about Queensland or Tasmania. They are performing very well.

Every day questions are asked, and some by the honourable senator from South Australia who is next on the speakers list. He bowls up a ball every day to Senator Walsh. But let us look at South Australia's performance. In South Australia, where Senator Maguire was an economic guru, he has just about wrecked that State's economy and that State has had to send him to Canberra. South Australia has the highest unemployment rate in Australia; it has the lowest retail sales, well below the national average. It has the lowest labour force growth rate in Australia. I would say to Senator Maguire that a person does not have to be an economist to go and look up the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, because anyone can do that. I have done it and I have proved that South Australia is the worst economic performer in the Commonwealth of Australia.
