TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a motion by Senator Parer on economic management. I find the motion breathtaking. Whoever would have thought that the Liberal Party of Australia would move a motion in the Senate alleging that this Government had broken promises? Whoever would have thought that a Party that was in office for 23 consecutive years and then for almost eight consecutive years would introduce a motion today-after only 3 1/2 years of Labor Government-claiming that this Government had broken its promises. That is particularly so when such a motion is moved by a Queensland senator. It is absolutely breathtaking and hypocritical. Senator Parer in his motion alleges a `continual failure' of the Government's economic measures and industry policies.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at this so-called failure and the alleged broken promises. The Hawke Government's record on economic management is tremendous. The Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia must be jealous. Under this Government there has been a major lift in total employment in the community. Since the National Economic Summit was held in April 1983-just 3 1/2 years ago-the number of Australians in work has increased by 650,000. I am not talking about a figure of 60,000, I am talking about 650,000 extra jobs in 3 1/2 years. What was the Hawke Government's promise on employment in the March 1983 election? The promise was to create 500,000 extra jobs in three years. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) went around the country and told the Australian people that his Government would create half a million extra jobs in the first three years in office. What has it created? Not 500,000 extra jobs, but 650,000 jobs in 3 1/2 years. That is the record, that is the achievement and that is the so-called broken promise. As a candidate in that election, I recall the Liberal Party of Australia ridiculing that promise. The Liberals scoffed at that suggestion that half a million jobs would be created by the Labor Party in three years. As I have already pointed out those 500,000 jobs were created and created within three years of our coming to office. Despite the carping, the knocking and the sheer negativism from the Opposition benches, the great majority of those extra jobs were created in the private sector. They were not band-aid jobs or make work jobs; they were permanent jobs in the private sector of the Australian economy. Opposition members said that it could not be done. They scoffed at the idea. They scoffed because all they had to base their ideas on was their own experience in government. That was the basis for their ridiculing our promise. In the last year of the Fraser-Howard Liberal Government, when Mr Howard, the present Leader of the Opposition, was Treasurer of this country, 186,000 Australians were thrown out of work and on to the industrial scrapheap. That is the record.

I was a candidate in the 1975 election; so my memory is very long. I can recall Mr Fraser going around the country saying that there would be jobs for all who wanted to work. I remember that very clearly. He said that in 1975, yet in the last 12 months of his Administration, when Mr Howard was Treasurer, 186,000 Australians were thrown out of work. That is the record of the Liberal Party. As a result of that fall in employment in Australia, unemployment peaked at 10.4 per cent in 1983. We had double digit unemployment as a result of Liberal Party policies. Certainly and clearly there were not jobs for all those who wanted to work in Australia. The Liberal Party left Australia with a record post-war jobless tally. What about that broken promise, Senator Parer? What about the promise to create jobs for all those who wanted to work? Those are the facts; that is the Howard record and that is why the Liberals are now in opposition. Under Labor unemployment has been cut from 10.4 per cent in 1983 to 8.4 per cent now-a 2 per cent reduction in that period. That is, there has been a reduction of 95,000 in the numbers of unemployed in that period. I am prepared to say that 8.4 per cent unemployment is far too high, given the resources of this country. Personally I find it unacceptable and I want to see further reductions, but the point is that under this Government the unemployment rate has been reduced from the 10.4 per cent that we inherited to 8.4 per cent now.

The Liberals and the Nationals talk about broken promises so let us have a look at inflation and that particular promise. In seven years in office the Liberals talked about the horrors of double digit inflation. That was one of their slogans. Their policy, espoused around this country on various platforms, was `fight inflation first'. I remember that very well. It was a key Liberal policy. The community was told that sacrifices had to be made, belts had to be tightened and that there was no such thing as a free lunch. This was all done in the name of fighting inflation first. What was the Liberal Party's record? What was the record of Mr Howard when he was Treasurer? He left the Labor Party with 11 1/2 per cent inflation in 1983. We had double digit inflation and double digit unemployment as a result of the policies of Mr Howard. Therefore, the Liberals broke their fundamental promise to fight inflation first. I repeat: We had double digit inflation and double digit unemployment. What a record, what a double. No wonder the electorate hurled the Liberal Party from office in 1983.

Another great promise that was made by the Liberal Party was to reduce taxation. That was one of its major promises. I recall the 1977 election-the so-called `fistful of dollars' election-when a disgraceful, deceitful advertisement appeared, showing dollars to the electorate and suggesting that the Liberal Party in office would reduce taxation. What was the record of the Liberal Party of Australia on taxation? Let us look at some of the facts. When the Liberals left office the taxation system they bequeathed to the Australian Labor Party had a top marginal tax rate of 60c in the dollar. From 1 July next year the top marginal tax rate will be 49c in the dollar. The best that Mr Howard could do as Treasurer was to have the lowest marginal tax rate in the tax system at 30c in the dollar. Under Labor, from 1 December this year the lowest marginal tax rate will be 24c in the dollar.

Let us look at another aspect of taxation. The record of the Liberal Party in office between 1975 and 1983, as set out in the 1986 Budget Papers, is that the share of Australia's gross domestic product going in taxation was higher at the end of the Liberal's period in office than it was in the beginning. That is a fact which cannot be denied by those opposite. The taxation share of gross domestic product rose by 1.7 percentage points over the period in which Mr Howard was Treasurer. He did not reduce taxation.

I am surprised that Senator Parer, a senator from Queensland, has raisedthis matter this afternoon alleging broken promises on the part of this Government, specifically on economic matters, because his State's economy is on its knees; it is going backwards. That is due to broken promises of conservative governments in Queensland. It is the fault of the Liberal- National Party Administration up to 1983 and it is the fault of the National Party Government of Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen since 1983 that the Queensland economy is littered with broken promises.

Let us look at Sir Joh's 1983 policy speech, which I read today. It is very interesting reading indeed. In 1983 Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen said that he would `present policies for growth and jobs in the State'. He said:
We will give the style of leadership that generates business and investment confidence, a style which creates jobs and security . . . Now more than ever we must keep Queensland moving ahead.

That is what Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen said just three years ago, promising the earth to Queenslanders, promising economic miracles in his State. Regrettably, it was a mirage, a sad hoax on the Queensland labour force. Let us look at the reality, not the mythology of the National Party. The reality is the reverse. Queensland has not had development; it has had stagnation. In only three out of 36 months since Sir Joh's 1983 policy speech has the unemployment rate in Queensland been below the national average. When he delivered that policy speech in September 1983 Queensland accounted for 14.8 per cent of all of Australia's unemployed people. Today the figure is not 14.8 per cent, not 15.8 per cent, not 16.8 per cent, not 17.8 per cent; it is 18 per cent of Australia's unemployed. Eighteen per cent of all unemployed Australians now live in Queensland. That is the record of the Bjelke-Petersen Administration. Queensland is contributing more and more to Australia's total of unemployed. That increased share of unemployment is one barometer of the misery and despair facing more and more Queenslanders under the policies of the Bjelke-Petersen Government.

Sir Joh has not given the leadership that generates business and investment confidence as promised. Senator Parer should look to his own State for broken promises. He should look at the continual failure of Queensland's inconsistent economic and industry policies. As a result of that failure, on 1 November Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen will have a bigger and more extensive power failure than we had this afternoon in Canberra. I can say that all over Queensland the lights are going out for the National Party.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's broken promises and the continual failure of its inconsistent economic and industry policies which have caused uncertainty and confusion in the community leading to reductions in investment, employment and economic growth.

I say to Senator Maguire that if he wants reductions in unemployment in Australia, he should get his Government to adopt policies that will encourage investment and lower rates of interest, which will therefore encourage economic growth and, therefore, job creation, instead of the raft of anti-business policies that the Government has imposed which are the great destroyers of economic growth and employment in this country.

Coming back to the state of the economy today, despite the deliberate attempts by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to talk up the economy-I will come back to that later-the fact is that the Australian economy is facing its most serious prospects since the 1930s. It is facing this potentially disastrous situation fairly and squarely as a result of the policies of this Hawke Labor Government. What are the facts? For starters, inflation in Australia today is more than three times higher than the average of the rest of the Western world. The gap is widening because our inflation rate is increasing. Inflation in Australia today is running at an annual rate of some 10 per cent. In Japan and Germany it is near zero, in the United States of America it is some 3 per cent and in the United Kingdom it is about 5 per cent, so on prices we are becoming increasingly uncompetitive.

For the past 18 months we have compensated for the decline in basic competitiveness by a massive depreciation of the Australian dollar. But that can be only a short term palliative; it cannot continue indefinitely and it is not the solution to our problems. The only solution to our problems is to increase our productivity and to lower our unit labor costs. But our unit costs are not being lowered; they are rising. During the three years 1983 to 1985, the first three years of the Hawke Government, unit labour costs in the seven major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries rose by about one per cent per year. In Australia over the same period they rose by about 4 per cent per year. So much for the Hawke Government's totally false claims that the recent wage restraint in Australia has been as good as or better than most Western economies. The fact is that nominal wage growth in Australia has consistently outstripped that of our major trading partners during all the period of the Hawke Government and the Australian Labor Party-Australian Council of Trade Unions prices and incomes accords marks 1 and 2.

Along with rising inflation and wage costs we have rising unemployment. Unemployment is on the rise again. It is now 8 1/2 per cent and this is certain to continue as investment falls and gross domestic product declines. Australia has now had at least nine months of negative economic growth. The latest figures, when they come to hand for the most recent quarter, will almost certainly extend that negative economic growth to 12 months. Despite this, our foreign debt continues to spiral as our balance of payments on the current account continues to deteriorate. The Government tries to make a positive virtue out of the fact that last month the deficit in our overseas account was only $1.45 billion. On an annual basis, that is a deficit of $1,000 each year for every man, woman and child in Australia-and the Government says that it is encouraged by such an outcome! As a nation we are going into debt to the rest of the world at the rate of $40 million every day. That is more than $25,000 every second of every hour of every day of every week of every month.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a disgraceful legacy to give to our children.

—It is a legacy that will bankrupt not only our children but also our nation as a whole. Merely to service the overseas debt that we have now accumulated-that is a debt that is approaching $6,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia-takes up 40 per cent of every dollar that we earn in selling our goods and services overseas. Five years ago the corresponding figure was 8 per cent. This parlous state of affairs is due very largely to the policies of the Hawke Government. The Government cannot blame the declining commodity prices for the state into which it has led the Australian economy. Other countries have experienced reduced terms of trade and they have coped. They have coped because they have taken the necessary corrective action and made the necessary adjustments. This Hawke Labor Government has failed completely to take these measures. Instead, it has pursued economic policies of increased government spending, increased taxation and increased borrowings to their highest levels in our history. In the process, the Government has mounted a massive attack on the productive sector of our nation through the introduction of a whole raft of new taxes and charges on business which will destroy incentive and make almost impossible the task of accumulating capital for future investment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not only business which has been hit for six by these enormous tax increases. At least as hard hit have been average income earners. In that context I note that in 1984-85, the second year of the Hawke Government and the last year for which figures are available, although the number of taxpayers in Australia increased by only 4 per cent, the number of taxpayers in the middle tax bracket increased by 32 per cent and the number in the top bracket increased by 33 per cent. The effect of inflation on the tax bracket creep has been enormous in this country. But the most hard hit has been the single income family. Even if the so-called personal tax cuts of the Government take full effect next year-that is surely a dubious assumption-a single income family with a dependent spouse and children will be paying 20.5 per cent of its total income in tax compared with 17.5 per cent when the Fraser Government lost office in March 1983. To put it another way, that family would need to receive a further tax cut of $15 per week over and above what the Government has promised in order just to be as well off as it was in March 1983. That comparison makes no allowance for the huge increases in interest rates, including housing loan interest rates, or any of the other tax imposts of the Hawke Government, such as increased sales taxes and similar taxes and charges.

The Government has yet to deliver on its promised so-called income tax cuts this year and next year. I do not think that we should be holding our breaths waiting. Already the promise to introduce the first instalment of the cuts has been broken. The date promised was 1 September 1986. That promise was broken. The scheduled date is now 1 December. Let us see what happens to that date and to the second instalment date of July 1987. It will be no surprise to see these promises broken, too. The record of the Hawke Government is one long litany of broken promises. All Australians will recall Mr Hawke's solemn promise prior to the 1983 election. He said:
There will be no capital gains tax.
Soon after that a capital gains tax was introduced. Who will forget Mr Hawke's solemn promise before the 1984 election about Medicare? He said:
. . . and now I give this undertaking-that for the term of our next government the Medicare levy will not be increased.
He reaffirmed that promise as recently as February 1986. Lo and behold, the August 1986 Budget provided for a 25 per cent increase in the Medicare levy.

Another famous 1984 election promise from the Prime Minister was the so-called trilogy-namely, that over the next three years neither taxation nor expenditure would rise as a percentage of gross domestic product and that the deficit would fall in money terms. The taxation leg of that trilogy promise has been broken in each of the two Budgets since it was made and it appears that the expenditure leg of the promise may have been broken too in this latest Budget. What about the Government's promise not to reintroduce tertiary education fees? That promise has been broken too and so has its promise on uranium exports. On and on it goes. Australia is littered with the list of the Hawke Government's broken promises. These broken promises have destroyed the electorate's confidence in this Government.

There is a growing perception of a deceitful, leaderless government at a time when honesty and firm leadership is essential in Australia. But how can the Australian people and business have confidence in a government which treats its promises as leaves in the wind, to be blown away without a trace and without concern? How can the community have confidence in the morality of a government whose Treasurer claims and receives $17,000 in travelling allowances in one year alone by claiming that his principal place of residence is in Sydney when in fact it is in Canberra? The Treasurer collects this large, tax-free allowance, which is paid for by the taxpayers, at the same time as he is calling on Australians to tighten their belts.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was not entitled to it.

—Of course he was not. But not content with broken promises and shattered morality, the Prime Minister and his senior Ministers have embarked upon what appears to be a deliberate campaign to confuse the electorate, particularly the business sector, by conflicting standards, statements and actions. We had the Treasurer telling us on 9 May this year that the economy was in great shape and that 1986 would be a year `in which we will see consolidation of the very strong gains of the past three years'. Five days later, on 14 May, he made his now famous banana republic statement forecasting gloom and doom. Six days later, on 20 May, he proclaimed: `What we have is an entirely healthy economy'. Two months later, in July, he told the New York Times in an interview that Australia's economy was in `a perpetual and permanent deterioration'. Now he is back trying to talk the economy up-a highly dangerous course to take because it will raise entirely false expectations and we have all seen what can happen to governments and economies when that occurs.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from that, it just adds confusion and uncertainty to an already confused and uncertain business environment. The confusion is compounded by the obviously rubbery growth and other assumptions on which the 1986 Budget is based. One key assumption, domestic growth, was discarded or disowned by the Treasurer's principal economic adviser in recent days. The Budget strategy itself was virtually disowned by the Prime Minister, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button)-three of the most senior Ministers in the Government-only three weeks after it was brought down, when either they refused to guarantee the integrity of the Budget throughout 1986-87 or they actually foreshadowed changes to it in the course of the year.

One could give many similar examples of the broken promises and the confusion and uncertainty generated, seemingly almost deliberately, by this Government over a period-fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax and the like.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are trying to do the same thing in Queensland.

—I was just going to say that the Labor Party in Queensland is trying to beguile the Queensland electorate with similar promises to those made and broken by Labor in Canberra and by Labor in my State of Victoria over many years. In Queensland it is promising cheaper petrol, a freeze on taxes, relief for farmers and so on. All these promises are set against a background of Labor's increased taxes, higher petrol costs, cost slugs on farmers and deliberately high interest rate policies. Labor in Canberra has shown clearly that it cannot be trusted to keep its word. There is no doubt that the same would apply with a Labor government in Queensland as has happened in my State of Victoria with the Cain Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we should have been debating a genuine matter of public importance. I found it very interesting this afternoon to listen to the hypocrisy of Queensland senators and other senators putting forward a matter of public importance about the so-called broken promises of the Government and the continual failure of its inconsistent economic and industry policies which have caused uncertainty and confusion in the community, leading to reductions in investment, employment and economic growth. If Senator Parer and the Opposition were genuine in examining broken promises and failure of inconsistent economic and industry policy--

No amount of defensive distraction by Opposition senators can hide the economic realities which have so affected the lives of Queenslanders. Opposition senators are continually resisting any attempt to examine seriously the facts relating to the performance of the Queensland economy in comparison with that of other States. When one looks at the opinion poll that was published in the Bulletin today, it is not surprising that National Party of Australia senators are rather defensive.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some good news in the same edition of the Bulletin this morning. It was a report from the economics editor, John Edwards, who comments on the Australian economy. He reports on early signs that the economy is picking up. He says:

Retail sales are up, employment is up, exports are up, imports are up, the dollar is up and share prices are up-all signs that the Australian economy is strengthening and investors are more confident.

Yet in this place this afternoon Senator Parer wants to use up this very precious time which is set aside to debate genuine matters of public importance. Perhaps he had not had time to read this morning's Bulletin. He is only interested in bad mouthing the performance of this Government, and that is restricting confidence in the economy of this country. I think many people, both in Australia and overseas, are tired of the doom and gloom merchants on the Opposition benches. I would like to continue reading from the comments that were made by the economics editor of the Bulletin. He goes on:
It is always possible there is worse to come, but most of the evidence suggests otherwise.

I would like to emphasise that we on this side of the House are interested in the evidence and the facts. Senators on this side are continually frustrated in their attempts to put forward the facts as they relate to the Queensland economy. The economics editor of the Bulletin goes on:
Within six weeks upper income consumers will be enjoying useful tax cuts . . .
Obviously he does not share the pessimism of Senator Short. He says:

. . . upper income consumers will be enjoying useful tax cuts, the effect of depreciation will continue to stimulate export and import competing industry, interest rates have peaked and may trend downwards while growth in the United States, Germany and Japan is stronger now than it has been for six months.

Obviously there are people of considerable expertise in Australia who have faith in the Hawke Labor Government's economic strategy. We have heard from a number of senators on the other side of the chamber about this Government's tax policies. I would like to focus for a few moments on the Queensland Government's tax policies and compare them with those of the Federal Government. By national standards Queenslanders were taxed quite heavily. With hidden taxes plus declared taxes in 1985-86 every Queenslander is paying well over $705, while Western Australians pay $670 and South Australians pay only $625. Hidden State taxes on rail transportation of coal were almost $400m. Total revenue raised by the much opposed fringe benefits tax will be only just over $300m for the Commonwealth. The Bjelke-Petersen Government has been concealing a lot of its own tax income, and it is time that it was fully exposed to the voters of Queensland. The Federal Government's scheme to cut taxes by $4,600m in a year will begin on 1 December, and there will be a further tax cut, regardless of the pessimism of Senator Short, on 1 July next year. The combined effect will mean that for someone on average weekly earnings the tax reductions will be well in excess of $12 a week.

The other matter that does concern me is that when Queensland Opposition senators attack the Federal Government's economic performance they conveniently overlook the very favourable treatment that has been given them by the Hawke Labor Government. I would like to put again on the public record, because Opposition senators so conveniently try to disguise it, just some of the very important initiatives of this Government in regard to Queensland. First of all, Senator Boswell was boasting about the number of jobs created by the Queensland minority Government. But let us put that in perspective. Of these jobs that Senator Boswell was talking about, 19,000 jobs-that is worth about $184 million-came from the community employment program.

Let us look again at recurrent grants from the Federal Government. I have already stated before in this place that recurrent grants are the equivalent of $1,215 per capita. That is higher than what was given to New South Wales or Victoria in recurrent grants. Health care is $915 higher than for New South Wales and Victoria. Yet we still have Opposition senators trying to avoid the facts, trying to discredit this Government and trying to pretend that somehow in an election year in Queensland that Queensland has been mistreated in regard to its entitlements from the Federal Labor Government.

Let us look at Queensland's performance in regard to private fixed capital expenditure and look at some figures to see whether or not this matter of public importance that we are debating applies more to Queensland than it does to the Federal Government. The newly released Australian Bureau of Statistics figures on private investment show an expected pick up nationally for the 1986-87 financial year, but with Queensland remaining in the doldrums. Estimates of private new capital expenditure show that Australian investment will grow by 26.9 per cent in 1986-87 to $17.7 billion, but Queensland's growth rate will only be 2.9 per cent, the lowest of all States. To me that does not sound as if there is any need for the concern that has been put forward in Senator Parer's matter of public importance today. Queensland is expected to spend $2,370.6m in 1986-87 in private new capital expenditure-2.9 per cent higher than in 1985-86, but 11.4 per cent down on actual investment expenditure in 1984-85. I could go on with any number of figures relating to the abysmal economic performance of Queensland, but I would like to turn now to broken promises. It is a catchcry that we often hear in this place. I suppose that as a Queenslander I am in a very good position to talk about broken promises on the part of the Liberal Party of Australia. At this election we find that the leader, Sir William Knox, is going to the Queensland election campaign with a slogan `Trust us'. No-one could trust those two defecting Liberals, Austin and Lane, in 1983. I firmly believe that we cannot trust them again.

In conclusion, I would like to look at the statement about the uncertainty of investment, employment and economic growth. I wonder whether Opposition senators, particularly those from Queensland, have given any thought to the uncertainty of investment, employment and economic growth under the political patronage of a Mafia-style National Party Government. Nothing is less likely to encourage economic growth than the complex, corruptive system of political manipulation which exists in Queensland. In Queensland we find that private enterprise is so admired by the National Party Government, and so private that nobody knows anything about just what is going on behind closed doors. There is no Public Accounts Committee in Queensland. It is the only State in Australia not to have a Public Accounts Committee. There is so much behind the scenes manoeuvring with friends of the Queensland Premier and other senior Ministers, that private enterprise development is very much a matter of whom one knows and how much one is prepared to pay into the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation. In actual fact, the Queensland economy is the most politically controlled because the National Party Government contrives to reward only those who support it. Look at Sir Edward Lyons, Keith Williams, Sir Leslie Thiess and Barry Paul and now more recently Alan Bond in the Queensland economy. To what do they owe their particular personal success and wealth? Their success has resulted from the direct intervention of political figures to guarantee that their business enterprises get the nod from the Bjelke-Petersen Government. That may be good for those who can become millionaires, but it certainly is not good for Queensland and it certainly is not good for Queenslanders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance introduced by Senator Parer brings up the whole question of the economic management of this disastrous Government. There are many aspects to economic management. The Budget deficit, or perhaps more accurately the public sector borrowing requirement, is a key element of it. So too is the total level of Government expenditure and the total level of Government taxation. In both of these it is not only the total amount but also the type of taxation and the type of expenditure that matter-whether they promote equity, whether they encourage increased efficiency and whether they promote general well-being or only feed sectional or selfish interests. On all these counts this Government performs very badly. It is also the highest taxing government in our history. This year we have the highest level of taxation this country has ever seen and also the highest amount of spending. But even more serious is the essentially fraudulent nature of this year's Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer (Mr Keating) trumpeted a great deal about the deficit having been brought down to $3,500m; though why he should be so triumphant about that I cannot imagine for after four years of growth, financed by very heavy overseas borrowing, it seems an outrage that there should be any deficit at all. But this is merely one more sign of the total incompetence and mismanagement of this Government. But worse still, the deficit is a phoney. It has been achieved not by cutting expenditure, but by deferring tax cuts, transferring expenditure from one year to another, deferring payments and bringing in windfall profits from bodies such as the Reserve Bank of Australia. The real crunch will come in the Budget for next year when even the smallest amount of economic responsibility will force the Government not to have a higher deficit. The effects of these deferrals will mean that it has to cut $4,000m out of its expenditure which will be required to continue the services it is providing this year. That will be very painful indeed both for the Government and for the people of Australia. The problem with this Government is that it always acts too little and too late and ultimately the people as a whole pay the penalty.

Since the Hawke Government came to power we have been borrowing more than $1,000m a month or $32,000 a minute to maintain our current standard of living. There is no sign of this lessening. We are living recklessly beyond our means. Any responsible Government should be cutting down expenditure, holding down wages and encouraging productivity because improved productivity by our manufacturing sector is where our salvation lies. One of the two ways to improve productivity is to cut out restrictive work practices, which are the bane of Australian manufacturing industry. I will give just one example-loading containers on board a ship. In Melbourne, 12 containers are loaded in an hour. With identical equipment in Singapore the figure is 24, double the productivity. The figure in Japan is nearly 27. These are all imposts on the Australian people as a whole, and this example can be multiplied right across the Australian manufacturing and mining sectors. We must tackle these as a matter of urgency. We must also get more investment in plant and equipment. That has been declining while the Hawke Government has been in power. It is disastrous for our future. If we want to see why people are not investing we only have to look at interest rates. Our interest rates are much higher than those of any of our competitors, and in turn they are fuelled by an inflation rate which is four times that of most of our competitors.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Government is propping up the dollar.

—That is another factor, and both have to be tackled. What do we get for all this? There is not time to deal with all the problems, but I shall deal with one of them. The Treasurer, who has been recently assessed as being the second worst Treasurer in the world, responds to serious questions on the economy with abuse. I list a few of the words he uses: He describes questioners as harlots; stupid, foul mouthed grubs; sleazebags; a piece of criminal garbage; scum; and half-baked crims. I could go on. That is his method of replying to serious criticism. That may be all right in the New South Wales Labor Party-in fact it is par for the course-and it may be acceptable in the House of Representatives, and in fact the majority there seem to accept it, but I do not think it is appropriate behaviour for the Treasurer of a major nation. He does great harm to our international image and I believe he owes more to this country and this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This paper from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission is volume 4 of its report for the 1985-87 triennium and it contains the Commission's recommendations for 1987. It will come as no surprise to honourable senators to learn that six of the first seven paragraphs in this report deal with the fees the Government has imposed upon tertiary students in Australia and which it has chosen to call an administration charge. It is quite clear from what the Tertiary Education Commission has to say that there will be considerable difficulty with this charge. The Commission notes that the Government has decided to introduce an administration charge of $250 per student and to allow institutions to keep a little bit of that money. The Tertiary Education Commission, this Government's advisory body, draws attention to some of the issues of equity that will flow from the imposition of this charge, particularly in the advanced education sector and particularly in relation to part time students and students in certain faculties such as nursing and teacher training.

It is quite clear from this report and it is quite clear from the Government's announcements that universal free access to tertiary education in Australia is dead, and it has died under a Labor Government. It has died under Senator Ryan as the Minister for Education; it is dead by virtue of the action of the Hawke Labor Government. This $250 is in fact a fee. This Government is not even honest enough when it imposes a $250 charge to admit that it is imposing the first universal fee for those not covered by Austudy and other exemptions. The Minister has argued on many occasions that an administration charge is not a fee and by using this semantic trick she hopes to convince Australians that fees have not been introduced. I am a member of the Council of the Australian National University and I was present a few weeks ago when a building dedicated to the memory of Sir John Crawford was opened. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) performed that opening and I saw then-it was not a very edifying sight-the protests of the students at the Australian National University who booed and heckled the Prime Minister continuously because of the fees he has introduced. They have no doubt that fees have been introduced. When Senator Ryan went to Sydney University a few weeks ago she was left in no doubt as to what the students there thought.

I have looked up a book of synonyms, the Macquarie Thesaurus, to see whether I had this wrong. Under the entry for `cost' I found words of similar or equivalent meaning to include going price or entrance fee, so fees and charges are in fact the same kind of thing. The Government is using a trick because it is not honest enough to admit to Australia's tertiary students that it has gone down the road of imposing fees.

I must declare my interest as a member of the Council of the Australian National University. I represent this Parliament on that body. It is the intention of the Australian National University to obey the law, and if the law requires that students must pay an administration charge, whatever the Council thinks of it-and it does not think much of it-once it is enacted the Council will not attempt to do anything to circumvent the law, and the Council will expect the students attending the university to obey it.

It is quite clear that universal free access to tertiary education in Australia is now dead. In Question Time today Senator Ryan drew attention to the fact that even at Harvard University most students are subsidised by virtue of the substantial endowment which that university has. I put to the tertiary students of Australia that there is not much difference between Harvard University, where people pay these fees and enjoy some subsidy from endowments, and Australia, where they get some subsidy from the Government but are now required to pay a fee for part of their course. The difference is one of degree. It has been a policy and a promise of the Hawke Government that there would be no fees. This represents one further broken promise and further evidence of bad faith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am provoked to rise by Senator Peter Baume's intemperate and absurd comments about this issue of the administrative fee which has been imposed in respect of Australian tertiary students. The first point I make is that we have to recognise, and Australian students have to recognise, that this is one of the few countries, if not the only one, where tertiary education has been able to be described as free for many years. In spite of the payment of union fees and other fees which students pay, the fact of the matter is that this country has had a free tertiary education system. Of course the Opposition is committed to full fee charging in universities.
—How can you possibly say that? Where did you get that from?

—The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, has said that. Let us be quite clear about that. Senator Baume said that students in Australian universities get `some subsidy from government'. What is the subsidy given to medical students? He ought to know. It is about $36,000 a year. That is some subsidy from government all right. That is what medical students get, and it cannot be described as just `some subsidy from government'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has instituted what has been described, appropriately, as an administrative fee. It is a flat rate fee which is charged to students irrespective of the extent of government subsidy extended to them. It is rebatable in the hands of the more disadvantaged students in the Australian community-those who are recipients of the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance, or those who are genuine recipients of TEAS as distinct from others who are not in my view genuine recipients but swingers on the system, coming as many of them do from wealthy families.

TALK.START.PARA: —It discriminates against part timers.

—Well, that is another issue, which I will come to in a minute. Let me deal with the points that Senator Baume spoke about. I am not surprised that he cluttered up his speech by reading from the Macquarie Thesaurus about things that he ought to have known about years ago. That is a student debating trick. If he had a serious point to make, he would not resort to primitive student debating tricks-as does his cousin, who sits up the back. Of course, his cousin, Senator Michael Baume-Liberal, New South Wales; I must identify him-after all, is something of a professional debater outside the House as well as in it, so he is to be more pardoned--
—We won, even with you on our side.

—I have watched my back too. The fact is that Senator Peter Baume ought to know better than that. He is part of the Opposition which has publicly expressed views, through its Leader and others, about the re-introduction of tertiary fees as a whole. But Senator Peter Baume, because of some demonstration at the Australian National University, adopted a pious posture, saying: `At the ANU we will obey the law'. Good on him! Big deal, Senator Baume! Senator Peter Baume, Liberal, New South Wales, says that as a member of the Council of the ANU he will obey the law. It is a great thing for him to say in the legislative chamber of the Commonwealth of this country, that he will obey the law.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that students may be aggrieved in part by this fee. But for Senator Peter Baume to make a populist speech in here, trying to widen his ratbag constituency to include students, is a very reprehensible thing for a member of the Council of the ANU to do, and for somebody who takes himself seriously as an Opposition spokesman on tertiary education. Senator Baume said: `Free tertiary education is dead'. That is the expression he used.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite right.

—It is not right. Free tertiary education is not dead in this country. In the next breath, Senator Baume no doubt will be expounding the virtues of the Bond university on the Gold Coast, because that is related to incentives and all those things; that is probably a good thing too. The fact is that to say that free tertiary education is dead in Australia is a lot of bunkum. A whole range of things described as free in this country, including health care and so on, are not absolutely free in terms of administrative fees and charges. That was a very regrettable statement from a relatively senior Opposition spokesman in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission report to the Senate. I will begin by addressing some remarks to those remarks made by Senator Peter Baume. In looking at this report, it certainly struck me, as it did Senator Peter Baume, that a considerable amount of the very early part of the report is devoted to the Commission's concern about the introduction of the $250 fee. I agree with Senator Baume that it is a fee-there is no question about that-and I share the outrage that he has expressed and the concerns that are expressed about that in the report of the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take a little more time than Senator Baume did to outline some areas of concern that were addressed in the report under the headings of participation and equity, key elements of the Government's education policy. The report points out that there is likely to be a considerable impact on participation. It underlines a couple of areas-teacher education and nurse education. On the issue of equity, which is addressed here, one group that is particularly mentioned is single supporting parents. I have a particular concern for all of those groups because the vast majority of them are women. It has been notable that since free tertiary education was introduced in 1974 by a previous Labor Government, tertiary education not having been free under coalition governments before then, there has been a considerable advance in the numbers of women participating in post-secondary education. In 1975, 40.7 per cent of students at colleges of advanced education were women. In 1984 the figure was 46.8 per cent. DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON HUMAN EMBRYO EXPERIMENTATION BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 October, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate on the report of the Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 provides one of the most important ethical and moral dilemmas that have come before the Senate. The Committee's report proceeded from a proposed piece of legislation introduced by Senator Harradine. Honourable senators may recall that, when Senator Harradine's private member's Bill first came before the Senate, there appeared to be an almost unanimous view that that Bill should be taken straightaway to a Senate select committee for investigation and report. I think that I alone spoke against that course of action and indicated at the time that I believed Senator Harradine's Bill should have been proceeded with and defeated at the second reading stage. Nevertheless, the Committee was established, and I am glad to say that at least one of its recommendations is that Senator Harradine's Bill in its present form should not be proceeded with.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has drawn attention to a number of defects in that piece of legislation. It would appear-and one cannot speculate with any degree of accuracy-that Senator Harradine's Bill in its present form as a result will not come before this chamber but that, following consideration of the Committee's report, it is likely that at some future stage either a set of guidelines or a specific piece of legislation will be produced. When that happens, it will be capable of being debated in full in this chamber.

I have had the opportunity of reading the report and also of starting the journey of reading the transcript of the evidence presented to the Committee. I am full of admiration for the work of the Committee's members, the Chairman in particular, and for the amount of effort expended in analysing the issues that came before it. Having said that, one comes to the nub and heart of the matter. We are faced with a majority recommendation or majority viewpoint and with a dissenting report signed by two Committee members. It indicates what must be regarded as a fundamentally different approach to the way in which this question should be resolved. The senators who signed the minority report, Senators Crowley and Zakharov, essentially take a view about the human embryo which itself is fundamentally different from that taken by the majority of the Committee.

To the extent that I have read and understood the report, the transcript of evidence and the material which I have studied in advance of that, I find myself squarely in agreement with the minority report of Senators Crowley and Zakharov on this matter. To that extent I suppose that when the debate comes forward again there will be an opportunity to go into those items in more detail. In essence, it seems to me that the majority report has latched itself on to the fundamental principle that from the moment of fertilisation there does not then appear, between that point and the point of the birth of the child, to be a significant marker point which can be accorded so much weight as to believe that the status of the embryo is different prior to that point from what it is after that point.

As I understand the dissenting report, it takes a different view. The dissenters take the view that there is a point in that period from fertilisation to birth which allows a distinguishing judgment to be made, pre and post event. Upon that basis they believe that it is possible for certain things to be done or that it is legitimate that certain procedures should be carried out. That exact marker point is clearly a matter for debate. If one reads this report carefully and also other reports such as those of the Waller Committee on the Social and Legal Issues arising from In Vitro Fertilisation and the Warnock Committee and some of the other investigations that have taken place in other State jurisdictions, one realises that the matter has been approached differently by different committees in different countries in different time frame works and with different terms of reference given to the committees concerned.

In some respects this report by seven senators has come to a series of conclusions which do not necessarily agree entirely with the conclusions reached by other expert bodies, in particular the Warnock Committee in the United Kingdom. It is certainly true that the findings of this committee are much closer to those of the Waller Committee in Victoria than they are to those of the Warnock Committee. Nevertheless, there seems to be a series of recommendations and decisions made from committees which have approached this in essence as a purely scientific question, a medical question, and those that have tried to bring a more comprehensive ethical framework to the whole debate. Therefore it is important to realise that what we are focusing on is not just this particular issue, but the continual vexatious issue of values and value neutrality in science; whether it is possible to erect a series of scientifically neutral positions which do not indicate an ethical predisposition and do not have ethical consequences. Many scientists have argued for that, but that is not a view which I share.

I do not believe that science or the practice of science is ever ethically neutral. At this stage I do not need to try to canvass that huge philosophical argument which has bedevilled most of the great minds which have paid attention to this issue. They have not been able to resolve it. In my consideration of this document I have attempted to bring to bear a set of ethical values of my own. I cannot do anything else; I certainly cannot adopt someone else's ethical values or standards for this debate. I certainly cannot adopt any formula that has been laid down by somebody else-no matter how much I might otherwise agree with that person's general approach to things-and say that working within that framework I can answer the questions that this Committee report raises. I can only approach my own values in this matter, and they are coloured. They are coloured primarily from the point of view of a married person who has been through the misery, the agony, the pain and the distress of being part of one of these IVF programs. There is nothing more intrusive, more difficult, more embarrassing and more strenuous than the process through which a married couple go in terms of the tests, the results, the procedures and temperature taking and in terms of everything else that goes on in relation to these matters. Because I believe that for many people the processes of in vitro fertilisation are the last hope of their desperate desire for children and because within the extent of my own commitment and moral framework, I believe in the value of experimentation over and beyond that which the Committee has recommended, I have to conclude that my own position is in accordance with the minority position. That is because I know what it is to be desperate, hopeful and, at the end of the day, unsuccessful. Other people should not be put through that process if there is an alternative. I believe that the alternative which arises from the minority viewpoint on this matter is a viewpoint to be preferred. It is one that I will support and defend if necessary if legislation is introduced into this place which would attempt to prevent or limit that alternative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments on the notable report of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 which was introduced into the Senate a little over a year ago by Senator Harradine. I believe that that report has been a landmark report of the Senate. It is in keeping with the distinguished record that the Senate has developed over the last decade or more in tackling a variety of major problems-not simply political issues, but major social and ethical questions which do or may require a political solution. I am pleased that the Senate's approach to this matter has been on non-party lines and I hope that any further debate on this matter will remain so. We do not want this subject to become a party political issue. Nevertheless, it is a political issue in the sense that it can only be resolved by our political process and by the Parliament exercising its responsibility to deal on behalf of the community with matters which, hopefully in most cases, are resolved by individuals and families themselves. These basically moral issues are better resolved by individuals and families. However, there are clearly a number of such issues which require a political solution in the sense that there must be a public decision on behalf of the community in relation to some social and moral questions.

SPEECH.PARA: The first question that had to be faced was whether the in vitro fertilisation program, with all its connotations, particularly that of experimentation, was an appropriate matter for a public resolution rather than a private matter of individual conscience and behaviour. The only rules that exist at present in this area are those that have been laid down by medical ethics committees and particularly by the National Health and Medical Research Council's guidelines. I suppose that would come within the category of self regulation. Certainly the NHMRC is a prominent medical body, familiar not only with medical and scientific questions, but also with the ethical issues that arise. Certainly, there is a strong case to be made that issues of this kind should be resolved in that way by individual conscience, by medical ethics and no doubt by moral principles established by religious affiliation and religious bodies or by other institutions that assist people in making their moral decisions about individual conduct.

It became clear that the issues involved in the in vitro program were very wide and that was the reason which motivated Senator Harradine to bring forward his Human Embryo Experimentation Bill, which was not to regulate the in vitro program as such but to deal with the problem of experimentation on the embryos. He sought in his Bill to limit experimentation in a fairly severe manner, if I may say so, and proposed to prohibit certain types of experimentation with criminal penalties and so forth. The effort of Senator Harradine in bringing forward his Bill is to be highly commended. On behalf of a number of honourable senators I moved that the Bill should be referred to a Senate committee because I thought that was the best way of tackling the matter.

The report has certainly not disappointed me. In fact, I believe that it is one of the major reports that the Senate committee system has ever produced. The Chairman of that Committee, Senator Tate, and the members who served on it, including Senator Harradine, deserve high commendation and our gratitude for the great work they have done. I think that the report as a whole-I do not exclude the dissenting report-has pointed a way towards the solution of these very sensitive issues. Senator Puplick, who has just spoken and who has had personal experience of this matter, has highlighted the sensitive nature of this question.

However, like the abortion debate, this issue raises the question of when human life begins and how it should be dealt with from the time of fertilisation, long before there is an implantation in the womb and before there is a recognisable foetus. The question had to be faced of what form of protection is required or justified for the embryo. That has been answered unanimously by the Committee. The dissenting report has recognised that the embryo is distinct from other human tissue and should be accorded special regard. Although the members of the Committee may have put it in different ways, they were unanimous that here we are dealing with something unique, because it is a human embryo which has the potential for full development as a human being.

I commend the Committee for some of the suggestions it has made for resolving the problem. I believe that the problem requires legislation in broad terms. The Committee has not recommended against Senator Harradine's Bill, but that does not mean that there should not be some legislation. The Committee has suggested a form of legislation, preferably of a national kind. I believe that is appropriate. I hope that the legislation will not be draconian or too positively prohibitive of conduct, but will lay down guidelines, establish a monitoring body to ensure that the guidelines are observed and establish a licensing system of medical institutions to carry out these experiments. The Committee has adopted a distinction between some forms of experimentation which it calls therapeutic and those forms which are destructive of the embryo, simply for the purposes of unlimited scientific research. That is also a valuable contribution to the solution of these problems and to continuing further debate.

I believe that the Committee's notion of a guardianship principle in relation to the embryo is far more appropriate than the notion of property, which hitherto has been the approach that the law has taken on anything to do with this matter to date. I think it is more consistent with the normal legal approach, when dealing with children and married couples or those in de facto relationships, to have a notion of guardianship. As I have said, the Committee rejects the notion that these matters are the sole perogative of the medical profession; they require a resolution on behalf of the community as a whole. I believe that governments in Australia should now act on this Committee report. If they do not, I am quite sure that there are sufficient senators in this place who are deeply concerned about these matters, who believe that the Committee has pointed a way for their solution and who will be interested in proceeding further in a positive way broadly along the lines of the recommendations of this most valuable report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Audio-Visual Copying by Educational Institutions

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by Senator Colston:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second report on the agenda for discussion today is the report of the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts entitled `Audio-Visual Copying by Educational Institutions'. This report proceeds, like the previous one, from a motion moved by Senator Durack in this place. When we were discussing the question of copyright amendment, the issue arose as to whether some amendment of copyright law should be made to provide for educational institutions to be able to copy programs for educational purposes without breaching the Copyright Act. The Copyright Act is part of that complex framework of intellectual property which receives very little discussion in this place, but is a matter of some concern to some honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: For in excess of five years the Attorney-General's Department has been struggling with amendments to the Copyright Act to try to bring some sense into audio-visual copyright matters. It is perhaps not surprising that it took so long-I am not altogether sure how long the Franki Copyright Law Committee on Reprographic Reproduction inquiry took, but I suspect that it was considerably more than five years. That inquiry ended up producing a scheme which was very complex and largely unworkable in terms of the paper burden which was placed upon institutions to maintain the sorts of photocopying records which they have to at the moment.

Despite the best endeavours, on this occasion the Senate Committee was unable to come to very specific recommendations about audio-visual copying for educational institutions. In fact, at paragraph 2.21 and subsequent paragraphs the Committee recommends that the Senate should not proceed with the proposed amendments to the Copyright Amendment Bill 1986 which were in prospect in terms of finding some solution to this particular matter. The report notes that virtually all of the witnesses who came before the Committee agreed that educational institutions should be able to copy television programs for educational purposes. By and large there appeared to be a general presumption in favour of a statutory licensing scheme. It is interesting that the evidence presented to this Committee clearly indicated that the majority of programs that appear to be copied off air are copied for the purposes of time shifting; so that individual viewers can see the programs at a time which is more convenient to them. When this matter was investigated in the United Kingdom, the Department of Trade and Industry produced a White Paper entitled `Intellectual Property and Innovation', which was presented to Parliament in April this year. That Department indicated in its report that video recording was almost exclusively for time shifting. It said:
. . . not much of the material recorded is retained for repeated viewing and there is very little home copying of pre-recorded videograms.

It went on to indicate that as far as the United Kingdom Government was concerned, it had no plans to introduce a levy on blank video tapes but in respect of blank recording tapes there was no realistic alternative to a compulsory levy. Representations have been made by bodies such as the Australian Record Industry Association Ltd claiming that there is only one way in which there will be any protection of its proprietorial interests in audio material copied for educational purposes. After all, a large number of programs are now broadcast on radio which are of very great educational significance. One thinks, for instance, of Robin Williams's programs. Frankly, in a large number of science courses that I know of in high schools throughout Australia, students would get a far better education, as far as scientific matters are concerned, if they spent more of their time in the classroom listening to Saturday's broadcast of The Science Show than they would reading some of the textbook material that is currently churned out, which very often is quite out of date and quite misleading. I think, therefore, that the claims made by people for the imposition of a levy on some blank tape, particularly that which is used in the audio section that this report deals with, are entirely justified.

The report is important in drawing attention to an interpretation of section 200 (2) of the Copyright Act, which section had not previously been brought to my attention. That was the belief that the protection afforded by section 200 (2) appears to allow educational institutions to copy radio programs intended for educational purposes but seems to have minimal application for the copying of educational television programs. To that extent the recommendation in the Committee's report that section 200 (2) be looked at as an area for potential amendment, so as to make clear that the protection that that currently extends to radio broadcasts of an educational nature should also be extended to television broadcasts of an educational nature seems to me to be a very sound recommendation.

However, the report indicates not only the complexity of the task which was given to the Committee but also it draws attention once again to the extreme slowness of the Attorney-General's Department in pursuing this matter. It was quite evident when Senator Gareth Evans was Attorney-General that a far higher priority was given to copyright issues, under his stewardship of that portfolio, than is the case at the moment. For instance, Senator Evans, in an address which he gave to the Copyright Society of Australia and the Australian Communications Law Association in Sydney on 11 November 1983, said:
. . . I do see considerable attractions in the proposal for a royalty on blank audio tapes as a trade-off for removing the existing legal restrictions on non-commercial home taping.

Although this very largely relates to the question of the taping of entertainment programs rather than educational programs, the point is precisely the same. It is impossible to sort them out. Everybody knows that, these days with the prices of records as high as they are and the prices of compact discs as high as they are, the majority of young people have no particular aversion to purchasing the latest LP and all their friends supplying them with blank tapes that cost either $2.99 or $5.99; the record is then mass produced and distributed, with, of course, consequent losses to the industry and consequent losses to the intellectual property of the artist concerned.

As I have said, the Senate Committee report is, therefore, a very useful one. It is useful, firstly, in saying: `It is altogether too hard for us to come to grips with this problem right at the moment but, nevertheless, here are some general directions which ought to be pursued. Section 200 (2) needs to be addressed; the proposed amendments to the copyright legislation should not be proceeded with in the form in which they were previously being discussed in the Senate, and some sort of impetus should be given to the Attorney-General's Department to try to conclude a very lengthy study on audio-visual copyright which has been under way for some time'. Although the United Kingdom report entitled `Intellectual Property and Innovation', to which I have referred, suggests some different approaches, I believe that we would now be well served by putting this Senate Committee report together with the eventual recommendations from the Attorney-General's Department and the white and green papers that have been produced by the United Kingdom Department of Trade and Industry in trying to resolve some of these questions and to give a proper legislative underpinning to advances in technology which have outstripped the protections provided to the owners of intellectual property under existing copyright law in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts inquiry into Audio-Visual Copying by Educational Institutions and the reference to it of the amendments to the Copyright Act are very good examples of the Senate's inaction and of the benefits of a more considered inquiry into legislation that comes before us. The Copyright Act is a very technical matter. The amendment that was before the Senate during the last session of Parliament sought to facilitate in our schools and other educational institutions the ability to use broadcast material for sound and useful education purposes. Whilst the intention of the amendment was clear, it was difficult to achieve a workable amendment to the Act that was fair to all the considerations and principles involved in copyright. It was difficult to achieve this amendment not only on the run but also in the preparation of its drafting. By referral this difficult matter to the Senate Committee, we were able to look at the various questions concerned and to bring down this valuable report of four or five chapters. I was very happy to be involved in this inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Puplick said earlier, we have moved from the printed page days to the radio days, to the television days and to a profusion of video machines, into the current era of the compact disc. The ability to so transcribe material and to have information stored that can then be used, particularly in the context of this debate, for educational purposes, is, to use a cliche, light years away from the educational provision of our parents and even our own primary school days.

The Copyright Act, as it is presently set out in its various sections, really relates to the emergence of radio and its use in the classroom. An educational program, broadcast particularly by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, could be slotted into a school's curriculum or its program with prepared material that would widen the scope of education and give a new medium of attention for the children, and a lot would be learned. So we would have, as it were, education on the air. The Copyright Act is limited because it does not really visualise any communication for educational purposes beyond radio. Accordingly, in the critical area, section 200 of the Act, there is no reference to film; there is no reference to any method other than the broadcasting of sound. That remains very useful, particularly for music that is broadcast and radio programs such as the science broadcasts of the ABC. In schools, colleges of advanced education and other educational institutions it is television material for which there is even more scope for useful, valuable and educational programs.

The fact that we had an amendment to the Copyright Act before the Parliament gave us room to try to bring the 1950s legislation up to date to take account of television, video machines and the like. But it cannot be done quickly. The nearest we came to seeing a solution was to change two parts of the Act. First of all, in section 10 of the Act, in which definitions are set out, the definition of `record' could be widened to include a cinematographic film, that is, something that is beyond what is on a tape recording of sound. If we extended the definition of `record' to include visual images and then in section 200 explicitly added the term `cinematographic film', it is possible that we would have extended the original 1950s concept to allow what was then intended for radio in schools to be applied to television. Such are the technicalities of copyright that even that is in doubt.

Film copyright subsists in the person who wrote the script, the persons who directed and produced the film, the performers in the film, the person who wrote the music and the persons who performed the music which is interspersed in most films, the package owner of the eventual product, and then there is a copyright in the company that is transmitting that material. When one is seeking a right, even for a good educational purpose, to rebroadcast or reproject that film, technically, the rebroadcaster, even a junior teacher in a school, would need to contact those five or six layers of copyright owners to get their permission. By a strict or even a straightforward reading of the Copyright Act, it is unlawful for a teacher to rebroadcast without that explicit permission. In the case of radio broadcasts for educational purposes simpler layers of copyright are involved. Broadcasts are put together with the knowledge that the Copyright Act will enable a bona fide educational institution to take that material and rebroadcast it without any legal limitations.

When we looked at the wider perspective of what is happening in practice at the moment in our schools and domestically, we found that an enormous amount of illegal copying is going on and that a practice has developed whereby--

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't do that, would you?

—None of us is happy that a proper reward is not going to the copyright owners. I believe, as does Senator Puplick and I think all the Senate-I have not heard anyone dispute the principle-that we ought to reward copyright owners for two main reasons: Firstly, for all the creativity and hard work that has gone into producing the material and, secondly, as an incentive for others to be creative in the future, to let them see that there is a reward and that it is worth producing something a little better so that it can be recognised and there can be proper compensation. There is a reward aspect and an incentive aspect to rewarding copyright holders.

SPEECH.PARA: In practice, whether at school or in the home, unlawfully many of us tape on our videos that evening's Olympic Games broadcast, for example. The answer to this lies in the conclusions of the Senate Committee's report; that is, we must see this question within the context of a solution for all the considerations of copying for rebroadcast. I wholeheartedly support the conclusions that we have reached. We call for the Attorney-General's Department's negotiations with the industry to be concluded much more quickly than has been the track record to this point. We hope that by the first day of the new year, 1 January 1987, we may have before us a solution that can then be placed in legislative form within the Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank those honourable senators who contributed to the debate. Senator Newman contributed on the day on which the report was presented. I thank Senator Puplick for his remarks. Towards the end of his speech he put forward some ideas which I think should be taken up by the Attorney-General's Department, with all the various types of reports and papers that have been presented, to present some form of legislation which we may look at next year. I take this opportunity to thank the members of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts for their assistance during the time that we had to look at this problem. The reference was given to the Committee with a deadline on it of some time in August. Because that particular day turned out not to be a sitting day, we had the time extended for a short period. The reference that we had was fascinating. I think some of us felt a bit out of our depth at some stages because none of us were lawyers.
—Senator Newman is.

—I am corrected; one of us was a lawyer. We probably had some advantages in that we were able to look at the matter with the eye of the ordinary person who does not have legal experience. At some stages we thought that we were starting to understand copyright law. That was a little time ago, and I would not like to say that I still understand it. I thank the Committee members because a deadline was placed upon us and we virtually met it. With the help of the Committee staff, I think we brought down a comprehensive report. I also thank all those individuals and representatives of organisations who appeared before the Committee. Without their assistance we would not have been able to bring down the report.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I mention two recommendations in the report. The first was that the Senate not proceed with the proposed amendment which was placed before us. Reasons for that are given in the report, and I think they have been well understood. The second recommendation is perhaps the more important one. We as a committee believed that the issue had been around for too long without a solution. We are recommending that concerted efforts be made to bring forward legislation which will cover audio-visual copying, not only for educational purposes but also for other purposes, and hopefully we will have this in the new year. The recommendation reads:

The Committee recommends that the Attorney-General's Department, taking into account the Committee's findings, should develop its proposal for a statutory licensing scheme for the educational copying of audio-visual material to the stage where the necessary audio-visual material to the stage where the necessary legislation may be introduced for Parliament's consideration in the 1987 Autumn sittings of the Parliament.

I commend that to the Attorney-General's Department. While commending it to the Attorney-General's Department, I also suggest that the proposals put forward by Senator Puplick should be taken into account. I am hopeful that honourable senators will be looking forward to legislation of this type being introduced early in the new year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
