DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of my colleague Senator Tate, I present the sixteenth report of 1986 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills concerning the Health Legislation Amendment Bill, Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill and Students Assistance Amendment Bill. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 16, dated 22 October 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 257th report of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-There are few countries in the world today as free of serious pests and diseases as Australia. High quarantine standards are maintained to safeguard Australia from the impact of the introduction of exotic diseases of humans, animals and plants. The cost of providing quarantine services in 1984-85 was approximately $36m. This report of the Public Accounts Committee outlines the findings of the Committee's inquiry into the `Report of the Auditor-General on an Efficiency Audit-Administration of Quarantine Services'. The audit was undertaken in 1985 to review the effectiveness of the administration of quarantine functions by the departments of Primary Industry and Health and controls exercised by those departments over State Government agencies performing quarantine activities on the Commonwealth's behalf.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General, in reviewing the effectiveness of the administration of quarantine functions by the departments of Primary Industry and Health, disclosed that whilst the administering departments recognised the changing nature of quarantine control, there were, nevertheless, a number of areas where there was scope for improvement. The more important findings of the audit included: The lack of formalised management information systems to assess the cost of operations and to monitor the effectiveness of activities undertaken by the States on the Commonwealth's behalf; a low overall level of cost recovery; the absence of a formal agreement between the Commonwealth and the States; the need for a comprehensive evaluation of all aspects of the clearance of aircraft and passengers arriving in Australia; and the need to re-assess the role of coastal surveillance.

The Committee, in its review of the management and organisational aspects of quarantine, noted that many of the Auditor-General's criticisms of the administering departments' operating procedures had been addressed. The Committee also noted that significant improvements in the administration of quarantine services had already been achieved. Nevertheless, the inquiry identified a number of areas that still required attention and the Committee made 23 recommendations for action by the responsible departments. These recommendations addressed the following major issues: The formalisation of a Commonwealth-State agreement on administrative arrangements for quarantine; the integration of animal and plant quarantine functions; the requirement for a basic level of education for quarantine officers such as a technical and further education certificate and the establishment of ongoing training programs; the annual revision of fee schedules and the monitoring of operational costs of all waste disposal sites to ensure maximisation of cost recovery; and quarantine procedures relating to international aircraft arrivals.

The Committee expressed particular concern about the length of time taken to get a formalised agreement between the Commonwealth and the States. The agreement is still in draft form, despite the Department of Health being advised as long ago as 1973 that a formal arrangement would be legally desirable. The Department of Primary Industry is now conducting negotiations with the States and the Committee would like to see these finalised at the earliest opportunity.

Another area of concern was the lack of a formalised management information system that would allow the Commonwealth to assess the cost of operations undertaken by the States on the Commonwealth's behalf and the effectiveness of such operations. The Committee has recommended that the Department of Primary Industry develop a proposal for computer systems, giving early consideration to compatibility with systems already in place in the States, thereby enabling satisfactory data transfer. The Committee would wish to see prompt action in particular on these issues. I commend the report to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: KAKADU NATIONAL PARK PLAN OF MANAGEMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 October, on motion by Senator Collard:
That the Kakadu National Park Plan of Management, prepared under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, and laid before the Senate on 18 September 1986, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some days ago we were debating the Government's plan for the Kakadu National Park. I spoke very briefly on the matter. I wish to speak only briefly on it tonight. I think it is worth while to bring forth one or two points. The Australian Democrats give guarded support to the Kakadu plan of management because the Government's plan does attempt to prohibit mining on stages 1 and 2 of the park. The Government's plan attempts to do this because the Government has not even been able to get rid of all mining in stage 1. We have the Ranger mine operating there and the Jabiluka prospect is still going. But even on stage 2 the Government has not been able to stop exploration.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen the confrontation between the Government and Peko-Wallsend Ltd. This company is persisting in pursuing its lease to explore in stage 2 of the park. It is on record as saying that exploring and mining are inseparably linked and that it is going to push the Government to the limit to get its way. Going on the record of Peko-Wallsend, we have no doubt that this uncompromising company will push the Government to the limit. The Peko-Wallsend company brought up the Robe River dispute. Last week it sacked 500 employees at its Besco Batteries plant in Sydney with half an hour's notice.

The crux of the matter is: Does an exploration right also cover a mining right? If a company finds minerals, can the Government then stop it mining them? The legal position, to say the least, is uncertain and the Government has not moved to dispel this uncertainty. With complete disregard for the problems of separating exploration rights from mining rights, the Government plans to amend the Foreign Takeovers Act to allow foreign companies to take over exploration leases without seeking Government approval. We are told and we are supposed to believe that this is not going to weaken the foreign investment rules because the Government says it will be able to refuse rights to mine if it feels that this is in the national interest or if these rights are threatened in any way. Of course the Peko dispute throws this question wide open. So far the Government has refused to recognise this. I asked a question of Senator Evans just the other day and he said that the problems at Kakadu and other places around Australia are not necessarily connected. So it is in a very guarded way that the Democrats are prepared to support the Government's plan of management for Kakadu. At least it does try to do something in stages 1 and 2.

Of course the Government has been incredibly weak-kneed over the whole uranium issue. On its record it cannot be trusted to make any firm commitment at all to uranium mining or to the protection of national parks. We saw the present Opposition allow the Roxby Downs project to go ahead and two Labor governments have supported that. That was a complete about face of Government policy. In the recent Budget the Government gave the green light to the exporting of uranium to France, despite the expressed wishes of its members and despite resolutions to the contrary carried by the Australian Labor Party Federal Conference. We know that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has favoured mining in the Kakadu National Park and only pulled away from that because of the furore it created within the Labor Party and the labour movement generally. So we wait to see what in fact does happen. We are very concerned that the Kakadu National Park is at risk. Senator Evans made his views on stage 3 very clear. He said that it is clapped-out buffalo country-a fairly emotive sort of comment which captured people's imagination, but the implication is quite clear. This Government is not concerned at all about stage 3. The fact that it is clapped-out buffalo country does not really matter too much because experience in other areas has shown that if buffalo numbers are restricted the country does regenerate very quickly. However, stages 1 and 2 are subject to some sort of protection at the moment and that must be a step in the right direction.

The whole campaign to open up Kakadu National Park to mining is an intensely political one. The Opposition, the Northern Territory Government and the mining industries are combining to gain mining access to national parks nationwide, not only Kakadu. We have been told that Kakadu is a national treasure chest that the conservationists are trying to lock away for their own selfish ends. However, the truth is far from that. Maps produced by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service show that up to 80 per cent of the mineralisation in the Kakadu area is outside the Park-that is, outside stages 1, 2 and 3. So there are many good prospects outside the park for the mining interests to exploit.

Everyone who has some interest in the region is throwing figures around on the value of the minerals in the park. The truth is that most of these figures are fanciful in the extreme. Most relate to mining deposits. For example, we have seen estimates that the value of the minerals in the park could be as high as $34 billion. However, if we add up the published figures we see that the value of the uranium deposits in the area amounts to $33.6 billion. So the vast majority of the supposed mineral wealth in the park is in fact uranium, and half of that wealth has already been mined. The rest is doubtful as a commercial proposition simply because of the calamitous state of the uranium market at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must have a good accountant running your business interests.

—If the honourable senator bothered to look at the National Parks and Wildlife Service maps showing where the mineralisation is, what I have said would be clear. I suggest that Senator Collard has not bothered to do so. We are seeing an orchestrated campaign to open up our national parks, not just Kakadu, to economic exploitation of all types. It is in the vital interests of future generations of this country for us to resist with every breath in our bodies the further exploitation of our wilderness areas.

SPEECH.PARA: We must preserve Kakadu and keep our national parks intact for future generations. As far as the Democrats are concerned that is the challenge in front of us. We are disappointed that the Government has not adopted a stronger attitude to uranium mining in general and to the Kakadu National Park in particular, and are disappointed that it has not made its position clear on exploration and mining rights, so whether it will contest the legality of the separation of those two sets of rights remains to be seen. We are fearful that the Government, as on so many other occasions, will go to water in this critical area but at least in the meantime we do have a plan of management for Kakadu which does give some measure of protection from mining at least in stages 1 and 2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by Senator Collard on behalf of the Opposition to disallow the new plan of management for Kakadu National Park which was tabled in the Senate by the Government on 18 September last. No doubt the Senate will recall that that was as a result of a somewhat precipitate decision taken by the Government two days earlier, early on the morning of 16 September, in order to stave off the revolt looming in Caucus about the development of this plan of management by the Government. Up until that time the Government seemed as though it was exploring the possibility of multiple land use being ordained in this new plan of management. Caucus reaction was very violent when a letter to that effect from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was referred to in the Canberra Times on the Sunday of the weekend preceding the decision. As has happened in the past, the Prime Minister completely went to water and was not prepared to stand up to Caucus and support the views which he undoubtedly held himself and which were clearly held by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans.

SPEECH.PARA: We now have this new plan of management and, in accordance with the decision of the Government and Caucus of 16 September, it prevents any exploration or mining for minerals taking place in a region covering 13,000 square kilometres of the Northern Territory-indeed 13,000 square kilometres of Australia. That area is placed completely out of bounds to the mining industry, except in respect of certain mineral leases that are in existence and preserved and protected under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. It is in respect of those areas that the Geopeko company has been doing some further work recently which has been the subject of some notoriety. Certainly the full legal status of its mineral leases is a matter for the courts to decide, if necessary, but clearly it has some rights there and those rights are protected under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. The Opposition is concerned-and I believe the Senate should be concerned as I am sure Australians generally are concerned-about the decision of this Government to lock up, to declare out of bounds, this huge area of Australia from any proper exploration or even assessment of its full mineral potential. It was a decision taken in an emotional atmosphere at the time, without any proper regard being paid by the Government or the Caucus to this most vital question. In the debate that has been conducted for some time already in the Senate on this issue, those who support the present plan of management-this includes Government senators and the Australian Democrats, of which Senator Siddons is a member; he has just resumed his seat-made a number of points, some of which I wish to deal with.

One of the points which was made strongly by the Democrats, and by Senator Richardson, who spoke in support of the present plan of management on behalf of the Government, was that we have to preserve the environment at all costs. Presumably, we have to keep it, and in particular the part which is of great significance, in its absolutely pristine state. As Senator Collard made quite clear, the Opposition believes that there are certain areas within the 13,000 square kilometres, particularly in the original stage 1 which is about 6,000 square kilometres, that are of great significance and which we in government would want to see preserved in their pristine state as far as possible. Those areas cover the escarpment, the Arnhem Land plateau, the wetlands which are the habitat for many species of bird life, the tidal flats and the rock art galleries, which of course we can all see, recognise and value as remarkable examples of Aboriginal rock art. The mining industry does not suggest for one minute that those areas should be mined or explored. Those areas should certainly be preserved in their pristine state and protected under a plan of management by the park's administration.

What we are concerned about is that a great deal of this area is certainly not in a pristine state because it has been occupied by Aborigines for probably 25,000 or 30,000 years. The Aborigines pursued policies of land management, particularly by fire. That sort of usage does change the land. Indeed, land is always changing. This land will change even as a national park, simply because of tourists being in the area. So, although those areas that I have mentioned must be preserved, there are other large areas, particularly in stage 2, which is the one more recently proclaimed and an area of about 6,000 or 7,000 square kilometres, which do not fall within that category. Only about one-quarter or at the most one-third would come within the category of requiring full preservation in a pristine state.

I will quote from the report of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry by Mr Justice Fox, a report which was dealt with and acted on by the Fraser Government. Mr Justice Fox describes the main natural features of the region. He talks about the plateau, the flood plains, the tidal flats-areas of great environmental significance, apart from the areas of Aboriginal sacred sites, rock art galleries and so on. The Fox report describes what is, as I have said, about at least two-thirds of the area we are debating. That area is called the lowlands. The report states:

The lowlands are somewhat monotonous scenically. Most parts are undulating, and there are low hills and ridges. Most of the soils are sandy or loamy, and are highly susceptible to erosion if disturbed. A few have a cover of gravel or rocks which protects them from erosion. The lowland vegetation is mostly open eucalypt forest or woodland, or scrub. Tall grasses, reaching heights of 2 metres or more in the wet season, are the main ground cover over large areas. Fire passes through much of the lowlands each dry season, and most of the vegetation is adapted to regular burning.

As I have said, that has continued for thousands of years. So probably two-thirds of the area covered by this plan of management, particularly the 7,000 square kilometres of stage 2, is being denied for mining exploration and assessment; it is being denied for mining altogether. There is nothing unique about that sort of country. One can easily see from that description that it is very common sort of country around Australia. To lock out the mining industry, to prevent it from even finding out what the mineral wealth is, is in our opinion quite absurd. The plan of management does just that. Because of all the government inquiries and decisions that have been made over the last 15 years, the mining industry has not been able fully to explore the region to discover the mineral potential. It had started to do so in the late 1960s and early 1970s. It discovered the major uranium province in that area, now being mined at the Ranger mine, and great uranium mineral deposits which are now being prevented by this Government from being mined simply because uranium is involved; it has nothing to do with the national park.
When this plan of management was being developed, the Department of Resources and Energy wrote to Professor Ovington on 18 July 1986. The letter states:
The BMR-
that is, the Bureau of Mineral Resources-

has identified the Kakadu region as one of the most promising areas of mineralisation in the world. There is no recognition of this in the Plan nor any discussion or attempt to resolve the land management questions involved. We believe the approach adopted at pages 112 and 113 of the Plan dealing with operations for the recovery of minerals is superficial in its discussion of this issue, and . . . unlikely to lead to any successful long term resolution of these undoubtedly difficult issues.
It also states:
In our view provisions similar to those in the first Plan would be adequate for this purpose and we would wish to see these reinstated.

That sums up entirely the position of the Opposition in this matter. We believe that there must be the opportunity for full assessment by the mining industry of this already highly pros- pective region in which, as I have said, there have already been discovered three major uranium deposits, one of which is Ranger. That view was totally ignored by Professor Ovington and ultimately by the Government. It is strange that not only was that the view of the Department of Resources and Energy as expressed in that letter; it was the view expressed by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Evans, on 8 September, just a week before the Government made this most unfortunate decision, in a letter to Mr Copeman, Chief Executive of Peko-Wallsend Ltd. In that letter the Minister said:

My Department has provided comments on the proposed Plan to the Director, National Parks and Wildlife which, among other things, seek inclusion in the Plan of provisions for operations for the recovery of minerals similar to those in the first plan . . .

You can be assured that I am following these issues carefully with the long term objective of establishing a multiple land use policy in the Region which balances the interests of the mining industry with those of other land users.
I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard that letter from Senator Gareth Evans to Mr Copeman.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
MINISTER FOR RESOURCES AND ENERGY
PARLIAMENT HOUSE
CANBERRA A.C.T. 2600
8 September 1986
Mr A. C. Copeman
Chief Executive
Peko-Wallsend Ltd
Box R211
P.O. Royal Exchange
SYDNEY, N.S.W. 2000
Dear Mr Copeman,
Thank you for your letters of 5 May and 4 July 1986 concerning mineral activity in the Kakadu Region.

I am conscious of the concern in the mining industry over future land use proposals in the Kakadu Region, including proposals for a new Plan of Management for the Park, World Heritage listing of Stage 2 and possible extensions to the Park.

My Department has provided comments on the proposed Plan to the Director, National Parks and Wildlife which, among other things, seek inclusion in the Plan of provisions for operations for the recovery of minerals similar to those in the first Plan. I have also written to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment indicating that I support this approach.

Although you have not directly referred in your letters to the World Heritage listing of Stage 2, I understand this matter is also of concern to you. It is my view, which I have again conveyed to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, that it would be premature to pursue the World Heritage listing of Kakadu Stage 2 until related questions about mineral activity in the Kakadu Region have been addressed by the Commonwealth.

You can be assured that I am following these issues carefully with the long term objective of establishing a multiple land use policy in the Region which balances the interests of the mining industry with those of other land users.
Yours sincerely,
GARETH EVANS

TALK.START.PARA: —That view, we know, was being supported by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It led to this outrage, particularly by the left wing of the Australian Labor Party's Caucus, which the Prime Minister would not stand up to. He changed the policy overnight because we can see from that letter the view of Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Resources and Energy, only a week before this rash and foolish decision was made by the Government. The Opposition supports the concept that there must be an opportunity for at least a full assessment of this area by the mining industry. Such an assessment has never been made. We have heard Labor senators speaking in here today. We have heard Professor Ovington indicating before Senate committees that there are not any great mineral prospects in that area. That is totally contradicted by the submission from the Department of Resources and Energy, from which I have just read. Of course, the suggestion that only a small proportion of this area is suitable for mineral prospectivity is completely refuted by the fact that there are these major mineral and uranium deposits which I have already mentioned, although they have been excised from the existing park. No doubt there are others to be found. Geopeko Mineral Exploration has already found a highly prospective area within stage 2, this lowland area of little environmental significance, which the company has not been able to fully explore but which it has already estimated could contain uranium worth $200m.

SPEECH.PARA: This plan of management that we are dealing with ignores all this. It differs markedly from the first plan of management, which operated until December 1985 when it expired. That plan of management, which was adopted by the Fraser Government, recognised in detail the economic and geological significance of this area. The plan contained extensive provisions for mining operations to be conducted in this area. That is what we believe should have been retained in the present plan. Indeed, the same proposition was put by the Department of Resources and Energy in the quotation which I read. Clearly there is a growing understanding of the multiple land use concept, except in relation to areas of great sensitivity and significance. As I have already mentioned, no one, not even the mining industry, suggests that such areas would be the subject of mining or even exploration. But the idea of tying up vast areas of land as national parks and declaring them then completely out of bounds to any other uses-particularly to any major economic use-when there is such great wealth there is becoming very out of date.

Modern methods of rehabilitation of mining areas make restoration possible after the mining operation is completed in the kind of area we are discussing; that is, this lowland scrub area which has been far better described by Senator Gareth Evans as `clapped out buffalo country'. That is probably the clearer vision of it. It is certainly the vision of it which I have had when I have visited there, as I have done on several occasions. That sort of country can be easily restored. We are not talking about threatening the wildlife or the wetland area. We are not talking about tearing down the rock art galleries. We are not talking about great beauty spots, such as Jim Jim Falls, which people see in beautiful pictures in weekly magazines and so on. We are talking about a balanced use of a large area of Australia. It is not only outmoded thinking by Professor Ovington, the Australian Democrats, the Government and the Australian Labor Party; we have seen in other places how a multiple use policy can work. For instance, the Barrow Island oilfield in Western Australia has a status in Western Australian law equivalent to that of a national park under Federal legislation. Under the very good advice of a notable environmentalist-probably the most notable in Australia, Harry Butler-that status allows this multiple land use to occur there.

We will have to see more and more of this because Australia cannot afford to tie up such vast areas of land of high mineral prospectivity, as is this area, from even the assessment of its mineral potential. Decisions on whether a major mineral resource, upon discovery, would be mined would have to be made at a later date, depending upon the place, the environmental studies, and, of course, if it is Aboriginal land, on the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. The mining industry understands the need for that. All we are saying is that proper mineral exploration should be allowed to continue in this area. We are not talking only about uranium, although this area is highly prospective for uranium. It is also highly prospective for a range of other minerals, such as gold particularly, probably platinum, and copper, silver, lead and zinc.

The Government made this panic-stricken decision, as I have said, overnight at a time when the Prime Minister and the Minister for Resources and Energy were in fact exploring and endeavouring to have the Government accept the multiple land use policy. The Caucus reversed that and we were landed with this plan of management which we seek to disallow because it simply locks up this land without us ever even knowing its mineral potential, preventing us from making rational decisions in Australia's time of economic need. No greater problem can face Australia at the moment than that of its export resource area, with our current balance of payments continually running Australia so heavily into overseas debt. It is increasing each month by such horrific amounts. Of course, we had an example of this the other day. Australia cannot afford to lock out the mining industry, which is one of the major creators of wealth in this country and which accounts for over 40 per cent of our export earnings. Here we have the Government and the Democrats trying to lock out the mining industry from more and more areas of land which may otherwise have been available for the discovery of the wealth which Australia so desperately needs and will continue to need for the foreseeable future at least. For all those reasons, the Opposition has moved to disallow this totally inadequate plan of management. It has been criticised by many people.

I was interested to note the many other reasons, which Senator Puplick explained the other night, that this plan of management is deficient. Professor Slatyer, one of Australia's most distinguished scientists and the Chairman of the Australian Science and Technology Council, has also criticised the plan as lacking a clear statement of the values to be preserved.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: International Year of Peace: Geilston Bay High School Petition-Women for Peace

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In August this year I was nearing the end of an afternoon of interviews with various constituents and lobby groups in my office in Salamanca Place in Hobart when a group of students from Geilston Bay High School trooped in. I was very quickly captivated by the enthusiasm of this group of young Australians who came up with a very ambitious project as their practical contribution to the International Year of Peace. They wanted to circulate a petition to other schools in Tasmania which would express the concerns and, to put it more positively, the hopes of young Australians who are so much more aware of political issues than I was at their age. The core group at Gielston Bay High School-and I have in front of me their photographs in the Tasmania media which has been very supportive of the project-are Joanne Fleming, Janet Sieven, Melissa Cracknell, Melinda Maddock, who I think conceived the idea at a student representative council meeting, and Simon Padman, the SRC President, at that high school. They were assisted by Peter Godfrey, a social science teacher.

SPEECH.PARA: I explained to them how to formulate a petition, whose wording as we know is very ancient, as befits one of the longest standing forms of voicing a concern to the elected representatives of the people in parliament assembled. I thought that this spontaneous expression of hope was so vital that my office was put at the disposal of the students. We obtained a list of all the schools in Australia, some 2,359, and circulated the petition with an accompanying letter. I would like to read some of the paragraphs from that letter sent by Simon Padman as President of Geilston Bay Students Representative Council. It reads as follows:
Dear Fellow Students

Geilston Bay High School Students Representative Council has decided to do something toward the Year of Peace. We intend presenting a petition to the Federal Parliament asking our Government to work towards a more peaceful world.

The idea came about after a suggestion in a meeting that school kids our age `Blaze a Trail' for a more peaceful Australia. Despite it being the International Year of Peace it didn't seem as though anything of significance would be accomplished by anyone or group that would represent the thoughts of youth in Australia.
In the not too distant future it is going to be our Australia. We have an opportunity now to have a say in what that future may be like.

There are 2,359 High Schools in Australia. If a significant number of their students sign the petition, we can have a great impact on our future. The more signatures your school provides, the more successful our campaign for a peaceful world will be. We have the chance to present to our Federal Parliament, the biggest petition ever.

The point I wish to make initially-and I am sure that Mr Godfrey would wish to emphasise this point also-is that we played merely a support role to the whole school, which became involved in the project. As the Mercury `Out of the Blue' weekly feature on young people noted in an article on 2 October this year:
The entire Geilston Bay High School has been involved in the project.
Each of the envelopes to the 2,259 Australian schools had to be stamped with the school emblem, addressed by hand and filled with petition forms and explanatory letters.
So there wasn't a student who wasn't roped in to help.
What then are the words of the petition? It reads:

To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the under-signed citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that in the International Year of Peace, young Australians face an uncertain future due to:
1. A continuing arms race between the super-powers which threatens to extend into outer space,
2. Military expenditure continuing at ridiculously high levels,
3. Continuing testing and stockpiling of nuclear weapons,
Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament to do everything possible to make our future more certain, by:
1. Encouraging peaceful dialogue through diplomatic channels as the means of solving issues,
2. Persuading all developed countries to spend less on armaments, and more on basic needs like food, health, shelter and education for all people of the world,
3. Promoting the extension of agreements to reduce testing and stockpiling of nuclear weapons.
And your petitioners as in duty will ever pray.

What has been the response? So far I have tabled in this chamber petitions from some 8,357 signatories. I know that at least 7,000 more have been received at Geilston Bay High School over the last couple of days. No doubt I shall have an opportunity to present even more petitions to this chamber when we return after the time in our electorates. So far some hundreds of schools, both government and non-government, throughout Australia have responded with signatures freely gathered usually by the student representative council in the school concerned.

There are those who have described this project as revealing how young people can be deceived or manipulated. The attacks in the Press have no doubt begun the political education of some of the pupils concerned. That is what they can expect if they are daring enough to try to change the world in a peaceful direction and if they voice their concerns and hopes in a public way rather than just over a cup of coffee with a few friends. These young people I met are not the types to be easily manipulated. On the contrary, they realise their emerging power to require politicians to be answerable for their future, and we must listen to be truly representative. Alistair Hobday, Head Prefect of the Rose Bay High School, in a letter accompanying signatures from that school said:
Our politicians, concerned as they appear, are mostly alienated from the youth of today. Thus you are helping to guide the leaders of the country.

That was a letter written to Simon Padman who circulated his letter with the petition forms to all schools throughout Australia. I believe that the impact of the expression of opinion by these young people on our politicians has captured the imagination of many pupils in many schools throughout Australia. I ask leave to have incorporated in Hansard a list of the schools in Tasmania which have responded to this request for signatures on the petition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this International Year of Peace and on the occasion of the visit to Australia and to this Parliament today of representatives of the Great Peace Journey initiated by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, I wish to speak about women and our vital contribution to world peace. I am very happy to follow Senator Tate's contribution on the subject of peace and youth. We are living in a time which is unique. Never before in our history have we had the capacity to destroy the earth, its people and every living thing many times over. It is a fact that this dreadful prospect did not exist before the development of nuclear weapons. It is also a fact that these weapons of destruction were created, designed and have been progressively developed by scientists, by the military, by men-powerful men, in powerful positions.

SPEECH.PARA: Down the centuries, the worlds of science and the military have been virtually exclusively the preserve of men-men who have developed these weapons, men who have trained other men to use them, men who have given the orders, and men, as well as women and children, who have died from their own weapons. The women of the world have largely been excluded from the laboratories, the armaments factories-except as a reserve work force in times of war-the educational institutions of the military colleges and the political and military decision-making process. This is the environment in which wars are made to happen-a male world from which women have largely been excluded and in which women of peace do not want to be included. More than that, women of peace want a world of peace and such a world will not come from an environment of war. This very different perspective of women of peace needs desperately to be introduced into the community's consciousness and into the decision-making process at personal, local, national and even global levels, as the representatives of the Great Peace Journey with whom I had lunch today clearly agree and recognise.

One way of doing this is for women to highlight their values, their roles and themselves at appropriate times and in appropriate places. Until recently our community has always taken for granted a number of exclusively male domains. As someone who lived in the country, I well recall that the bar of the local pub was certainly a place where no woman would be seen. Fortunately, that has changed, just as the attitude to other traditionally all male preserves is changing. I mention particularly the all-male members' stand at the Melbourne Cricket Ground and the all-male members' enclosure at Moonee Valley Racecourse. Unfortunately, there has been no change in the membership of clubs such as the Melbourne Club, the Canberra Club and so on. We still have our male preserves.

The lawns in front of Parliament House have become a traditional place for the widest possible range of groups to highlight their concerns, values and presence. They have ranged from the Aboriginal `embassy', to the atom free `embassy', the Vietnamese camp and scores of others. The very day I came to this place as a senator, there were students camped on those lawns expressing their concerns. The fact that women, believing as I do and as they do that they have a special role to play in the promotion and achievement of world peace and in creating an environment of balance rather than war, chose to follow that tradition and camp on the lawns of Parliament House should not be seen in any way as particularly remarkable or threatening. Groups and individuals who have felt threatened, because they are still tied to the confrontationist modes of thinking and acting, have been unable to accept the naturalness of what that camp is and means. Any group wanting to highlight the issue of United States bases, Australia's role in world nuclear strategies and the whole issue of war and violence would have to decide that the most appropriate place was in front of Parliament and that the most appropriate time was when the Pine Gap lease could be ended, if the Government so wished.

Many other women around Australia have chosen this time to demonstrate in a variety of ways, as I did last Sunday in Melbourne. Many men have joined in these protests and will continue to do so. I support what Women for Peace are doing, as do so many of my colleagues in this place. So, too, do a great many enlightened men who, far from feeling threatened, welcome the moves of which this is just a part, towards a more balanced and humane society.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 29 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of a recent statement attributed to business analyst David Price, that under proposed Government guidelines trustees of superannuation funds would become `whipping horses'.

(2) Is the Minister concerned that such claims are part of the conservative campaign against the current Australian Council of Trade Unions' National Productivity Case and the introduction of universal occupational superannuation.
(3) Will the Minister give consideration to the provision of an educational program for trustees of such schemes, by the Government, should a need later emerge.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of a statement by Mr Price on this matter. That statement indicated, inter alia, that the responsibilities of trustees will increase as a result of the application of the Government's Operational Standards to superannuation funds and that the trustee would become the pivot point/`whipping horse' for superannuation in Australia.

The Government recognises that the Operational Standards, announced by the Treasurer on 11 June 1986, will impose responsibilities on trustees beyond those arising from trust law generally. The Standards are aimed at ensuring that taxation concessions for occupational superannuation are directed towards meeting members' retirement needs and enhancing protection of their entitlements.

(2) The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, in its National Wage Case decision of 26 June 1986, indicated that it would not impose by arbitration any obligation on employers to pay contributions to occupational superannuation schemes on behalf of their employees during the life of the current Wage Fixing Principles.

However, the Commission's decision provides for award prescription of superannuation by way of consent agreements. The Commission has stated that it will certify agreements or make consent awards which provide for payment of employer contributions up to the equivalent of 3 per cent of ordinary time earnings to approved superannuation schemes, subject to a number of conditions outlined in the decision. The operative date for employer contributions will not be before 1 January 1987 except in special and isolated circumstances.

Consequently, superannuation is now a matter to be processed in a rational and orderly manner under the centralised wage fixing system. The Commission's decision is one to which all unions, employers and governments should give their strong commitment.

(3) I do not see any need for the Government to provide for an educational program of the kind mentioned and would note that this appears to be largely a matter for consideration by the relevant industry and professional bodies. I should add that an Interim Group of the Occupational Superannuation Commissioner has now been established within the Department of the Treasury and that the Group is able to provide background information and advice on the application of the Operational Standards and the new responsibilities being imposed on trustees.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 22 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are overseas born residents, upon qualifying for the Australian pension, advised to claim the pension from their country of origin first, and then apply to the Minister's Department to correct any shortfall that may exist between the overseas pension and the value of the Australian pension; if so, to how many residents of each country does this apply.
(2) Has the value of the supplement received by these pensioners been changed at least 12 times over the past 18 months because of the Government's decision to float the Australian dollar.

(3) Does the Minister for Social Security agree that it is very difficult for these pensioners to plan with any certainty their financial future, as many of these pensioners are also receiving other income from their country of origin.

(4) Have many of these pensioners who are in receipt of the Commonwealth Pensioner Entitlement Card had their card continually withdrawn then reissued as the value of the Australian dollar varies against other currencies, since March 1983, when the dollar was first floated.

(5) Have those pensioners who have appealed to the social security appeals tribunal about this situation been advised by that tribunal to ignore any letter from the Minister's Department informing them that they are to return their card, and to continue to claim fringe benefits, if so, what action will be taken to correct the conflicting advice given to pensioners by the Minister's Department on this matter.

(6) Does the Minister agree that this whole situation needs to be reviewed and a more enlightened and compassionate policy adopted; if so, will the Minister establish an inquiry and inform the Senate at a later date of its findings and what changes will be implemented as a result.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am not aware of any instances where officers of my Department have been instructed to advise overseas born residents claiming an Australian pension that they must first claim a pension from their country of origin and then make a claim for the difference between the amount of foreign pension paid and the amount of Australian pension payable.

Where it is evident that a person has come from the United Kingdom and there may be eligibility for a UK pension, my Department advises that this entitlement may exist. Such a person is not advised to claim from the UK first and then apply to my Department to correct any shortfall.
In no circumstances would a grant of Australian pension be delayed pending the determination of a claim for foreign pension.

The Reciprocal Social Security Agreement between Australia and the United Kingdom provides that, where a person entitled to an Australian pension by virtue of the Agreement is also entitled to a UK pension, the amount of the UK pension is to be treated as a direct deduction from the Australian pension entitlement. In effect, this tops up (supplements) the UK pension to the maximum rate of Australian pension which the person would be paid under the income and assets test if he or she qualified under the Social Security Act. As at 27 June 1986 there were 12,148 Australian pensioners paid under these arrangements.

The direct deduction provision is not applicable to recipients of UK pension where entitlement is not based on the Australia/UK Reciprocal Social Security Agreement. Any UK pension received in those cases is subject to the normal income test in determining the rate of Australian pension payable.
(2) The amount of Australian pension received by Australia/UK Agreement pensioners has changed 15 times since February 1985.

It has increased 3 times since February 1985, in May and November 1985 and May 1986, due to CPI related increases in the rates of the Australian pension. It has also changed 12 other times since February 1985 due to variations in the notional exchange rate used to value UK pensions and other sterling income. Variations to the notional exchange rate are generally made whenever movements in the actual exchange rates are relatively substantial.

(3) The Australian dollar value of each pensioners total pension package (Australian and UK) has been kept the same even though exchange rates have fluctuated. This is so because the Australian pension paid tops up (supplements) the UK pension to the maximum rate of Australian pension which the person would be paid under the income and assets test if he or she qualified under the Social Security Act. Any other overseas income received would of course be subject to the fluctuations of international exchange rates.
(4) No statistics are kept which would enable me to provide an answer.

(5) I am not aware that the Social Security Appeals Tribunals are advising appellants to ignore departmental advices requesting the return of Pensioner Health Cards and Transport Concession Certificates in situations where entitlement to fringe benefits has been lost. I think it is most unlikely that they would do so. However, if the Honourable Senator is aware of any specific instance where a Tribunal has so advised an appellant I would be pleased to receive more precise details so that I may have the matter fully examined.
